TEXT.English: Inuit
TEXT.German: Inuit:Inuit:Inuit

TEXT.English: Inuit
TEXT.German: Inuit

TEXT.English: [TAB]There are two main groups referred to as Eskimo: Yupik and Inuit. A third group, the Aleut, is related. The Yupik language dialects and cultures in Alaska and eastern Siberia have evolved in place beginning with the original (pre-Dorset) Eskimo culture that developed in Alaska. Approximately 4,000 years ago the Unangam (also known as Aleut) culture became distinctly separate, and evolved into a non-Eskimo culture. Approximately 1,500-2,000 years ago, apparently in Northwestern Alaska, two other distinct variations appeared. The Inuit language branch became distinct and in only several hundred years spread across northern Alaska, Canada and into Greenland. At about the same time, the Thule Technology also developed in northwestern Alaska and very quickly spread over the entire area occupied by Eskimo people, though it was not necessarily adopted by all of them.[PARAGRAPH:1]The earliest known Eskimo cultures were Pre-Dorset Technology, which appear to have been a fully developed Eskimo culture that dates to 5,000 years ago. They appear to have evolved in Alaska from people using the Archaic Small Tools Technology, who probably had migrated to Alaska from Siberia at least 2 to 3 thousand years earlier; though they might have been in Alaska as far back as 10 to 12 thousand years or more. There are similar artifacts found in Siberia going back to perhaps 18,000 years ago. It is believed that the Mongols, Eskimos, and probably the Korean people too all share a common ancestor in northern Asia.[PARAGRAPH:1]Today the two main groups of Eskimos are the Inuit of northern Alaska, Canada and Greenland, and the Yupik, comprising speakers of four distinct Yupik languages and originating in western Alaska, in South Central Alaska along the Gulf of Alaska coast, and in the Russian Far East.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Als Inuit bezeichnen sich die indigenen Volksgruppen, die im arktischen Zentral- und Nordostkanada sowie auf Grönland leben. Die Bezeichnung Eskimo wird als Oberbegriff benutzt, der auch die entfernter verwandten arktischen Volksgruppen der Yupik und der Aleuten umfasst. Die Sprache der Inuit ist Inuktitut (Nordostkanada und Grönland) und Inuinnaqtun (arktisches Zentralkanada). [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Herkunft der Vorfahren der Inuit ist nicht genau bekannt. Bei Inuit-Kleinkindern tritt (wie bei Indianer-Kindern) häufig der Mongolenfleck auf, was durchaus auf eine Verwandtschaft mit heutigen altaischen Völkern hindeuten kann. Als sicher gilt heute, dass Paläo-Eskimo etwa 3000 v. Chr. (lange nach der letzten, etwa 10000 v. Chr. endenden Eiszeit) von Asien aus über die Beringstraße nach Alaska (Nordamerika) einwanderten. Sie sind nach einhelliger archäologischer Auffassung mindestens 12.000 Jahre später als die ersten paläoindianischen Gruppen auf den amerikanischen Kontinent gelangt. Gegen 2500 v. Chr. (das Klima der Arktis war damals wärmer als heute) wanderte ein Teil der Paläo-Eskimo von Alaska bis nach Grönland. In dieser Zeit entwickelte sich die Prä-Dorset-Kultur (mit den Independence-Kulturen I und II sowie der Saqqaq-Kultur). Später - etwa 500 v. Chr. bis 1000 n. Chr. - folgte dann die Dorset-Kultur (benannt nach der heutigen Südbaffin-Siedlung Cape Dorset, in deren Nähe archäologische Fundstücke entdeckt wurden).

TEXT.English: Tuglawina

[H1]Tuglawina[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Inuit Tribes[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1738 - 1798[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Tuglawina's early life, except that he was born in Northern Labrador and by 1770 he had become Anagok (shaman) to his people. Married to Mikak, who was well known to the Moravian missionaries because of her recent stay in England, Tuglawina, served as a pilot on the Moravian sloop sent to find a suitable locale for the Nain mission, and in 1775, transported several Moravians in his own boat to seek a site for the Hoffenthal mission. [PARAGRAPH:1] Eventually separated from Mikak, Tuglawina took several additional wives, and by 1782 had four wives, a mark of extraordinary prestige at a time when the most successful Inuit men had only two or three spouses. Trading at some of the fishing and sealing posts for muskets and gunpowder, Tuglawina became a successful middleman, trading goods to the Inuit who lived north of the missions, and carrying south in his sloop valuable raw materials to the Europeans. Though despite his success many of his followers left him, and he became obsessed that his enemies were plotting against him in retribution for his role in the murders of several rival Inuit years earlier.[PARAGRAPH:1] By 1790, Tuglawina had stopped his southern trading venture, and along with his one remaining wife moved to the mission at Nain. Baptized in 1783, he was accepted into the church congregation at Nain in 1793 and became a strong advocate for Christianity. He died of pleurisy in 1798 and was buried in the mission cemetery.

Æåíàòûé íà Ìèêàê, õîðîøî çíàêîìîé ìîðàâñêèì ìèññèîíåðàì, òàê êàê îíà íåçàäîëãî äî òîãî îñòàíàâëèâàëàñü â Àíãëèè, Òóãëàâèíà áûë ëîöìàíîì íà ìîðàâñêîì øëþïå, îòïðàâëåííîì íàéòè ïîäõîäÿùóþ ìåñòíîñòü äëÿ ìèññèè Íýéí, à â 1775 âîçèë íåñêîëüêèõ ìîðàâèéöåâ â ñâîåé ñîáñòâåííîé ëîäêå, ïîäûñêèâàÿ ìåñòî äëÿ ìèññèè Õîôôåíòàëÿ.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â êîíöå êîíöîâ ðàññòàâøèñü ñ Ìèêàê, Òóãëàâèíà âçÿë ñåáå åùå íåñêîëüêèõ æåí è ê 1782 ãîäó èìåë ÷åòûðåõ, ÷òî áûëî çíàêîì íåîáû÷àéíîãî ïðåñòèæà â òî âðåìÿ, êîãäà ó ñàìûõ óñïåøíûõ èíóèòîâ áûëî ïî äâå-òðè ñóïðóãè. Îäíàêî íåñìîòðÿ íà âñþ åãî óñïåøíîñòü, ìíîãèå ïîñëåäîâàòåëè ïîêèíóëè Òóãëàâèíó, è îí ñòàë îäåðæèì ìûñëüþ î òîì, ÷òî ÿêîáû åãî âðàãè ñãîâîðèëèñü ïðîòèâ íåãî, ÷òîáû îòîìñòèòü çà åãî ó÷àñòèå â óáèéñòâå íåñêîëüêèõ âðàãîâ èç ÷èñëà èíóèòîâ ãîäû ðàíåå.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ê 1790 Òóãëàâèíà îñòàâèë ñâîþ òîðãîâóþ àâàíòþðó íà þãå è âìåñòå ñ åäèíñòâåííîé îñòàâøåéñÿ æåíîé ïåðååõàë â ìèññèþ Íýéí. Òàê êàê â 1783 ãîäó îí áûë êðåùåí, â 1793 åãî ïðèíÿëè â ïàñòâó Íýéíà, è îí ñòàë ÿðûì ñòîðîííèêîì õðèñòèàíñòâà. Òóãëàâèíà óìåð â 1798 ãîäó îò ïðåâðèòà è áûë ïîõîðîíåí íà êëàäáèùå ìèññèè Íýéí.
TEXT.German: [H1]Tuglawina[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Inuit Stämme[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]c. 1738 - 1798[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Wenig ist über das frühe Leben von Tuglawina bekannt, ausser dass er im nördlichen Labrador geboren wurde und um 1770 Anagok (Shamane) seiner Leute wurde. Verheiratet mit Mikak, die aufgrund ihres kürzlichen Aufenthaltes in England, den Moravian Missionaren gut bekannt war, diente Tuglawina als Führer um einen Ort für die Nain Mission und die Hoffenthal Mission zu finden. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach der Trennung von Mikak nahm sich Tuglawina weitere Frauen. Gegeb 1782 hatte er vier Ehefrauen, was ein grosses Zeichen des Erfolges und Standarsymbol darstellte, da selbst die erfolgreichsten Inuit meist nur zwei und in seltenen Fällen drei Ehefrauen hatten. Tuglawina wurde ein erfolgreicher Mittelsmann im Austausch von Rechten für Fischgründe oder Seehundjagdgründe gegen Waffen und Schiesspulver, wie auch im Handel mit Gütern für die Inuit nördlich der Missionen und Rohstoffen für die südlicher lebenden Europäer. Trotz - oder vielleicht auch gerade aufgrund - seines Erfolges verliessen ihn viele seiner Anhänger und Tuglawina wurde von dem Gedanken besessen, seine Gegner würden sich zur Rache, aufgrund seiner Rolle bei Morden von rivalisierenden Inuit Jahre zuvor, verschwören.[PARAGRAPH:1] Gegen 1790 beendete Tuglawina seine Handelsunternehmungen und zog mit einer verbliebenen Frau in die Mission von Nain. 1783 getauft, wurde er ein starker Verfechter des Christentums. 1798 starb er an Rippenfellentzündung und wurde auf dem Missionsfriedhof begraben.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Tuglawina[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Inuit Tribes[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1738 - 1798[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Tuglawina's early life, except that he was born in Northern Labrador and by 1770 he had become Anagok (shaman) to his people. Married to Mikak, who was well known to the Moravian missionaries because of her recent stay in England, Tuglawina, served as a pilot on the Moravian sloop sent to find a suitable locale for the Nain mission, and in 1775, transported several Moravians in his own boat to seek a site for the Hoffenthal mission. [PARAGRAPH:1] Eventually separated from Mikak, Tuglawina took several additional wives, and by 1782 had four wives, a mark of extraordinary prestige at a time when the most successful Inuit men had only two or three spouses. Trading at some of the fishing and sealing posts for muskets and gunpowder, Tuglawina became a successful middleman, trading goods to the Inuit who lived north of the missions, and carrying south in his sloop valuable raw materials to the Europeans. Though despite his success many of his followers left him, and he became obsessed that his enemies were plotting against him in retribution for his role in the murders of several rival Inuit years earlier.[PARAGRAPH:1] By 1790, Tuglawina had stopped his southern trading venture, and along with his one remaining wife moved to the mission at Nain. Baptized in 1783, he was accepted into the church congregation at Nain in 1793 and became a strong advocate for Christianity. He died of pleurisy in 1798 and was buried in the mission cemetery.

TEXT.English: Hello. I am [OUR_NAME], chief and Angakkuq of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Be our guest for tonight, for our seal hunters could return any moment now.
TEXT.French: Ïðèâåòñòâóþ âàñ. ß [OUR_NAME], âîæäü è àíãàêóê ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3]. Ïîãîñòèòå ó íàñ ýòèì âå÷åðîì, èáî íàøè îõîòíèêè çà íåðïàìè ìîãóò âåðíóòüñÿ â ëþáîé ìîìåíò.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Inuit. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Do you know why we have so many words for snow? Because snow is vastly more interesting to us than you are. Go away.
TEXT.French: Ó íàñ ìíîãî ñëîâ, êîòîðûå îáîçíà÷àþò ñíåã, ýòî íóæíî íàì äëÿ óäà÷íîé îõîòû. Äëÿ ëæåöîâ ó íàñ âñåãî îäíî ñëîâî, ïîòîìó ÷òî îò òàêèõ ëþäåé äîñòàòî÷íî èçáàâèòüñÿ. Ïðîùàéòå.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Too late. Because of your crimes, the spirits of the northern lights have marked you for death.
TEXT.French: Ïîçäíî. Çà âàøè ïðåñòóïëåíèÿ äóõè ñåâåðíîãî ñèÿíèÿ ïðèãîâîðèëè âàñ ê ñìåðòè.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people gladly welcome the leader of their [CT_CIV_ADJ] friends. How can we be of assistance?
TEXT.French: Ïëåìÿ [OUR_CIV_ADJ] ðàäî ïðèâåòñòâîâàòü âîæäÿ ñâîèõ [CT_CIV_ADJ] äðóçåé. ×åì ìû ìîæåì âàì ïîìî÷ü?
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Häuptling Tuglawina aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Back again? Please, educate us further in the fine arts of deceit and treachery.
TEXT.French: Åñëè âû çàáëóäèëèñü â ìîåì ïîñåëåíèè, ïîïðîñèòå ìîèõ îõîòíèêîâ - îíè ñ ðàäîñòüþ óêàæóò âàì äîðîãó îòñþäà.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: ß è ìîè ëþäè íóæäàåìñÿ â ïîìîùè, ìîæåò ëè [CT_EMPIRE] ïîìî÷ü?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèõîæó ñ ìèðîì, ÷òîáû ïîïðîñèòü âàñ î ïîìîùè. ×òî ñêàæåòå?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I hold the fate of the [CT_EMPIRE] in my hand. Give me what I demand.
TEXT.French: Ñóäüáà [CT_EMPIRE] â ìîèõ ðóêàõ. ß ìîãó ñäåëàòü òàê, ÷òî óäà÷à îòâåðíåòñÿ îò âàñ.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Huron
TEXT.German: Huronen

TEXT.English: Huron
TEXT.German: Huronen

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Huron, who are also known as the Wyandot, originally inhabited the area of central Ontario. Little is known of the history of the Huron's before the arrival of the French upon the shores of the St. Lawrence in 1535. [PARAGRAPH:1] Prior to the arrival of the Europeans, the Huron may of numbered as many as 40,000 people. French estimates of the four core tribes that made up the Huron Confederacy in 1615 numbered the Huron population from 20,000 -30,000 spread throughout 16-25 villages. However, European contact proved devastating for the Huron, and by 1640 successive epidemics and wars had reduced their number to less than 10,000. In 1609, the Huron entered into a loose military and economic alliance with the French against the Iroquois. This allowed the Huron to eventually become the preferred trading partner of the French, and to act as intermediaries between the French and other trading tribes. War with their long standing enemy the Iroquois, continued throughout the early part of the 17th Century until 1649-50, when the Iroquois armed with guns supplied from Dutch and English colonies overrun the Huron, driving them from their lands. Those that survived split into two groups. The first group migrated to Lorette, just north of Quebec, while the remaining Huron that had merged with the Tionontati, Erie and Neutral tribes, endured a harsh nomadic existence for the remainder of the century traveling through present day Wisconsin, Minnesota and upper Michigan. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the early 1700's the Huron had moved to the Ohio Valley, where they aided the French during the Fox Wars 1712-16 and 1728-33. Switching allegiance between the French and the British over the next 20 years, the Huron sided with the French during the French and Indian War 1754-63, and then sided with the British against the Americans during the American Revolutionary War 1775-83. Each succeeding war took its toll on the Huron's and by the end of the 1780s they had been reduced to little over a 100 warriors. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Huron continued to remain in the Ohio Valley until the 1840's when they were removed to Kansas. The Huron living in the United States today are known as Wyandot and are to be found primarily in Kansas and Oklahoma.

Ñåãîäíÿ ãóðîíû, æèâóùèå â ÑØÀ, èçâåñòíû êàê âàéàíäîòû è íàõîäÿòñÿ ïðåæäå âñåãî â Êàíçàñå è Îêëàõîìå.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Huronen (oder Wyandot oder Wendat - für die Zeit bis um 1700 ist die vom französischen hurons abgeleitete Bezeichnung Huronen geläufig) waren, als die ersten Europäer im 16. Jahrhundert mit ihnen Kontakt aufnahmen, eine Konföderation von fünf indianischen Ethnien. Sie sprachen eine der irokesischen Sprachen. Zu den Wyandot zählten etwa 30.000 Menschen, doch durch Pockenepidemien und die Biberkriege (1640-1701) brach die Bevölkerungszahl zusammen - in Kanada bis 1760 auf etwa hundert Menschen. Andere, ebenfalls versprengte Gruppen schlossen sich Wyandotgruppen an, doch mussten diese südlicheren Gruppen innerhalb der USA westwärts ziehen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Ursprünglich waren die Wyandot Teil des irokesischen Volkes, trennten sich aber von diesem und verbündeten sich mit Algonkin-Völkern. Wie die Irokesen lebten sie in Langhäusern und betrieben Landwirtschaft. Gegen 1300 schlossen sich mehrere Clans zusammen und bildeten die Attignawantan (Attignousntan), die innerhalb der sich bildenden Wyandot-Konföderation der beherrschende und größte Stamm werden sollten. Um 1420 schlossen sich diesen die Attingneenangnahoc an, und diese beiden Stämme gründeten die Wyandot-Konföderation. Als Hauptstadt wurde Ossossane gewählt, die größte Siedlung der Attignawantan. Mit der Verbreitung und dem teilweisen Abzug der Sankt-Lorenz-Irokesen aus dem östlichen Ontario schlossen sich 1560 die Arendahronon sowie 1570 die Tahontaenrat (Tohonaenrat) der Konföderation an. Jeder Stamm sandte Repräsentanten zum gemeinsamen Rat in Ossossane, in dem über Krieg und Frieden, Bündnisse sowie Handel und Jagd beraten wurde. Auf dem Höhepunkt ihrer Macht gehörten dem Rat der Wyandot etwa 52 Mitglieder an. [PARAGRAPH:1] Bald nach Ankunft der Franzosen, ihren langjährigen Verbündeten, erlangten sie eine beherrschende Stellung im Fellhandel. Doch die Franzosen hatten sich hierdurch die mächtige Irokesen-Liga zum Feind gemacht, die sich im Covenant Chain mit den Engländern verbündeten und von diesen (wie zuvor von den Niederländern) mit Waffen versorgt wurden. Dies gab den zahlenmäßig schwächeren Irokesen eine enorme militärische Schlagkraft gegenüber den sie umgebenden Stämmen, zumal die Wyandot 1639 schwer von einer Pockenepidemie getroffen wurden. Besonders die Mohawk stiegen durch diese Kämpfe zu den wichtigsten Handelspartnern der Briten am Hudson River auf und bekriegten fortan die südlichen Verbündeten der Wyandot, die Susquehannock. Langsam wurden die Susquehannock durch die Attacken der Mohawk und Oneida immer mehr aufgerieben und geschwächt. Die Huronen ihrerseits ließen sich, nachdem die Engländer 1629 Quebec erobert hatten (bis 1632) durch Jean Nicolet für einen Boykott der Engländer gewinnen.

TEXT.English: Huron

TEXT.English: Kondiaronk

[H1]Kondiaronk[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Petun Huron[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1649 - 1701[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Known by the French as "Le Rat", Kondiaronk was one of the most successful Huron war chiefs of the 17th Century. [PARAGRAPH:1] A powerful orator and shrewd strategist, he led the pro-French Petun and Huron refugees against their bitter rivals the Iroquois. Ever fearful that the Iroquois would seek to finish the destruction of his own tribe, Kondiaronk used a combination of persuasion and force to unite the tribes of the upper Lakes preventing them from making their own peace treaties with the Iroquois. [PARAGRAPH:1] Wishing to prevent a separate peace pact between the French and the Iroquois, in 1688 he ambushed and captured an Iroquois peace envoy en route near present day Oswego, evoking the anger of the Governor General of New France. Nine years later in 1697, he led another war party that killed 55 Seneca in a two hour canoe battle on Lake Erie, ending the Seneca's attempts to ally with disaffected Huron's and split the solidarity of the pro-French tribes.[PARAGRAPH:1] A general weakening of Iroquois strength through both disease and war, along with the inability of the English to protect the Iroquois' northern and western boarders, forced the Iroquois to more seriously pursue peace with their neighboring Indian tribes and the French. Kondiaronk helped craft the 1701 Great Peace of Montreal, which secured peace for France, and her Indian allies of the great lakes with the Iroquois Confederacy, ended the Beaver wars and opened up the interior of the continent for further French exploration and trade. [PARAGRAPH:1] Kondiaronk did not live to see the results of his work, he contracted a fever and died in Montreal during the negotiations for the Great Peace.
TEXT.French: [H1]Êîíäüÿðîíê[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Âîæäü ïëåìåíè ïåòóí[NEWLINE]Ãîäû æèçíè: [\BOLD]îê. 1649 - 1701[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Áèîãðàôèÿ:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Èçâåñòíûé ôðàíöóçàì êàê ''Êðûñà'', Êîíäüÿðîíê áûë îäíèì èç ñàìûõ óñïåøíûõ âîæäåé ãóðîíîâ XVII âåêà.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ñèëüíûé îðàòîð è õèòðûé ñòðàòåã, îí âîçãëàâèë ïðîôðàíöóçñêèå ïëåìåíà ïåòóí è ãóðîíñêèõ áåæåíöåâ â áîðüáå ñî çëåéøèìè âðàãàìè, èðîêåçàìè. Äàæå ïîä ñòðàõîì òîãî, ÷òî èðîêåçû ïîïûòàþòñÿ çàêîí÷èòü íà÷àòûé èìè ãåíîöèä åãî ïëåìåíè, Êîíäüÿðîíê èñïîëüçîâàë ñî÷åòàíèå äàðà óáåæäåíèÿ è ñèëû, ÷òîáû îáúåäèíèòü ïëåìåíà âåðõíèõ Âåëèêèõ îçåð, ÷òî ïðåäîòâðàòèëî âîçìîæíîñòü çàêëþ÷åíèÿ èìè ñâîèõ ñîáñòâåííûõ ìèðíûõ äîãîâîðîâ ñ èðîêåçàìè.[PARAGRAPH:1]Æåëàÿ ïðåäîòâðàòèòü ïîäïèñàíèå îòäåëüíîãî ìèðíîãî äîãîâîðà ìåæäó ôðàíöóçàìè è èðîêåçàìè, îí óñòðîèë çàñàäó è çàõâàòèë â ïëåí ãîíöà èðîêåçîâ, êîãäà òîò åõàë ïðîñèòü ìèðà âîçëå ñåãîäíÿøíåãî Îñóèãî, ÷òî âûçâàëî áåøåíñòâî Ãåíåðàë-ãóáåðíàòîðà Íîâîé Ôðàíöèè. Äåâÿòü ëåò ñïóñòÿ, â 1697 ãîäó, îí âîçãëàâëÿë äðóãîé îòðÿä, êîòîðûé óáèë 55 èíäåéöåâ ïëåìåíè ñåíåêà â äâóõ÷àñîâîé áèòâå íà êàíîý íà îçåðå Ýðè, ïîêîí÷èâ ñ ïîïûòêàìè ïëåìåíè ñåíåêà çàêëþ÷èòü ñîþç ñ íåëîÿëüíûìè åìó ãóðîíàìè, è ðàçäåëèë ñîëèäàðíîñòü ïðîôðàíöóçñêèõ ïëåìåí.[PARAGRAPH:1] Îáùåå îñëàáëåíèå ñèë èðîêåçîâ è áîëåçíÿìè, è âîéíîé âìåñòå ñ íåñïîñîáíîñòüþ àíãëè÷àí çàùèòèòü ñåâåðíûå è âîñòî÷íûå ãðàíèöû çåìëè èðîêåçîâ çàñòàâèëî èõ áîëåå ñåðüåçíî ñòðåìèòüñÿ ê ìèðó ñ ñîñåäíèìè ïëåìåíàìè èíäåéöåâ è ñ ôðàíöóçàìè. Êîíäüÿðîíê ïîìîã ïðèãîòîâèòü Âåëèêèé ìîíðåàëüñêèé ìèð, êîòîðûé ãàðàíòèðîâàë ìèð Ôðàíöèè è åå èíäåéñêèì ñîþçíèêàì èç ñîþçà èðîêåçîâ, çàâåðøèë áîáðîâûå âîéíû è îòêðûë âíóòðåííèé ëàíäøàôò êîíòèíåíòà äëÿ äàëüíåéøèõ ôðàíöóçñêèõ èññëåäîâàíèé è òîðãîâëè.[PARAGRAPH:1]Êîíäüÿðîíê íå äîæèë äî òîãî, ÷òîáû óâèäåòü ðåçóëüòàòû ñâîèõ òðóäîâ. Îí ïîäõâàòèë ëèõîðàäêó è óìåð â Ìîíðåàëå âî âðåìÿ ïåðåãîâîðîâ î Âåëèêîì ìèðå.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kondiaronk[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Petun Huronen[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]c. 1649 - 1701[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Bei den Franzosen als "Die Ratte" bekannt, war Kondiaronk einer der erfolgreichsten Häuptlinge der Huronen des 17ten Jahrhunderts. [PARAGRAPH:1] Als ein überzeugender Sprecher und gewiefter Stratege führt er die pro-französischen Petun und Huronen gegen ihre erbitterten Rivalen die Iroquesen. Stets in Sorge, dass die Iroquesen letztlich die vollständige Auslöschung seines Stammes wieder vorantreiben könnten, nutzte Kondiaronk eine Kombination aus überredung und Gewalt um die Stämme der Oberen Seen zu vereinen um damit zu verhindern, dass diese eigene Friedensabkommen mit den Iroquesen schliessen würden. [PARAGRAPH:1] Mit dem Ziel einen separaten Frieden zwischen Franzosen und Iroquesen zu verhindern, überfiel er 1688 iroquesische Abgesandte auf einer Strecke in der Nähe des heutigen Oswego und zog sich damit den Unmut des Gouvernuer Generals von Neu Frankreich zu. Neun Jahre später in 1697 führte er einen Kriegstrupp, der 55 Seneca in einem zweistündigen Kampf mit Canoes auf dem Lake Eire tötete und damit die Versuche der Seneca beendete sich mit übergelaufenen Huronen zu verbünden, was zum Bruch der Solidarität der pro-französichen Stämme führte. [PARAGRAPH:1] Eine allgmeine Schwächung der Iroquesen durch sowohl Krankheiten, wie auch Kriege aber auch die Unfähigkeit der Engländer, die nördlichen und westlichen Grenzen der Iroquesen zu schützen, zwang die Iroquesen dazu ersthafterer Anstrengungen für den frieden mit benachbarten Ureinwohnerstämmen und den Franzosen zu betreiben. Kondiaronk half darauf im Jahr 1701 dabei den Grossen Frieden von Montreal zu schmieden, welcher den Frieden für Frankreich und dessen alliierten Stämme mit der Iroquesen Föderation sicherte. Dies beendete den sogenannten Bieber Krieg und öffnete das Inland des Kontinents für weitere Erkundung und Handel für die Franzosen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Kondiaronk lebte nicht lange genug um die Ergebnisse seiner Arbeit zu sehen, da er noch während der Verhandlungen für den Grossen Frieden in Montreal an Fieber starb.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Kondiaronk[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Petun Huron[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1649 - 1701[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Known by the French as "Le Rat", Kondiaronk was one of the most successful Huron war chiefs of the 17th Century. [PARAGRAPH:1] A powerful orator and shrewd strategist, he led the pro-French Petun and Huron refugees against their bitter rivals the Iroquois. Ever fearful that the Iroquois would seek to finish the destruction of his own tribe, Kondiaronk used a combination of persuasion and force to unite the tribes of the upper Lakes preventing them from making their own peace treaties with the Iroquois. [PARAGRAPH:1] Wishing to prevent a separate peace pact between the French and the Iroquois, in 1688 he ambushed and captured an Iroquois peace envoy en route near present day Oswego, evoking the anger of the Governor General of New France. Nine years later in 1697, he led another war party that killed 55 Seneca in a two hour canoe battle on Lake Erie, ending the Seneca's attempts to ally with disaffected Huron's and split the solidarity of the pro-French tribes.[PARAGRAPH:1] A general weakening of Iroquois strength through both disease and war, along with the inability of the English to protect the Iroquois' northern and western boarders, forced the Iroquois to more seriously pursue peace with their neighboring Indian tribes and the French. Kondiaronk helped craft the 1701 Great Peace of Montreal, which secured peace for France, and her Indian allies of the great lakes with the Iroquois Confederacy, ended the Beaver wars and opened up the interior of the continent for further French exploration and trade. [PARAGRAPH:1] Kondiaronk did not live to see the results of his work, he contracted a fever and died in Montreal during the negotiations for the Great Peace.

[PARAGRAPH:1] Kondiaronk did not live to see the results of his work, he contracted a fever and died in Montreal during the negotiations for the Great Peace.

TEXT.English: I am [OUR_NAME], chief of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ], and I bid you welcome. The elders of our people desire to extend the hand of friendship to you and your people. I hope you appreciate the honor we bestow upon you by doing so.
TEXT.French: ß [OUR_NAME], âîæäü [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3], äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü ê íàì. Ñòàðåéøèíû íàøåãî ïëåìåíè æåëàþò ïðîòÿíóòü âàì è âàøåìó íàðîäó ðóêó äðóæáû. Íàäåþñü, ÷òî âû îñòàíåòåñü áëàãîäàðíûìè çà òîò ïî÷åò, êîòîðûé ìû âàì îêàçàëè.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Huronen. Begegnet uns mit Achtung, und wir werden auch Euch achten. Tut es nicht und ihr werdet es bereuen. Ich habe gesprochen.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Leave us alone. We only speak with snakes after we have cut out their venomous fangs.
TEXT.French: Ïðîâàëèâàéòå. Ìû ðàçãîâàðèâàåì ñ ãàäþêîé òîëüêî ïîñëå òîãî, êàê âûðûâàåì ó íåå ÿäîâèòûå çóáû.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: There will be no peace before the [CT_CIV_ADJ] have paid for their crimes with their blood!
TEXT.French: Ìèðà íå áóäåò, ïîêà [CT_CIV_ADJ] íå çàïëàòÿò çà ñâîè çëîäåÿíèÿ êðîâüþ!
TEXT.German: Nein, Bleichgesicht. Wir werden den Kriegspfad nicht verlassen. Erst wenn Euer Skalp in meinem Wigwam hängt, werde ich meine Männer heim zu ihren Kindern und Weibern holen.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the longhouses of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let our meeting take place under the blessing of the Great Spirit.
TEXT.French: Äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü â äëèííûå äîìà [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Äà ñîñòîèòñÿ íàøà âñòðå÷à ïî áëàãîñëîâåíèþ Âåëèêîãî Äóõà.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Lasst uns beraten, wie wir unsere Feinde vernichten.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Your arrival in [OUR_CIV_ADJ] lands was heralded by unrest among evil spirits. Apparently, they are horrified by your presence. As are we. What do you want?
TEXT.French: Êîãäà âû âñòóïèëè íà çåìëþ [OUR_CIV_ADJ], äóõè çëà ïðèøëè â äâèæåíèå. Ýòî äóðíîé çíàê. Ãîâîðèòå áûñòðî è óõîäèòå.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: The spirits have allowed my tribe to suffer much hardship, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: Âåëèêèé Äóõ ïîâåë íàñ òðóäíûì ïóòåì, è ñåé÷àñ ó íàñ êîí÷èëèñü ñèëû. Â òàêîå âðåìÿ ëþäè ïðîñÿò ïîìîùè äðóã ó äðóãà. Ìîæåò ëè [CT_EMPIRE] ïîìî÷ü?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. Will you honor the friendship we have made?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøåë ñ ìèðîì ïðîñèòü ïîìîùè. Ïî÷òèòå ëè âû äðóæáó, êîòîðàÿ ñëîæèëàñü ìåæäó íàìè?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I have the strength to wipe the [CT_EMPIRE] seed from this land. Give me all that I ask.
TEXT.French: Ìîèõ ñèë õâàòèò, ÷òîáû ñêèíóòü âñå ìàëåíüêîå ïëåìÿ [CT_EMPIRE] â îêåàí. Äàéòå ìíå âñå, ÷òî ÿ ïðîøó, òîãäà ÿ íå ïðè÷èíþ âàì çëà.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Zapotec
TEXT.German: Zapotec:Zapotec:Zapotec

TEXT.English: Zapotec
TEXT.German: Zapotec

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Zapotec, the Cloud People, originated in the Oaxaca valley during the latter part of the 6th Century BC. The Zapotec were knowledgeable in both complex Mayan mathematics and are believed to be the first Meso-Americans to develop writing. As their capital of Monte Alban became the largest city in the southern Mexican highland, the Zapotec began to conquer and colonize settlements far beyond the Oaxaca valley. By 900 AD, they had abandoned Monte Alban and moved their religious center to Mitla, only to abandon that site also. Over the next three centuries the Zapotec empire continued to decline as more of their land was lost to an ever increasing Mixtec migration into the Oaxaca valley. Forced to submit to Mixtec rule or migrate from the Oaxaca, the Zapotec moved into the territory of their neighbours, seizing the city of Tehuantepec from the Zoquean and Huavean, and making it their new capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]By the 15th century, both the Zapotecs and Mixtecs had ceased a halt to hostilities against one another in the face of a new regional power, the Aztecs, who were trying to dominate the trade routes outside of Oaxaca. From 1486-1496, war waged between a Zapotec-Mixtec alliance and the Aztecs. The Aztecs destroyed the Zapotec capital cities of Mitla and Zaachila-Yoo, but ultimately were driven out of the region of Tehuantepec, by a Zapotec-Mixtec force under the brilliant generalship of the Zapotec king, Cocijoeza. Under a peace treaty with the Aztecs and Mixtecs, the Zapotecs managed to maintain political autonomy for the next 25 years.[PARAGRAPH:1] Hostilities between Zapotecs and Mixtecs broke out again in 1519, but were interrupted by the arrival of the Spanish. With the fall of the Aztec empire, the Zapotecs pledged allegiance to Cortez, and helped the Spanish defeat the Mixtecs. The Zapotec in turn were conquered by the Spanish in several campaigns from 1522-27.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Ñàïîòåêè (''Îáëà÷íûé Íàðîä'') áåðóò ñâîå íà÷àëî â äîëèíå Îàõàêà â êîíöå VI â. äî í.ý. Ñàïîòåêàì áûëè èçâåñòíû îáå ñëîæíûå ìàòåìàòèêè ïëåìåíè ìàéÿ, à ñàìè îíè ñ÷èòàþòñÿ ïåðâûìè ìåçîàìåðèêàíöàìè, íà÷àâøèìè ïèñàòü. Â òî âðåìÿ êàê èõ ñòîëèöà, Ìîíòå-Àëüáàí, ñòàëà êðóïíåéøèì ãîðîäîì íà òåððèòîðèè âñåãî íàãîðüÿ â þæíîé Ìåêñèêå, ñàïîòåêè íà÷àëè çàâîåâûâàòü è çàñåëÿòü òåððèòîðèè äàëåêî çà ïðåäåëàìè äîëèíû Îàõàêà. Îäíàêî ê 900 ã. í.ý. îíè îñòàâèëè Ìîíòå-Àëüáàí è ïåðåìåñòèëè ñâîé ðåëèãèîçíûé öåíòð â Ìèòëó, íî è ýòî ìåñòî ïðèøëîñü îñòàâèòü. Â òå÷åíèå òðåõ ïîñëåäóþùèõ âåêîâ èìïåðèÿ ñàïîòåêîâ ïðîäîëæàëà òåðÿòü âëèÿíèå, â òî âðåìÿ êàê áîëüøå èõ òåððèòîðèè óòðà÷èâàëîñü âñëåäñòâèå âñå óâåëè÷èâàþùåéñÿ ìèãðàöèè ïëåìåíè ìèøòåêîâ â äîëèíó Îàõàêà. Âûíóæäåííûå ëèáî ïîä÷èíèòüñÿ âëàñòè ìèøòåêîâ, ëèáî óéòè, ñàïîòåêè óøëè íà òåððèòîðèþ ñîñåäíèõ ïëåìåí ñîêå è óàâå, âçÿâ ãîðîä Òåóàíòåïåê è ñäåëàâ åãî ñâîåé ñòîëèöåé.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ê XV âåêó è ñàïîòåêè, è ìèøòåêè ïðèîñòàíîâèëè âðàæäó ñ öåëüþ ñïëîòèòüñÿ ïåðåä ëèöîì íîâîé ðåãèîíàëüíîé ñèëû, àöòåêîâ, êîòîðûå ïûòàëèñü êîíòðîëèðîâàòü òîðãîâûå ïóòè âíå Îàõàêè. Â 1486-1496 ãã. ìåæäó àöòåêàìè è ñîþçîì ìèøòåêîâ è ñàïîòåêîâ áûëà ðàçâÿçàíà âîéíà. Àöòåêè ðàçðóøèëè ãëàâíûå ãîðîäà ñàïîòåêîâ, Ìèòëó è Ñàà÷èëó, íî â êîíöîâ áûëè âûíóæäåíû ïîêèíóòü îáëàñòü Òåóàíòåïåêà ïîä äàâëåíèåì ñèë ñîþçà ñàïîòåêîâ è ìèøòåêîâ ïîä áëåñòÿùèì êîìàíäîâàíèåì öàðÿ ñàïîòåêîâ Êîñèéîýñû. Ïî óñëîâèÿì ìèðíîãî äîãîâîðà ìåæäó àöòåêàìè è ìèøòåêàìè ñàïîòåêàì óäàëîñü ñîõðàíèòü ïîëèòè÷åñêóþ àâòîíîìèþ åùå íà 25 ëåò.[PARAGRAPH:1] Âðàæäà ìåæäó ñàïîòåêàìè è ìèøòåêàìè ñíîâà ðàçãîðåëàñü â 1519, íî áûëà ïðåðâàíà ïðèáûòèåì èñïàíöåâ. Ñ ïàäåíèåì èìïåðèè àöòåêîâ ñàïîòåêè ïðèñÿãíóëè íà âåðíîñòü Êîðòåçó è ïîìîãëè èñïàíöàì ïîáåäèòü ìèøòåêîâ. Â ñâîþ î÷åðåäü óæå ñàìè ñàïîòåêè áûëè çàâîåâàíû èñïàíöàìè â õîäå íåñêîëüêèõ êàìïàíèé â 1522-27 ãã.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Zapotec, das Wolkenvolk, entstanden während des 6ten Jahrhunderts vor Christus im Oaxcatal. Die Zapotec kannten die komplexe Mathematike der Mayan und gelten als das erste Volk Mittelamerikas, dass eine Schrift entwickelte. Als ihre Hauptstadt Monte Alban zur grössten Stadt in den südlichen Hochlanden des heutigen Mexikos anwuchs, begannen sie damit weit über das Oaxaca-Tal hinaus zu kolonisieren und zu erobern. Um 900 nach Christus verliessen sie Monte Alban und verlegten ihr religiöses Zentrum nach Mitla, nur um wenig später auch diese Stadt aufzugeben. Während der nächsten 3 Jahrhunderte schrumpfte das Imperium der Zapotec stetig, da mehr und mehr von ihrem Land von den Mixtec übernommen wurde. Gezwungen sich entweder der Herrschaft der Mixtec zu unterwerfen oder das Oaxaca-Tal zu verlassen, flohen die Zapotec in das Territorium ihrere Nachbarn und eroberten die Stadt Tehuantepec von den Zoquean und Huavean und machten diese zu ihrer neuen Hauptstadt.[PARAGRAPH:1] Im 15. Jahrhundert beendeten die Zapotec und die Mixtec ihre Feindschaft aufgrund einer neuen aufsteigenden Grossmacht, den Azteken. Um 1486 bis 1496, herrschte ein blutiger Krieg zwischen der Zapotec-Mixtec Allianz und den Azteken. Zwar zerstörten die Azteken Mitla und Zaachila-Yoo, die Hauptstädte der Zapotec, wurden jedoch letztlich von einer gemischten Zapotec-Mixtec Streitmacht unter der Befehlsgewalt des brillanten Strategen Cocijoeza wieder aus der Gegend vertrieben. Durch einen Friedensvertrage mit den Azteken und den Mixtec gelang es den Zapotec für die folgenden 25 Jahre autonom zu bleiben.[PARAGRAPH:1] 1519 brach die Feindschaft zwischen Zapotec und Mixtec erneut aus, wurde aber durch die Ankunft der Spanier unterbrochen. Nach dem Fall des Azteken-Imperiums schworen die Zapotec Cortez die Gefolgschaft und halfen bei der Vernichtung der Mixtec. Die Zapotec wiederum wurden in einigen kurzen Campagnen der Spanier zwischen 1522 und 1527 ebenfalls von den Spaniern unterworfen.

TEXT.English: Cocijoeza

[H1]Cocijoeza[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Zapotec[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1460 - 1529[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Cocijoeza was the fourth ruler of the Zapotec kingdom of Zaachila from 1487 until his death in 1529. Regarded as the greatest of the Zapotec kings, Cocijoeza, led an alliance of Zapotecs and Mixtecs against the armies of the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] A shrewd tactician and astute politician, Cocijoeza, quickly realized that playing the two larger powers of the Mixtec and Aztec against one another would help ensure the survival of his kingdom. Knowing the Aztecs would have to invade Mixtec territory before reaching his own, he promised aid to the Mixtecs, while making a separate peace with the Aztec's. After a long and protracted war, a weary Aztec army finally achieved victory over the Mixtecs. Seizing the initiative, Cocijoeza, attacked the weakened Aztecs and defeated them. [PARAGRAPH:1] Cocijoeza tried this tactic again, allying with the Spanish in 1521, in their conquest of the Mixtec, only to see his own people suffer the same fate at the hands of the Spanish.
TEXT.French: [H1]Êîñèéîýñà[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Âîæäü ñàïîòåêîâ[NEWLINE]Ãîäû æèçíè: [\BOLD]îê. 1460 - 1529[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Áèîãðàôèÿ:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Êîñèéîýñà áûë ÷åòâåðòûì ïðàâèòåëåì ñàïîòåêñêîãî öàðñòâà Ñàà÷èëû ñ 1487 äî ñàìîé ñìåðòè â 1529. Ñ÷èòàþùèéñÿ îäíèì èç ñèëüíåéøèõ öàðåé ñàïîòåêîâ, Êîñèéîýñà âåë ñîþç ñàïîòåêîâ è ìèøòåêîâ â áîðüáå ïðîòèâ âîéñê àöòåêîâ.[PARAGRAPH:1] Õèòðûé òàêòèê è èñêóñíûé ïîëèòèê, Êîñèéîýñà áûñòðî ïîíÿë, ÷òî ñòàëêèâàíèå äâóõ áîëåå ñèëüíûõ ïëåìåí äðóã ñ äðóãîì ïîìîãëî áû îáåñïå÷èòü åãî êîðîëåâñòâó âûæèâàíèå. Çíàÿ, ÷òî àöòåêàì ïðèøëîñü áû çàõâàòèòü òåððèòîðèþ ìèøòåêîâ, ïåðåä òåì êàê îíè áû äîñòèãëè åãî, îí ïîîáåùàë ìèøòåêàì ïîìîùü, â òî âðåìÿ êàê ñàì ñ àöòåêàìè ïîìèðèëñÿ. Ïåðåõâàòûâàÿ èíèöèàòèâó, Êîñèéîýñà àòàêîâàë îñëàáëåííûõ àöòåêîâ è èõ ðàçãðîìèë.[PARAGRAPH:1]Êîñèéîýñà ñíîâà ïîïðîáîâàë ýòó òàêòèêó â 1521, ïîìîãàÿ èñïàíöàì â çàâîåâàíèè ìèøòåêîâ, íî â êîíöå êîíöîâ óâèäåë, êàê åãî ñîáñòâåííûé íàðîä ïîòåðïåë òó æå ñàìóþ ñóäüáó â ðóêàõ èñïàíöåâ.
TEXT.German: [H1]Cocijoeza[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Zapotec[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]c. 1460 - 1529[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Cocijoeza war vierter Herrscher des Zapotec Königreiches vono Zaachila von 1487 bis zu seinem Tod im Jahre 1529. Als der grösste König der Zapotec bekannt, führte Cocijoeza eine Allianz von Zapotec und Mixtec gegen die Armeen der Azteken. [PARAGRAPH:1] Als gewiefter Taktiker und kluger Politiker, realisierte Cocijoeza schnell, dass das Auspielen der beiden grösseren Mächte der Mixtec und Aztekeng gegeneinander die einzige Chance zum überleben seines Reiches darstellte. Der Tatsache bewusst, dass die Azteken zuerst das Territorium der Mixtec erober mussten, bevor sie sein Reich direkt bedrohen konnten, versprach der den Mixtec Unterstützung, während er gleichzeitig einen separaten Frieden mit den Azteken schloss. Nach einem langen und aufreibenden Krieg gelang es einer ermüdeten Armee der Azteken schliesslich den Sieg über die Mixtec zu erringen. Die Initiative ergreifen griff Cocijoeza dann die geschwächten Azteken an und errang einen Sieg.[PARAGRAPH:1] Cocijoeza versuchte eine ähnliche Taktik, als er sich 1521 mit den Spaniern bei der Eroberung der Mixtec verbündetet. Dieses Mal jedoch ging diese Taktik nicht auf und letztlich erlitt sein Volk das selbe Schicksal durch die Hände der Spanier, wie zuvor die Azteken und die Mixtec.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Cocijoeza[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Zapotec[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1460 - 1529[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Cocijoeza was the fourth ruler of the Zapotec kingdom of Zaachila from 1487 until his death in 1529. Regarded as the greatest of the Zapotec kings, Cocijoeza, led an alliance of Zapotecs and Mixtecs against the armies of the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] A shrewd tactician and astute politician, Cocijoeza, quickly realized that playing the two larger powers of the Mixtec and Aztec against one another would help ensure the survival of his kingdom. Knowing the Aztecs would have to invade Mixtec territory before reaching his own, he promised aid to the Mixtecs, while making a separate peace with the Aztec's. After a long and protracted war, a weary Aztec army finally achieved victory over the Mixtecs. Seizing the initiative, Cocijoeza, attacked the weakened Aztecs and defeated them. [PARAGRAPH:1] Cocijoeza tried this tactic again, allying with the Spanish in 1521, in their conquest of the Mixtec, only to see his own people suffer the same fate at the hands of the Spanish.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Cocijoeza[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Zapotec[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1460 - 1529[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Cocijoeza was the fourth ruler of the Zapotec kingdom of Zaachila from 1487 until his death in 1529. Regarded as the greatest of the Zapotec kings, Cocijoeza, led an alliance of Zapotecs and Mixtecs against the armies of the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] A shrewd tactician and astute politician, Cocijoeza, quickly realized that playing the two larger powers of the Mixtec and Aztec against one another would help ensure the survival of his kingdom. Knowing the Aztecs would have to invade Mixtec territory before reaching his own, he promised aid to the Mixtecs, while making a separate peace with the Aztec's. After a long and protracted war, a weary Aztec army finally achieved victory over the Mixtecs. Seizing the initiative, Cocijoeza, attacked the weakened Aztecs and defeated them. [PARAGRAPH:1] Cocijoeza tried this tactic again, allying with the Spanish in 1521, in their conquest of the Mixtec, only to see his own people suffer the same fate at the hands of the Spanish.

TEXT.English: I am [OUR_NAME], king of the peaceful [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. I hope you share our ideals of friendship and fellowship.
TEXT.French: ß [OUR_NAME], öàðü ìèðíîãî ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Íàäåþñü, ÷òî âû ðàçäåëÿåòå íàøè èäåàëû äðóæáû è òîâàðèùåñòâà.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Zapotec. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Had you been a civilized person, I would be willing to talk to you. Sadly, your level of erudition falls far short of [OUR_CIV_ADJ] standards.
TEXT.French: Áóäü âû öèâèëèçîâàííûì ÷åëîâåêîì, ÿ áû õîòåë ñ âàìè ïîáåñåäîâàòü. Íî ê ñîæàëåíèþ, óðîâåíü âàøåãî îáðàçîâàíèÿ íàìíîãî íèæå ïðèíÿòîãî ó [OUR_CIV_ADJ].
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: We will not withhold the judgment you have brought upon your own heads.
TEXT.French: Ìû, Îáëà÷íûé Íàðîä, íèêîãäà íå cìîæåì ñìèðèòüñÿ ñ òàêèìè ìåðçêèìè æèâîòíûìè, êàê âû.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The [CT_CIV_ADJ] are welcome visitors to the glorious cities of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. On what issues can we assist you with our counsel?
TEXT.French: [CT_CIV_ADJ] - âñåãäà æåëàííûå ãîñòè â ñëàâíûõ ãîðîäàõ [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Â êàêèõ âîïðîñàõ ìû ìîæåì âàì ïîìî÷ü ñîâåòîì?
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Häuptling Cocijoeza aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: As a sophisticated man, I see it as my duty to educate even the basest of creatures, so consider yourself lucky. Which of your many follies shall we discuss?
TEXT.French: ß îáðàçîâàííûé ÷åëîâåê, è ìîé äîëã ïðîñâåùàòü è íàñòàâëÿòü äàæå ñàìûõ íèçøèõ ñóùåñòâ, â ýòîì âàì ïîâåçëî. Èòàê, êàêàÿ ãëóïàÿ ìûñëü ïðèâåëà âàñ â ìîé äîì?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Volkes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: Íàøè ãîðîäà ïåðåæèâàþò òÿæåëûå âðåìåíà. Ìîæåò ëè [CT_EMPIRE] íàì ïîìî÷ü?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøåë ñ ìèðîì ïðîñèòü î ïîìîùè. ×òî ñêàæåòå?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could crush the [CT_EMPIRE] at will. Give me what I demand.
TEXT.French: Îäíîãî ìîåãî æåëàíèÿ äîñòàòî÷íî, ÷òîáû óíè÷òîæèòü íàðîä [CT_EMPIRE]. Äàéòå ìíå òî, ÷òî ÿ òðåáóþ.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Guarani
TEXT.French: Ãóàðàíè
TEXT.German: Guarani

TEXT.English: Guarani
TEXT.German: Guarani

TEXT.English: [TAB]Europeans first made contact with the Guarani in 1537, when the Spanish founded the city of Asuncion, later the capital of Paraguay. The first governor initiated the policy of intermarriage between Europeans and the indigenous women, and the enslavement of the native tribes who received no protection until the arrival of the Jesuits in 1585. Further Jesuits soon followed, resulting in a Jesuit college being founded at Asuncion. As a consequence of Jesuit protests against the enslavement of the Guarani and other indigenous people, in 1608, King Philip III of Spain gave authority to the Jesuits to convert and colonize the tribes of Guayra.[PARAGRAPH:1] The first Guayra mission, Loreto, was established in 1610, and twelve more missions quickly followed, containing some 40,000 Guarani's who fled to the missions to escape enslavement. However, slave raiders saw the missions as little more than places to capture large quantities of slaves. In 1629 an army of Paulistas (Portuguese from Sao Paulo) attacked several missions, and within two years all but a few of the missions had been destroyed with 60,000 Guarani sent to Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro to be sold into slavery. By 1638, despite continued resistance, all twelve of the Jesuit missions beyond the Uruguay were abandoned, prompting Pope Urban VIII to forbid the enslavement of the missionaries, and King Philip IV of Spain to permit the Guarani to bear arms. The Paulista's attacked the missions again in 1641 and 1651, where they encountered fierce opposition from armed Guarani forces often led by Jesuits.[PARAGRAPH:1] In 1750, the Treaty of Madrid, between Spain and Portugal, transferred the territory occupied by the seven missions on the Uruguay from Spain to Portugal. The Guarani's were ordered to be removed, but refused. Seven years of guerilla warfare followed, known as the Guarani War, that left thousands of Guarani dead or enslaved, and a joint Spanish-Portuguese force occupying all seven missions. The Treaty of El Pardo, signed in 1761, reversed the terms of the Treaty of Madrid and restored the disputed mission territory back to Spanish jurisdiction. However, the Jesuits had little time to celebrate and in 1767, they were expelled from Spanish dominions by royal edict, submitting without resistance.[PARAGRAPH:1] The Guarani people and culture continue to exist. The majority of the forest tribes on the borders of present day Paraguay are Guarani, many being the descendants of mission exiles. In Paraguay, Guarani heritage is dominant in the population and the Guarani language continues to be spoken in most provinces.

Ïåðâûé ãóáåðíàòîð íà÷àë ïîëèòèêó áðàêîâ ìåæäó åâðîïåéöàìè è àáîðèãåíêàìè è ïîðàáîùåíèÿ êîðåííûõ ïëåìåí, êîòîðûå íå ïîëó÷àëè íèêàêîé çàùèòû äî ïðèáûòèÿ èåçóèòîâ â 1585 ã. Çà íèìè ïîñëåäîâàëè íîâûå èåçóèòû, è ñêîðî â Àñóíñüîíå áûë îñíîâàí èåçóèòñêèé êîëëåäæ. Âñëåäñòâèå èåçóèòñêèõ ïðîòåñòîâ ïðîòèâ ïîðàáîùåíèÿ ãóàðàíè è äðóãèõ àáîðèãåíîâ â 1608 ã. èñïàíñêèé êîðîëü Ôèëèïï III äàë èåçóèòàì ðàçðåøåíèå íà êîëîíèçàöèþ êîðåííûõ ïëåìåí Ãóàéðû è îáðàùåíèå èõ â õðèñòèàíñòâî.[PARAGRAPH:1] The first Guayra mission, Loreto, was established in 1610, and twelve more missions quickly followed, containing some 40,000 Guarani's who fled to the missions to escape enslavement. However, slave raiders saw the missions as little more than places to capture large quantities of slaves. In 1629 an army of Paulistas (Portuguese from Sao Paulo) attacked several missions, and within two years all but a few of the missions had been destroyed with 60,000 Guarani sent to Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro to be sold into slavery. By 1638, despite continued resistance, all twelve of the Jesuit missions beyond the Uruguay were abandoned, prompting Pope Urban VIII to forbid the enslavement of the missionaries, and King Philip IV of Spain to permit the Guarani to bear arms. The Paulista's attacked the missions again in 1641 and 1651, where they encountered fierce opposition from armed Guarani forces often led by Jesuits.[PARAGRAPH:1] In 1750, the Treaty of Madrid, between Spain and Portugal, transferred the territory occupied by the seven missions on the Uruguay from Spain to Portugal. The Guarani's were ordered to be removed, but refused. Seven years of guerilla warfare followed, known as the Guarani War, that left thousands of Guarani dead or enslaved, and a joint Spanish-Portuguese force occupying all seven missions. The Treaty of El Pardo, signed in 1761, reversed the terms of the Treaty of Madrid and restored the disputed mission territory back to Spanish jurisdiction. However, the Jesuits had little time to celebrate and in 1767, they were expelled from Spanish dominions by royal edict, submitting without resistance.[PARAGRAPH:1] The Guarani people and culture continue to exist. The majority of the forest tribes on the borders of present day Paraguay are Guarani, many being the descendants of mission exiles. In Paraguay, Guarani heritage is dominant in the population and the Guarani language continues to be spoken in most provinces.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der erste Kontakt zwischen Euroäern und Guarani erfolgte 1537 als Spanier die Stadt Asuncion gründeten, die später die Hauptstadt von Paraguay wurde. Der erste Gouverneur führte die Politik der interkulturellen Heirat zwischen Europäern und Ureinwohnerfrauen ein und sorgte für die Versklavung der Ureinwohnerstämme, die keinerlei Fürsprecher hatten, bis 1585 die Jesuiten eintrafen. Als Konsequenz auf die Proteste der Jesuiten gegen die Versklavung der Guarani und anderer Stämme, gab 1608 König Philipp III von Spanien den Jesuiten die Authorität die Stämme von Guayra zu konvertieren und zu kolonisieren.[PARAGRAPH:1] 1610 wurde die erste Mission in Guayra errichtet, Loreto. Es folgten 12 weitere Missionen, die bald über 40.000 Guarani umfassten, die dorthin vor der Versklavung flüchteten. Jedoch sahen die Sklavenfänger in den Missionen wenig mehr als geeignete Orte um grosse Mengen an Sklaven zu finden und zu fangen. 1629 griff eine grosse Armee Portugiesen aus Sao Paulo mehrere Missionen an und in weniger als zwei Jahren waren fast alle zerstört und über 60.000 Guarani nach Rio de Janeiro und Sao Paulo in die Sklaverei verkauft. Trozt stetigem Widerstand waren um 1638 alle zwölf Misisonen, was dazu führte, dass der Papst die Versklavung von Missionaren verbot und König Philipp es den Guarani erlaubte Waffen zu tragen. Die Portugiesen griffen 1641 und 1651 die Missionen erneut an, trafen jedoch auf starken Widerstand durch bewaffnete Guarani, die oft von Jesuiten angeführt wurden.[PARAGRAPH:1] 1750 übertrug der Vertrag von Madrid das Territorium von Uruguay von Spanien and Portugal. Den Guarani wurde befohlen das Gebiet zu verlassen, doch sie weigerten sich. Sieben jahre Guerilliakrieg folgten, die heutzutage als Guarani-Krieg bekannst sind, tausende tote und versklavte Guarani zur Folge hatten und die Spanier und Portugiesen dazu brachte mit einer gemeinsamen Streitmacht das Gebiet der Missionen zu besetzen. Der Vertag von El Pardo von 1761 kehrte den Vertrag von Madrid wieder um und unterwarf das Territorium der Missionen wieder spanischer Rechtssprechung. Dennoch hatten die Jesuiten wenig Zeit zum feiern, denn 1767 wurden sie durch königliches Edikt aller Spanischer Gebiete verwiesen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Das Volk der Guarani und ihre Kultur existieren noch heute. Die Mehrheit der Waldstämme an der Grenze des heutigen Paraguay sind Guarani und Nachkommen der Vertriebenen der Missionen. In einigen Provinzen Paraguays wird noch heute Guarani gesprochen.

The first governor initiated the policy of intermarriage between Europeans and the indigenous women, and the enslavement of the native tribes who received no protection until the arrival of the Jesuits in 1585. Further Jesuits soon followed, resulting in a Jesuit college being founded at Asuncion. As a consequence of Jesuit protests against the enslavement of the Guarani and other indigenous people, in 1608, King Philip III of Spain gave authority to the Jesuits to convert and colonize the tribes of Guayra.[PARAGRAPH:1] The first Guayra mission, Loreto, was established in 1610, and twelve more missions quickly followed, containing some 40,000 Guarani's who fled to the missions to escape enslavement. However, slave raiders saw the missions as little more than places to capture large quantities of slaves. In 1629 an army of Paulistas (Portuguese from Sao Paulo) attacked several missions, and within two years all but a few of the missions had been destroyed with 60,000 Guarani sent to Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro to be sold into slavery. By 1638, despite continued resistance, all twelve of the Jesuit missions beyond the Uruguay were abandoned, prompting Pope Urban VIII to forbid the enslavement of the missionaries, and King Philip IV of Spain to permit the Guarani to bear arms. The Paulista's attacked the missions again in 1641 and 1651, where they encountered fierce opposition from armed Guarani forces often led by Jesuits.[PARAGRAPH:1] In 1750, the Treaty of Madrid, between Spain and Portugal, transferred the territory occupied by the seven missions on the Uruguay from Spain to Portugal. The Guarani's were ordered to be removed, but refused. Seven years of guerilla warfare followed, known as the Guarani War, that left thousands of Guarani dead or enslaved, and a joint Spanish-Portuguese force occupying all seven missions. The Treaty of El Pardo, signed in 1761, reversed the terms of the Treaty of Madrid and restored the disputed mission territory back to Spanish jurisdiction. However, the Jesuits had little time to celebrate and in 1767, they were expelled from Spanish dominions by royal edict, submitting without resistance.[PARAGRAPH:1] The Guarani people and culture continue to exist. The majority of the forest tribes on the borders of present day Paraguay are Guarani, many being the descendants of mission exiles. In Paraguay, Guarani heritage is dominant in the population and the Guarani language continues to be spoken in most provinces.

TEXT.English: Sepe Tiaraju

[H1]Sepé Tiaraju[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Guarani[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c.? - 1756[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Sepe Tiaraju was a Guarani leader born in the Jesuit reduction mission of Sao Luiz Gonzaga. [PARAGRAPH:1] He led the fight against the Portuguese and Spanish in the Guarani War. On February 7, 1756, Tiaraju was killed in the municipality of Sao Gabriel, just three days before a combined force of 3,000 Spanish and Portuguese soldiers massacred over 1,500 Guarani, effectively ending the Guarani war and driving the Guarani's out of the missions and back into the forests.

TEXT.English: Welcome, many-clothes wearing stranger. I, [OUR_NAME], represent the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] tribes. Let us have dinner together with all of our families, our friends, their families, their friends, and all people that were somehow still missed out!
TEXT.French: Ïðèâåòñòâóþ ñòðàííèêà, îäåòîãî âî ìíîãèå îäåæäû. ß, [OUR_NAME], âîæäü ïëåìåí [OUR_CIV_ADJ], ïðèãëàøàþ ñòðàííèêà ïðèñîåäèíèòüñÿ ê íàøåìó îáåäó âìåñòå ñ ðîäíûìè, äðóçüÿìè, ðîäíûìè äðóçåé è âñåìè ëþäüìè, êîòîðûõ õîòåëîñü áû ïðèãëàñèòü!
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Guarani. Begegnet uns mit Achtung, und wir werden auch Euch achten. Tut es nicht und ihr werdet es bereuen. Ich habe gesprochen.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Seek out the sacred spirits if you desire a conversation.
TEXT.French: Âû ïðèøëè ÷òîáû ãîâîðèòü, íî âû èç òåõ çåìåëü, êîòîðûì íå ïîêðîâèòåëüñòâóþò äîáðûå äóõè. Óõîäèòå.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: When the last of your people falls, and his blood is washed out to the sea by the great rivers, then there will be peace.
TEXT.French: Êîãäà áóäåò óáèò ïîñëåäíèé ÷åëîâåê âàøåãî ïëåìåíè, è åãî êðîâü ñòå÷åò ïî Âåëèêîé Ðåêå â âîäû ìîðÿ, òîãäà ìû áóäåì ãîâîðèòü.
TEXT.German: Nein, Bleichgesicht. Wir werden den Kriegspfad nicht verlassen. Erst wenn Euer Skalp in meinem Wigwam hängt, werde ich meine Männer heim zu ihren Kindern und Weibern holen.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the lands of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ], friend. Let the gods of the river grant us wisdom in our conversation.
TEXT.French: Äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü â çåìëè [OUR_CIV_ADJ], äðóã. Ïóñòü äóõ Âåëèêîé Ðåêè äàðóåò íàì ìóäðîñòü, è áóäåò ñâèäåòåëåì íàøåãî ðàçãîâîðà.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Lasst uns beraten, wie wir unsere Feinde vernichten.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: There you are again. Just when I was having a nice evening. Please inform us how we can make you go away again.
TEXT.French: Îïÿòü òû?.. Òû èñïîðòèë ìíå âå÷åð! Ñêàæè ìíå, ÷òî óõîäèøü, è ÿ îáðàäóþñü.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Volkes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: Ìîå ïëåìÿ íóæäàåòñÿ â ïîìîùè, áóäóò ëè äîáðû ê íàì ëþäè ïëåìåíè [CT_EMPIRE]?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Ñî ñìèðåíèåì ÿ ïðèøåë ïðîñèòü âàñ. Ìîæåòå ëè âû ïîìî÷ü?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I hold the fate of the [CT_EMPIRE] in my hand. Give me what I demand.
TEXT.French: ß äåðæó â ñâîèõ ðóêàõ æèçíü è ñìåðòü ïëåìåíè [CT_EMPIRE]. Ïðèíåñèòå ìíå òî, ÷òî ÿ òðåáóþ.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: From the 8th-11th centuries the Danes, were known as the Vikings. Widely renowned as fierce warriors, Viking parties raided and conquered parts of France and the British Isles, as well as establishing trades routes that extended from Greenland to Constantinople via Russian rivers. Excellent shipbuilders and navigators the Viking were the first Europeans to discover and settle Iceland, the Faroe Islands, Greenland, Vineland and Newfoundland. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]With the reign of Harald Blatand, the Danes accepted Christianity in 965 AD, and were forged into one kingdom. By the 13th century, civil wars and ineffective leadership had weakened Denmark, with much of the country pawned off to the nobility. It was not until the late 14th century that Denmark under the rule of Margaret I, began to recover as the three kingdoms of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden became linked in 1397, in what became known as the Kalmar Union. Yet growing tensions between the Sweden and Denmark, swiftly reduced the union to a mere legal concept. Several wars between the two nations followed and Sweden eventually left the Kalmar Union forcing its collapse in 1521. Denmark still retained political control over Norway, and the two kingdoms known as Denmark-Norway, continued to be joined under a single monarch, although Norway maintained some degree of autonomy. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]For much of the 17th century, Denmark found itself embroiled in a series of wars against Sweden. The Thirty Years War, 1618-48, and the Second Northern War, 1655-60, saw Denmark cede several large Norwegian territories and the whole of eastern Denmark to its bitter rival. With the Third Northern War, 1700-21, Sweden was weakened to the point where it was no longer a threat, but Denmark's allies opposed Danish claims to former territorial possessions, fearing the waterway from the Baltic to the Atlantic being controlled by a single nation again. The rest of the 18th century saw Denmark at peace, as its economy continued to expand and Danish merchant ships traded across Europe, to India and the America's, traveling to the Danish colonies of Greenland in the North Atlantic, Tranquebar in India, and the islands of St. Thomas, St. John, and St. Croix in the Caribbean. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]With the onset of the Napoleonic Wars, the Danish navy was defeated by the British Navy in 1801, and forced to surrender their entire fleet to the British in 1807. By 1813 Denmark had been bankrupted by the war and sued for peace, witnessing in the following year, the dissolution of its union with Norway, which was granted to Sweden at the Treaty of Kiel. Yet, despite its losses the period was also one of a "golden age", for Danish intellectual history, Literature, painting, sculpture and philosophy which all experienced a vibrant rebirth.
