Â ðåçóëüòàòå Òðèäöàòèëåòíåé âîéíû 1618-48 ãîäîâ è Âòîðîé Ñåâåðíîé âîéíû 1655-60 ãîäîâ Äàíèÿ óñòóïèëà íåñêîëüêî êðóïíûõ íîðâåæñêèõ òåððèòîðèé è âñþ âîñòî÷íóþ Äàíèþ ñâîåìó çëåéøåìó ñîïåðíèêó. Â ðåçóëüòàòå Òðåòüåé Ñåâåðíîé âîéíû 1700-21 ãîäîâ Øâåöèÿ áûëà îñëàáëåíà íàñòîëüêî, ÷òî ïåðåñòàëà ïðåäñòàâëÿòü óãðîçó, íî ñîþçíèêè Äàíèè âûñòóïèëè ïðîòèâ äàòñêèõ ïðåòåíçèé íà áûâøèå òåððèòîðèàëüíûå âëàäåíèÿ, îïàñàÿñü, ÷òî âîäíûé ïóòü èç Áàëòèêè â Àòëàíòèêó ñíîâà áóäåò êîíòðîëèðîâàòüñÿ îäíèì ãîñóäàðñòâîì. Â îñòàâøóþñÿ ÷àñòü XVIII âåêà Äàíèÿ æèëà â ìèðå, åå ýêîíîìèêà ïðîäîëæàëà ðàçâèâàòüñÿ, à äàòñêèå òîðãîâûå ñóäà òîðãîâàëè ïî âñåé Åâðîïå, â Èíäèè è Àìåðèêå, çàõîäÿ â äàòñêèå êîëîíèè Ãðåíëàíäèþ â Ñåâåðíîé Àòëàíòèêå, Òðàíêåáàð â Èíäèè è îñòðîâà Ñåíò-Òîìàñ, Ñåíò-Äæîí è Ñåíò-Êðóà â Êàðèáñêîì áàññåéíå. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ñ íà÷àëîì íàïîëåîíîâñêèõ âîéí äàòñêèé ôëîò ïîòåðïåë ïîðàæåíèå îò áðèòàíñêîãî â 1801 ãîäó è áûë âûíóæäåí ñäàòü âåñü ñâîé ôëîò àíãëè÷àíàì â 1807 ãîäó. Ê 1813 ãîäó Äàíèÿ áûëà ðàçîðåíà âîéíîé è çàïðîñèëà ìèðà, à â ñëåäóþùåì ãîäó ðàñòîðãëà ñîþç ñ Íîðâåãèåé, êîòîðûé áûë ïåðåäàí Øâåöèè ïî Êèëüñêîìó äîãîâîðó. Îäíàêî, íåñìîòðÿ íà ïîòåðè, ýòîò ïåðèîä ñòàë "çîëîòûì âåêîì" äëÿ äàòñêîé èíòåëëåêòóàëüíîé èñòîðèè, ëèòåðàòóðû, æèâîïèñè, ñêóëüïòóðû è ôèëîñîôèè, êîòîðûå ïåðåæèëè áóðíîå âîçðîæäåíèå.
TEXT.German: Vom 8ten bis zum 11ten Jahrhunder ware die Dänen als Wikinger bekannt. Weithing als zähe Krieger berühmt, überfielen und erobertend die Wikinger Teile von Frankreich und der Britischen Inseln. Sie gründeten des weiteren Handelsrouten, die von Grönland über russische Flüsse bis nach Konstantinopel reichten. Als herausragende Schiffsbauer und Navigatoren wraen sie die ersten Europäer, die Island entdeckten und besiedelten. Ausserdem noch die Faroe Inseln, Grönland, Vineland und Neufundland. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Während der Herrschaft von Harald Blatland akzeptierten sie 965 nach Christus das Christentum und wurden zu einem Königreich. Bis zum 13ten Jahrhundert jedoch, war Dänemark durch Bürgerkriege udn schlechte Führung stark geschwächt. Erst im späten 14ten Jahrhundert unter der Führung von Margaret I, begannen sich die Dänemark wieder zu erholen, als sich die drei Königreiche Dänemark, Scheweden und Norwegen verbanden und 1397 die Kalmar Union entstand. Aufgrund wachsender Spannungen zwischen Dänemark und Schweden, war die Kalmar Union aber bald nur noch ein rechtliches Konzept. Mehrere Kriege zwischen den beiden Nationen folgten und Schwede trat schliesslich der Kalmar Union aus, was 1521 zu deren Kollaps führte. Dänemark behielt jedoch die politische Kontrolle über Norwegen und die zwei Königreiche, als Dänemark-Norwegen bekannt, blieben unter einem König vereint, obwphl Norwegen zu einem gewissen Masse noch autonom war. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]über weite Teile des 17ten Jahrhunderst wurde Dänemark in Kriege mit Schweden verstrickt. Im 30jährigen Krieg, 1618 bis 48 und im Zweite Nord Krieg 1655 bis 1660, musste Dänemark mit ansehen, wie grosse Teile von Norwegen und der östlichen Küste von Dänemark an den Rivalen fielen. Nach dem Dritten Nord Krieg 1700 bis 1721 war Schweden so geschwächt, dass es keien grosse Gefahr mehr darstellte, aber die dänischen Verbündeten widersetzten sich deren Ansprüche auf frühere territioriale Ansprüche um zu verhindern, dass die Seewege vom Baltikum bis zum Atlantik unter die Kontrolle einer einzigen Nation fielen. Den Rest des 18ten Jahrhunderts verbrachte Dänemark in Frieden, wodurch die Wirtschaft wuchs und viele dänische Handelsschiffe die Ozeane zwischen Europa, Indien und Amerika bereisten, um die dänsichen Kolonien Grönland im Nordatlantik, Tranquebar in Indien und die Inseln St. Thomas, St. John und St. Croix in the Caribbean zu besuchen. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB] Zu Beginn des Napoleonischen Krieges wurde die Danische Flotte fon der Britischen Navy im Jahre 1801 besiegt und musste sich 1807 vollständig ergeben. Um 1813 hatte der Krieg Dänemark ruiniert. Dänemark musste sich ergeben und in den folgenden Jahren den Zerfall der Union mit Norwegen mit ansehen welches im Abkommen von Kiel an Schweden überging.
TEXT.Italian: From the 8th-11th centuries the Danes, were known as the Vikings. Widely renowned as fierce warriors, Viking parties raided and conquered parts of France and the British Isles, as well as establishing trades routes that extended from Greenland to Constantinople via Russian rivers. Excellent shipbuilders and navigators the Viking were the first Europeans to discover and settle Iceland, the Faroe Islands, Greenland, Vineland and Newfoundland. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]With the reign of Harald Blatand, the Danes accepted Christianity in 965 AD, and were forged into one kingdom. By the 13th century, civil wars and ineffective leadership had weakened Denmark, with much of the country pawned off to the nobility. It was not until the late 14th century that Denmark under the rule of Margaret I, began to recover as the three kingdoms of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden became linked in 1397, in what became known as the Kalmar Union. Yet growing tensions between the Sweden and Denmark, swiftly reduced the union to a mere legal concept. Several wars between the two nations followed and Sweden eventually left the Kalmar Union forcing its collapse in 1521. Denmark still retained political control over Norway, and the two kingdoms known as Denmark-Norway, continued to be joined under a single monarch, although Norway maintained some degree of autonomy. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]For much of the 17th century, Denmark found itself embroiled in a series of wars against Sweden. The Thirty Years War, 1618-48, and the Second Northern War, 1655-60, saw Denmark cede several large Norwegian territories and the whole of eastern Denmark to its bitter rival. With the Third Northern War, 1700-21, Sweden was weakened to the point where it was no longer a threat, but Denmark's allies opposed Danish claims to former territorial possessions, fearing the waterway from the Baltic to the Atlantic being controlled by a single nation again. The rest of the 18th century saw Denmark at peace, as its economy continued to expand and Danish merchant ships traded across Europe, to India and the America's, traveling to the Danish colonies of Greenland in the North Atlantic, Tranquebar in India, and the islands of St. Thomas, St. John, and St. Croix in the Caribbean. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]With the onset of the Napoleonic Wars, the Danish navy was defeated by the British Navy in 1801, and forced to surrender their entire fleet to the British in 1807. By 1813 Denmark had been bankrupted by the war and sued for peace, witnessing in the following year, the dissolution of its union with Norway, which was granted to Sweden at the Treaty of Kiel. Yet, despite its losses the period was also one of a "golden age", for Danish intellectual history, Literature, painting, sculpture and philosophy which all experienced a vibrant rebirth.
TEXT.Spanish: From the 8th-11th centuries the Danes, were known as the Vikings. Widely renowned as fierce warriors, Viking parties raided and conquered parts of France and the British Isles, as well as establishing trades routes that extended from Greenland to Constantinople via Russian rivers. Excellent shipbuilders and navigators the Viking were the first Europeans to discover and settle Iceland, the Faroe Islands, Greenland, Vineland and Newfoundland. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]With the reign of Harald Blatand, the Danes accepted Christianity in 965 AD, and were forged into one kingdom. By the 13th century, civil wars and ineffective leadership had weakened Denmark, with much of the country pawned off to the nobility. It was not until the late 14th century that Denmark under the rule of Margaret I, began to recover as the three kingdoms of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden became linked in 1397, in what became known as the Kalmar Union. Yet growing tensions between the Sweden and Denmark, swiftly reduced the union to a mere legal concept. Several wars between the two nations followed and Sweden eventually left the Kalmar Union forcing its collapse in 1521. Denmark still retained political control over Norway, and the two kingdoms known as Denmark-Norway, continued to be joined under a single monarch, although Norway maintained some degree of autonomy. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]For much of the 17th century, Denmark found itself embroiled in a series of wars against Sweden. The Thirty Years War, 1618-48, and the Second Northern War, 1655-60, saw Denmark cede several large Norwegian territories and the whole of eastern Denmark to its bitter rival. With the Third Northern War, 1700-21, Sweden was weakened to the point where it was no longer a threat, but Denmark's allies opposed Danish claims to former territorial possessions, fearing the waterway from the Baltic to the Atlantic being controlled by a single nation again. The rest of the 18th century saw Denmark at peace, as its economy continued to expand and Danish merchant ships traded across Europe, to India and the America's, traveling to the Danish colonies of Greenland in the North Atlantic, Tranquebar in India, and the islands of St. Thomas, St. John, and St. Croix in the Caribbean. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]With the onset of the Napoleonic Wars, the Danish navy was defeated by the British Navy in 1801, and forced to surrender their entire fleet to the British in 1807. By 1813 Denmark had been bankrupted by the war and sued for peace, witnessing in the following year, the dissolution of its union with Norway, which was granted to Sweden at the Treaty of Kiel. Yet, despite its losses the period was also one of a "golden age", for Danish intellectual history, Literature, painting, sculpture and philosophy which all experienced a vibrant rebirth.

TEXT.English: [H1]Jens Munk[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Explorer and Navigator[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1579 - 1628 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Jens Munk was a Norwegian navigator and explorer, born in Arendal in the south of Norway, where his father, the notorious nobleman Erik Munk, was governor.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1591, at the age of twelve, Munk went to Oporto in Portugal where he worked for the shipping magnat Duart Duez. The following year he sailed with a Dutch convoy to Bahia in Brazil. Off the Brazilian coast the convoy was attacked by French pirates. Munk was among the seven survivors. Munk lived in Bahia (today's Salvador) for six years, where he was in the service of Duart Duez' brother, Miguel. Under dramatic circumstances Munk returned to Europe and Copenhagen in 1599, where the Danish magnat and Lord Chancellor Henrik Ramel hired him as ship clerk.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]After two unsuccessful attempts to find the Northeast passage in 1609 and 1610 he caught the attention of King Christian IV. In the Swedish - Danish war (1611-13), the so called Kalmar war, Jens Munk together with the noble man Jorgen Daa lead a successful attack on the Swedish fortress Alvsborg in 1612, near today's Gothenburg. In 1614 he lead a search for the notoriuos Spanish privateer Jan Mendoza, who he fought in a battle at Kanin Nos near the entrance of the White Sea. In the spring of 1617 he recruited eighteen Basque whalemen for the first Danish whaling expedition to Spitsbergen. In 1618 king Christian IV appointed him as commander of the first Danish expedition to East India with five vessels and almost 1000 men, but only one month before the departure of the expedition in November Munk was relegated and replaced by the much younger nobleman Ove Gjedde. The reason for the relegation is unclear, but was most likely caused by a conflict Munk had with the Lord Chancellor, Christian Friis. A few months earlier Munk also had lost a vast amount of money as a result of an unsuccessful whaling expedition and which caused loss of social prestige. As an attempt to regain his social position he started the planning of a much more spectacular expedition in 1619, the search for the Northwest Passage.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]On 9 May 1619, under the auspices of King Christian IV, Munk set out with 65 men and His Royal Majesty's two ships, the Unicorn and Lamprey, to discover the Northwest Passage to the Indies and China. He penetrated Davis Strait as far north as 69°, found Frobisher Bay, and then spent almost a month fighting his way through Hudson Strait. In September 1619 he found the entrance to Hudson Bay and spent the winter near the mouth of the Churchill River. Cold, famine, and scurvy destroyed so many of his men that only two persons besides himself survived. With these men, he sailed for home with the "Lamprey" on 16 July 1620, reaching Bergen, Norway, on 20 September, 1620.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Munk had planned on a new Northwest Passage journey to take possession of "Nova Dania" (New Denmark) for the Danish crown, but his health was too weak to go on with it. In the subsequent years Munk served as sea captain in the royal fleet. During the Thirty years war Munk lead a blockade on the river Weser in 1626 and 1627. Munk took part in the attacks on Wallensteins troops at Fehmarn and in the Kieler fjord in March and April 1628. Munk died on 26 June the same year probably as a result of being wounded in the battles in the Kieler fjord a couple of months earlier. According to the French scientist Isaac de la Peyrere, who served as a legate at the French embassy in Copenhagen, Munk died as a result of a dispute with king Christian IV, where the king fouriously had attacked Munk with his stick and thus caused his death.
TEXT.French: [H1]Йенс Мунк[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Исследователь и мореплаватель[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Жил: [\BOLD]1579 - 1628[PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]История:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Йенс Мунк - норвежский мореплаватель и исследователь, родился в Арендале на юге Норвегии, где его отец, печально известный дворянин Эрик Мунк, был губернатором.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]В 1591 году, в возрасте двенадцати лет, Мунк отправился в Опорто в Португалии, где работал на судоходного магната Дуарта Дуэса. В следующем году он отправился с голландским конвоем в Баию (Бразилия). У бразильского побережья конвой был атакован французскими пиратами. Мунк был в числе семи выживших. В течение шести лет Мунк жил в Баие (современный Салвадор), где находился на службе у брата Дуарта Дуэса, Мигеля. При драматических обстоятельствах Мунк вернулся в Европу, в Копенгаген в 1599 году, где датский магнат и лорд-канцлер Хенрик Рамель нанял его в качестве корабельного клерка.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]После двух неудачных попыток найти Северо-восточный проход в 1609 и 1610 годах он привлек внимание короля Кристиана IV. Во время шведско-датской войны (1611-13), так называемой Кальмарской войны, Йенс Мунк вместе со знатным человеком Йоргеном Даа в 1612 году возглавил успешное нападение на шведскую крепость Альвсборг, расположенную недалеко от современного Гетеборга. В 1614 году он возглавил поиски небезызвестного испанского капера Яна Мендосы, с которым сразился в битве при Канин-Носе у входа в Белое море. Весной 1617 года он набрал восемнадцать басков-китобоев для первой датской китобойной экспедиции на Шпицберген. В 1618 году король Кристиан IV назначил его командиром первой датской экспедиции в Восточную Индию с пятью судами и почти 1000 человек, но всего за месяц до отплытия экспедиции в ноябре Мунк был понижен в должности и заменен гораздо более молодым дворянином Ове Гьедде. Причина отставки неясна, но, скорее всего, она была вызвана конфликтом Мунка с лорд-канцлером Кристианом Фриисом. Несколькими месяцами ранее Мунк также потерял огромную сумму денег в результате неудачной китобойной экспедиции, что привело к потере социального престижа. Пытаясь восстановить свое положение в обществе, он начал планировать гораздо более впечатляющую экспедицию в 1619 году - поиск Северо-Западного прохода.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]9 мая 1619 года под покровительством короля Кристиана IV Мунк отправился с 65 людьми и двумя кораблями Его Королевского Величества, "Единорогом" и "Миногой", чтобы открыть Северо-Западный проход в Индию и Китай. Он проник в пролив Дэвиса на север до 69°, нашел залив Фробишера, а затем почти месяц пробивался через Гудзонов пролив. В сентябре 1619 года он нашел вход в Гудзонов залив и провел зиму вблизи устья реки Черчилль. Холод, голод и цинга уничтожили так много его людей, что в живых осталось только два человека, кроме него самого. С этими людьми он отплыл домой на корабле "Лампри" 16 июля 1620 года и достиг Бергена, Норвегия, 20 сентября 1620 года.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Мунк планировал совершить новое путешествие Северо-Западным проходом, чтобы завладеть Новой Данией для датской короны, но его здоровье было слишком слабым, чтобы продолжать его. В последующие годы Мунк служил морским капитаном в королевском флоте. Во время Тридцатилетней войны Мунк руководил блокадой на реке Везер в 1626 и 1627 годах. Мунк принимал участие в нападениях на войска Валленштейна у Фехмарна и в Килер-фьорде в марте и апреле 1628 года. Мунк умер 26 июня того же года, вероятно, в результате ранения, полученного в сражениях в Килерском фьорде несколькими месяцами ранее. По мнению французского ученого Исаака де ла Пейрера, служившего легатом во французском посольстве в Копенгагене, Мунк умер в результате спора с королем Кристианом IV, когда тот в ярости набросился на Мунка со своей палкой и тем самым вызвал его смерть.
TEXT.German: [H1]Jens Munk[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Entdecker Navigator[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte: [\BOLD] 1579 - 1628 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Jens Munk war ein norwegischer Navigatur und Entdecker. Geboren in Arendal im Süden Norwegens, wo sein Vater, der Edelmann Erik Munk, Gouverneur war. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Im Jahre 1591, im Alter von zwölf, ging Munk nach Oporto in Portugal wo er für den Schiffsmagnaten Duart Duez arbeitete. Die folgenden Jahre segelte er mit einem niederländischen Konvoi nach Bahia in Brasilien. An der brasilianischen Küste wurde der Konvoy von französischen Piraten angegriffen. Munk war einer von nur sieben überlebenden. Munk lebte daraufhin in Bahia (heute Salvador) für sechs Jahre im Dienste von Duart Duezes Bruder. Unter dramatischen Umständen kehrte Munk im Jahre 1599 nach Copenhange zurück und wurden vom Lordkanler Henrik Ramel als Schiffsjunge angeworben.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Nach zwei erfolglosen Versuchen die Nordostpassage zu finden, fand er die Aufmerksamkeit von König Christian IV. Im Schwedisch-Dänischen Krieg (1611-1613), dem sogenannten Kalmar Krieg, führte Jens Munk 1612 zusammen mit dem Edelmann Jorgen Daa erfolgreich einen Angriff auf die schwedische Festung Alvsborg, nahe Göteburg. 1614 führte er die Suche nach dem berüchtigten Spanischen Freibeuter Jan Mendoza, den er letzlich in der White Sea in der Schlacht von Kanis Nos stellte. Im Frühjahr 1617 rekrutierte er achtzehn baskische Walfänger für die erste dänische Walfangexpedition nach Spitzbergen. 1618 ernannten König Christian IV ihn als Kommandanten der ersten dänischen Expedition nach Ostindien, die 5 Schiffen und fast 1000 Mann umfasste. Jedoch nur einen Monat vor der Abfahrt der Expedition wurde Munk durch einen viel jüngeren Edelmann ersetzt, Ove Gjedde. Der Grund hierfür war vermutlich ein Konflikt zwischen Munk und dem Lordkanzler Christian Friis. Einige Monate davor hatte Munk auch viel Geld und Prestige in einem erfolglosen Walfangunternehmen verloren. Als Versuch seinen sozialen Stand wiederzuerlangen plante Munk 1619 eine spektakuläre Expedition zur Suche der Nordwestpassage.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Im Mai 1619, mit dem Segen von König Christian IV, setzte Munk mit 65 Männern und zwei Schiffen, Unicorn und Lamprey, segel um die Nordwestpassage nach Indien und China zu entdecken. Im September 1619 fand er die Hudson Bay und verbrachte den Winter an der Mündung des Churchill River. Kälte, Hunger und Krankheiten tötete so viele seiner Männer, das ausser Munk zur noch zwei weitere überlebten. Mit diesen beiden Männern gelang es ihm die Lamprey" zwischen dem 16. Juli 1620 und dem 20. September 1620 zurück nach Bergen in Norwegen zu segeln.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Munk plante eine weitere Nordwestpassagenreise um für die dänsiche Krone Besitz von "Nova Dania" (Neu-Dänemark), jedoch lies seine schwache Gesundheit dies nicht zu. In den folgenden Jahren dient Munk als Kapitän in der königlichen Flotte. Im 30-jährigen Krieg befehligte Munk eine Blockade der Weser zwischen 1626 und 1627 und war an einem Angriff Wallensteins im Kieler Fjord 1628 beteiligt. Munk starb am 26. Juni des selben Jahres, was vermutlich auf eine Verwundung während der Schlacht im Kielder Fjord, einige Monate zuvor, zurückzuführen ist.

TEXT.English: [H1]Hans Poulsen Egede[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lutheran missionary, Greenland colonizer[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1686 - 1758 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Hans Poulsen Egede was a Norwegian Lutheran missionary, called the Apostle of Greenland. Egede was an evangelist on the northern Norwegian islands of Lofoten when he heard stories about the Viking settlements in Greenland, with which contact had been lost years before. In May 1721, he asked Frederick IV of Denmark for permission to seek the colony and establish a mission there, presuming that it had remained Catholic or lost the Christian faith. Frederick gave consent at least partially to reestablish a colonial claim to the island.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede landed on the west coast of Greenland on July 3. He was sent to seek the old Viking colony on Greenland but he found no survivors. The last communication with that colony had been over 300 years earlier. He did, however, find the Inuit and started a mission among them. He studied the Inuit language and translated Christian texts into it. This required some imagination as, for instance, the Inuit had no bread nor any idea of it. So the words of the Lord's Prayer were translated by Egede as the equivalent of "Give us this day our daily harbor seal".[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede founded Godtheb (now Nuuk), which later became the capital of Greenland. In 1724, he baptised the first children. The new king, Christian VI of Denmark, recalled all Europeans from Greenland in 1730. Egede remained, however, encouraged by his wife Gertrud. Egede's book Det gamle Grønlands nye Perlustration, (The old Greenland's new Perlustration, or an accurate description of those old Nordic Colonies in Greenland) appeared in 1729 and was translated into several languages.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1733, the Herrnhut missionaries of Nicolaus Ludwig Zinzendorf were allowed to establish New Herrnhut, south of Nuuk. In 1734, a smallpox epidemic broke out which spread through the Inuit and claimed Gertrud Egede in 1735. Hans Egede left his son Paul in Greenland and traveled on 9 August 1736 with his daughters and his son Niels to Copenhagen. In 1741, he was named bishop of Greenland. He established a catechism for use in Greenland in 1747.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede became a national saint of Greenland and the town of Egedesminde (literally: memory of Egede) commemorates him. It was established by Niels Egede, Hans' second and surviving son, in 1759 on the Eqalussuit peninsula but moved to the island of Aasiaat in 1763, which had been the site of a pre-Viking Inuit settlement.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Hans Egede gives one of the oldest desciptions of a sea serpent. On 6 July 1734 his ship sailed past the coast of Greenland when suddenly those on board "saw a most terrible creature, resembling nothing they saw before. The monster lifted its head so high that it seemed to be higher than the crow's nest on the mainmast. The head was small and the body short and wrinkled. The unknown creature was using giant fins which propelled it through the water. Later the sailors saw its tail as well. The monster was longer than our whole ship", wrote Egede.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]A hulk named after Hans Egede can be found at the point where Cliffe marshes meet the Thames, adjacent to Cliffe Fort.
TEXT.French: [H1]Õàíñ Ïîóëüñåí Ýãåäå[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ëþòåðàíñêèé ìèññèîíåð, êîëîíèçàòîð Ãðåíëàíäèè[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Æèë: [\BOLD]1686 - 1758 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Èñòîðèÿ:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Õàíñ Ïîóëüñåí Ýãåäå áûë íîðâåæñêèì ëþòåðàíñêèì ìèññèîíåðîì, êîòîðîãî íàçûâàëè àïîñòîëîì Ãðåíëàíäèè. Ýãåäå áûë åâàíãåëèñòîì íà ñåâåðíûõ íîðâåæñêèõ îñòðîâàõ Ëîôîòåí, êîãäà óñëûøàë ðàññêàçû î ïîñåëåíèÿõ âèêèíãîâ â Ãðåíëàíäèè, ñâÿçü ñ êîòîðûìè áûëà ïîòåðÿíà ìíîãî ëåò íàçàä. Â ìàå 1721 ãîäà îí ïîïðîñèë ó Ôðåäåðèêà IV Äàòñêîãî ðàçðåøåíèÿ íàéòè êîëîíèþ è îñíîâàòü òàì ìèññèþ, ïðåäïîëàãàÿ, ÷òî îíà îñòàëàñü êàòîëè÷åñêîé èëè óòðàòèëà õðèñòèàíñêóþ âåðó. Ôðåäåðèê äàë ñîãëàñèå, ïî êðàéíåé ìåðå ÷àñòè÷íî, ÷òîáû âîññòàíîâèòü êîëîíèàëüíûå ïðàâà íà îñòðîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ýãåäå âûñàäèëñÿ íà çàïàäíîì ïîáåðåæüå Ãðåíëàíäèè 3 èþëÿ. Îí áûë ïîñëàí íà ïîèñêè ñòàðîé êîëîíèè âèêèíãîâ íà Ãðåíëàíäèè, íî íå íàøåë íè îäíîãî âûæèâøåãî. Ïîñëåäíÿÿ ñâÿçü ñ ýòîé êîëîíèåé áûëà áîëåå 300 ëåò íàçàä. Îäíàêî îí íàøåë èíóèòîâ è íà÷àë ìèññèþ ñðåäè íèõ. Îí èçó÷èë ÿçûê èíóèòîâ è ïåðåâåë íà íåãî õðèñòèàíñêèå òåêñòû. Ýòî òðåáîâàëî îïðåäåëåííîé ôàíòàçèè, ïîñêîëüêó, íàïðèìåð, ó èíóèòîâ íå áûëî íè õëåáà, íè ïðåäñòàâëåíèÿ î íåì. Ïîýòîìó ñëîâà ìîëèòâû "Îò÷å íàø" Ýãåäå ïåðåâåë òàê: "Äàé íàì â ýòîò äåíü íàøåãî åæåäíåâíîãî ïîðòîâîãî òþëåíÿ".[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ýãåäå îñíîâàë ãîðîä Ãîäòåá (íûíå Íóóê), êîòîðûé âïîñëåäñòâèè ñòàë ñòîëèöåé Ãðåíëàíäèè. Â 1724 ãîäó îí êðåñòèë ïåðâûõ äåòåé. Íîâûé êîðîëü, Êðèñòèàí VI Äàòñêèé, îòîçâàë âñåõ åâðîïåéöåâ èç Ãðåíëàíäèè â 1730 ãîäó. Îäíàêî Ýãåäå îñòàëñÿ, ïîäáàäðèâàåìûé ñâîåé æåíîé Ãåðòðóäîé. Â 1729 ãîäó âûøëà êíèãà Ýãåäå "Det gamle Grønlands nye Perlustration" ("Íîâàÿ ïåðëþñòðàöèÿ ñòàðîé Ãðåíëàíäèè, èëè òî÷íîå îïèñàíèå ñòàðûõ ñåâåðíûõ êîëîíèé â Ãðåíëàíäèè"), êîòîðàÿ áûëà ïåðåâåäåíà íà íåñêîëüêî ÿçûêîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Â 1733 ãîäó ãåðíõóòñêèì ìèññèîíåðàì Íèêîëàóñà Ëþäâèãà Öèíöåíäîðôà áûëî ðàçðåøåíî îñíîâàòü Íîâûé Ãåðíõóò, ê þãó îò Íóóêà. Â 1734 ãîäó âñïûõíóëà ýïèäåìèÿ îñïû, êîòîðàÿ ðàñïðîñòðàíèëàñü ñðåäè èíóèòîâ è óíåñëà æèçíü Ãåðòðóäû Ýãåäå â 1735 ãîäó. Õàíñ Ýãåäå îñòàâèë ñâîåãî ñûíà Ïàóëÿ â Ãðåíëàíäèè è 9 àâãóñòà 1736 ãîäà âìåñòå ñ äî÷åðüìè è ñûíîì Íèëüñîì îòïðàâèëñÿ â Êîïåíãàãåí. Â 1741 ãîäó îí áûë íàçíà÷åí åïèñêîïîì Ãðåíëàíäèè. Â 1747 ãîäó îí ñîçäàë êàòåõèçèñ äëÿ èñïîëüçîâàíèÿ â Ãðåíëàíäèè.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ýãåäå ñòàë íàöèîíàëüíûì ñâÿòûì Ãðåíëàíäèè, è â ÷åñòü íåãî áûë îñíîâàí ãîðîä Ýãåäåñìèíäå (áóêâàëüíî: ïàìÿòü îá Ýãåäå). Îí áûë îñíîâàí Íèëüñîì Ýãåäå, âòîðûì è âûæèâøèì ñûíîì Õàíñà, â 1759 ãîäó íà ïîëóîñòðîâå Ýêàëóññóèò, à â 1763 ãîäó ïåðåíåñåí íà îñòðîâ Ààñèààò, ãäå äî âèêèíãîâ ðàñïîëàãàëîñü ïîñåëåíèå èíóèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Õàíñ Ýãåäå äàë îäíî èç ñàìûõ äðåâíèõ îïèñàíèé ìîðñêîãî çìåÿ. 6 èþëÿ 1734 ãîäà åãî êîðàáëü ïðîïëûâàë ìèìî ïîáåðåæüÿ Ãðåíëàíäèè, êîãäà âíåçàïíî íàõîäèâøèåñÿ íà áîðòó "óâèäåëè óæàñíåéøåå ñóùåñòâî, íå ïîõîæåå íè íà ÷òî, âèäåííîå èìè ïðåæäå. ×óäîâèùå ïîäíÿëî ãîëîâó òàê âûñîêî, ÷òî êàçàëîñü, îíà âûøå âîðîíüåãî ãíåçäà íà ãðîò-ìà÷òå. Ãîëîâà áûëà ìàëåíüêîé, à òåëî - êîðîòêèì è ìîðùèíèñòûì. Íåâåäîìîå ñóùåñòâî îïèðàëîñü íà ãèãàíòñêèå ïëàâíèêè, êîòîðûå äâèãàëè åãî ïî âîäå. Ïîçæå ìîðÿêè óâèäåëè è õâîñò. Ìîíñòð áûë äëèííåå, ÷åì âåñü íàø êîðàáëü", - ïèñàë Ýãåäå.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Êîðàáëü, íàçâàííûé â ÷åñòü Ãàíñà Ýãåäå, ìîæíî íàéòè â ìåñòå, ãäå áîëîòà Êëèôôà âñòðå÷àþòñÿ ñ Òåìçîé, ðÿäîì ñ ôîðòîì Êëèôôà.
TEXT.German: [H1]Hans Poulsen Egede[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lutheranischer Missionar, Gründer der Gröndlandkolonie[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte: [\BOLD] 1686 - 1758 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Hans Poulsen Egede war ein norwegischer lutheranischer Missionar, der auch Apostel von Grönland genannt wird. Egede war ein Evangelist auf der nördlichen norwegische Insel Lofoten, als er Geschichten von Vikingersiedlungen in Grönland hörte, zu denen schon seit Jahrhunderten jeglicher Kontakt verloren war. In Mai 1721, fragte er Frederick IV von Dänemark um Erlaubnis um diese Kolonien zu suchen und dort eine Mission zu errichten. Frederick gab seine Einwilligung um dort koloniale Ansprüche zu erheben.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede landete an der Westküste von Grönland am 3. Juli, fand aber keine überlebenden der Vikingerkolonie. Stattdessen traf er auf Inuit und errichtete seine Mission unter ihnen. Er studierte die Sprache der Inuit und übersetzte christliche Texte in diese. Dies bedurfte viel Vorstellungskraft, da die Inuit beispielsweise kein Brot kannte oder eine Vorstellung davon hatten. So wurden viele Gebete in idiome übersetzt, die die Inuit auch verstanden.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede gründetet Gothab (heutzutage Nuuk), welches später die Hauptstad von Grönland wurde. 1724 taufte er die ersten Kinder. Der neue König, Christian VI von Dänemark, rief 1730 alle Europäer aus Grönland zurück. Egede jedoch blieb. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede wurde zum nationalen Heiligen von Grönland und die Stadt Egedesminde (sprichwörtlich: Erinnerung an Egede) erinnert noch heute an ihn.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Hans Poulsen Egede[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lutheran missionary, Greenland colonizer[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1686 - 1758 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Hans Poulsen Egede was a Norwegian Lutheran missionary, called the Apostle of Greenland. Egede was an evangelist on the northern Norwegian islands of Lofoten when he heard stories about the Viking settlements in Greenland, with which contact had been lost years before. In May 1721, he asked Frederick IV of Denmark for permission to seek the colony and establish a mission there, presuming that it had remained Catholic or lost the Christian faith. Frederick gave consent at least partially to reestablish a colonial claim to the island.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede landed on the west coast of Greenland on July 3. He was sent to seek the old Viking colony on Greenland but he found no survivors. The last communication with that colony had been over 300 years earlier. He did, however, find the Inuit and started a mission among them. He studied the Inuit language and translated Christian texts into it. This required some imagination as, for instance, the Inuit had no bread nor any idea of it. So the words of the Lord's Prayer were translated by Egede as the equivalent of "Give us this day our daily harbor seal".[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede founded Godthåb (now Nuuk), which later became the capital of Greenland. In 1724, he baptised the first children. The new king, Christian VI of Denmark, recalled all Europeans from Greenland in 1730. Egede remained, however, encouraged by his wife Gertrud. Egede's book Det gamle Grønlands nye Perlustration, (The old Greenland's new Perlustration, or an accurate description of those old Nordic Colonies in Greenland) appeared in 1729 and was translated into several languages.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1733, the Herrnhut missionaries of Nicolaus Ludwig Zinzendorf were allowed to establish New Herrnhut, south of Nuuk. In 1734, a smallpox epidemic broke out which spread through the Inuit and claimed Gertrud Egede in 1735. Hans Egede left his son Paul in Greenland and traveled on 9 August 1736 with his daughters and his son Niels to Copenhagen. In 1741, he was named bishop of Greenland. He established a catechism for use in Greenland in 1747.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Egede became a national saint of Greenland and the town of Egedesminde (literally: memory of Egede) commemorates him. It was established by Niels Egede, Hans' second and surviving son, in 1759 on the Eqalussuit peninsula but moved to the island of Aasiaat in 1763, which had been the site of a pre-Viking Inuit settlement.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Hans Egede gives one of the oldest desciptions of a sea serpent. On 6 July 1734 his ship sailed past the coast of Greenland when suddenly those on board "saw a most terrible creature, resembling nothing they saw before. The monster lifted its head so high that it seemed to be higher than the crow's nest on the mainmast. The head was small and the body short and wrinkled. The unknown creature was using giant fins which propelled it through the water. Later the sailors saw its tail as well. The monster was longer than our whole ship", wrote Egede. (Mareš, 1997)[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]A hulk named after Hans Egede can be found at the point where Cliffe marshes meet the Thames, adjacent to Cliffe Fort.

Egede's book Det gamle Grønlands nye Perlustration, (The old Greenland's new Perlustration, or an accurate description of those old Nordic Colonies in Greenland) appeared in 1729 and was translated into several languages.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1733, the Herrnhut missionaries of Nicolaus Ludwig Zinzendorf were allowed to establish New Herrnhut, south of Nuuk. On 6 July 1734 his ship sailed past the coast of Greenland when suddenly those on board "saw a most terrible creature, resembling nothing they saw before. The monster lifted its head so high that it seemed to be higher than the crow's nest on the mainmast. The head was small and the body short and wrinkled. The unknown creature was using giant fins which propelled it through the water. Later the sailors saw its tail as well. The monster was longer than our whole ship", wrote Egede. (Mareš, 1997)[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]A hulk named after Hans Egede can be found at the point where Cliffe marshes meet the Thames, adjacent to Cliffe Fort.

TEXT.English: [H1]Danish Monarchy[\H1][BOLD][NEWLINE]Founded: [\BOLD]936 AD[PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB][PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]United into a single kingdom by Harald Blatand in 965 AD, The Danish monarchy is the oldest monarchy in Europe, and can trace its linage back to the Viking king, Gorm the old. From the 11th century, Denmark began a steady evolution from regional chiefs with a weak royal institution, into a realm which more closely matched the feudalism of its European neighbors, with a powerful king who ruled through an influential nobility. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]By the 14th century, internal discord and a series of civil wars had severely weakened the Danish monarchy and reduced the power and prestige of the country. Under the reign of Valdemar IV and his daughter Margaret I, Denmark experienced a resurgence, becoming the driving force behind the political unification under a single authority of the kingdoms of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the form of the Kalmar Union. Ineffectual leadership, discontent and eventually hostilities between Denmark and Sweden led to the Union's dissolution and two centuries of intermittent warfare between the two nations in which Denmark lost vast amounts of territory to its bitter rival.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1849 the Danish constitution was altered to create a constitutional monarchy for Denmark, and under Christian IX, the country embarked on several social reforms. During this period the Danish monarchy established through marriage, close ties to the ruling royal dynasties of Britain, Russia, Norway, Greece and the kingdom of Hanover, earning Christian IX the title "the Father-in-law of Europe." To this day the Danish Royal Family are related to most other reigning European royal families.
TEXT.French: [H1]Äàòñêàÿ ìîíàðõèÿ[\H1][BOLD][NEWLINE]Îñíîâàíà: [\BOLD]936 ãîä í.ý.[PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Èñòîðèÿ:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB][PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Îáúåäèíåííàÿ â åäèíîå êîðîëåâñòâî Õàðàëüäîì Áëàòàíäîì â 965 ãîäó í.ý., Äàòñêàÿ ìîíàðõèÿ ÿâëÿåòñÿ ñàìîé ñòàðîé ìîíàðõèåé â Åâðîïå è âåäåò ñâîþ ðîäîñëîâíóþ îò êîðîëÿ âèêèíãîâ, Ãîðìà Ñòàðîãî. Íà÷èíàÿ ñ XI âåêà, Äàíèÿ íà÷àëà óñòîé÷èâóþ ýâîëþöèþ îò ðåãèîíàëüíûõ âîæäåé ñî ñëàáûì êîðîëåâñêèì èíñòèòóòîì ê êîðîëåâñòâó, êîòîðîå áîëåå ñîîòâåòñòâîâàëî ôåîäàëèçìó ñâîèõ åâðîïåéñêèõ ñîñåäåé, ñ ìîãóùåñòâåííûì êîðîëåì, êîòîðûé óïðàâëÿë ÷åðåç âëèÿòåëüíîå äâîðÿíñòâî. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ê XIV âåêó âíóòðåííèå ðàçäîðû è ñåðèÿ ãðàæäàíñêèõ âîéí ñèëüíî îñëàáèëè äàòñêóþ ìîíàðõèþ è ñíèçèëè ìîùü è ïðåñòèæ ñòðàíû. Âî âðåìåíà ïðàâëåíèÿ Âàëüäåìàðà IV è åãî äî÷åðè Ìàðãàðèòû I Äàíèÿ ïåðåæèëà âîçðîæäåíèå, ñòàâ äâèæóùåé ñèëîé ïîëèòè÷åñêîãî îáúåäèíåíèÿ ïîä åäèíîé âëàñòüþ êîðîëåâñòâ Äàíèè, Íîðâåãèè è Øâåöèè â ôîðìå Êàëüìàðñêîé óíèè. Íåýôôåêòèâíîå ðóêîâîäñòâî, íåäîâîëüñòâî è â êîíå÷íîì èòîãå âðàæäà ìåæäó Äàíèåé è Øâåöèåé ïðèâåëè ê ðàñïàäó ñîþçà è äâóì ñòîëåòèÿì ïåðèîäè÷åñêèõ âîéí ìåæäó äâóìÿ ãîñóäàðñòâàìè, â õîäå êîòîðûõ Äàíèÿ ïîòåðÿëà îãðîìíûå òåððèòîðèè â ïîëüçó ñâîåãî çëåéøåãî ñîïåðíèêà.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Â 1849 ãîäó â äàòñêóþ êîíñòèòóöèþ áûëè âíåñåíû èçìåíåíèÿ, â ðåçóëüòàòå êîòîðûõ â Äàíèè áûëà ñîçäàíà êîíñòèòóöèîííàÿ ìîíàðõèÿ, à ïðè Êðèñòèàíå IX â ñòðàíå íà÷àëñÿ ðÿä ñîöèàëüíûõ ðåôîðì. Â ýòîò ïåðèîä äàòñêàÿ ìîíàðõèÿ óñòàíîâèëà ÷åðåç áðàêè òåñíûå ñâÿçè ñ ïðàâÿùèìè êîðîëåâñêèìè äèíàñòèÿìè Âåëèêîáðèòàíèè, Ðîññèè, Íîðâåãèè, Ãðåöèè è êîðîëåâñòâà Ãàííîâåð, ÷òî ïðèíåñëî Êðèñòèàíó IX òèòóë "òåñòü Åâðîïû". È ïî ñåé äåíü äàòñêàÿ êîðîëåâñêàÿ ñåìüÿ ñîñòîèò â ðîäñòâå ñ áîëüøèíñòâîì äðóãèõ ïðàâÿùèõ åâðîïåéñêèõ êîðîëåâñêèõ ñåìåé.
TEXT.German: [H1]Dänische Monarchie[\H1][BOLD][NEWLINE]Gegründet: [\BOLD]936 AD[PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB][PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Im Jahre 965 durch Harald Blatand zu einem einzelnen Königreich vereint, ist die dänsiche Monarchie die älteste in Europa und kann ihren Ursprung bis zu dem Vikingerkönig Gorm the Alte zurückverfolgen. Im 11ten Jahrhunder begann Dänemark eine stetige Evolution von regionalen Häuptlingen mit einer schwachen Königlichen Institution zu einem Reich mit ähnlichen feudalen Strukturen, einem mächtigen König und einflussreichen Edelmännern, wie in benachbarten europäischen Nationen. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Im 14ten Jahrhunder hatten interne Streitigkeiten und eine Reihe von Bürgerkriegen die dänische Monarchie und das Prestige des Landes stark geschwächt. Unter der Herrschaft von Valdemar IV und seiner Tochter Margaret I erfuhr die Monarchie von Dänemark einen erneuten Aufschwung und wurde die treibende Kraft Denmark einer politischen Union der Königreiche von Dänemark, Norwege und Schweden in der Form der Kalmar Union. Jedoch führten ineffektive Herrschaft, Unzufriedenheit und sogar Aggression zwischen Dänemark und Schweden zur Auflösung der Uniton und sogar zu zwei Jahrhunderten Kriege zwischen den beiden Nationen. Dänemark verlor in dieser Zeit grosse Gebiete an den erbitterten Gegner.
TEXT.Italian: [[H1]Danish Monarchy[\H1][BOLD][NEWLINE]Founded: [\BOLD]936 AD[PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB][PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]United into a single kingdom by Harald Blatand in 965 AD, The Danish monarchy is the oldest monarchy in Europe, and can trace its linage back to the Viking king, Gorm the old. From the 11th century, Denmark began a steady evolution from regional chiefs with a weak royal institution, into a realm which more closely matched the feudalism of its European neighbors, with a powerful king who ruled through an influential nobility. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]By the 14th century, internal discord and a series of civil wars had severely weakened the Danish monarchy and reduced the power and prestige of the country. Under the reign of Valdemar IV and his daughter Margaret I, Denmark experienced a resurgence, becoming the driving force behind the political unification under a single authority of the kingdoms of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the form of the Kalmar Union. Ineffectual leadership, discontent and eventually hostilities between Denmark and Sweden led to the Union's dissolution and two centuries of intermittent warfare between the two nations in which Denmark lost vast amounts of territory to its bitter rival.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1849 the Danish constitution was altered to create a constitutional monarchy for Denmark, and under Christian IX, the country embarked on several social reforms. During this period the Danish monarchy established through marriage, close ties to the ruling royal dynasties of Britain, Russia, Norway, Greece and the kingdom of Hanover, earning Christian IX the title "the Father-in-law of Europe." To this day the Danish Royal Family are related to most other reigning European royal families.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Danish Monarchy[\H1][BOLD][NEWLINE]Founded: [\BOLD]936 AD[PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB][PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]United into a single kingdom by Harald Blatand in 965 AD, The Danish monarchy is the oldest monarchy in Europe, and can trace its linage back to the Viking king, Gorm the old. From the 11th century, Denmark began a steady evolution from regional chiefs with a weak royal institution, into a realm which more closely matched the feudalism of its European neighbors, with a powerful king who ruled through an influential nobility. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]By the 14th century, internal discord and a series of civil wars had severely weakened the Danish monarchy and reduced the power and prestige of the country. Under the reign of Valdemar IV and his daughter Margaret I, Denmark experienced a resurgence, becoming the driving force behind the political unification under a single authority of the kingdoms of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the form of the Kalmar Union. Ineffectual leadership, discontent and eventually hostilities between Denmark and Sweden led to the Union's dissolution and two centuries of intermittent warfare between the two nations in which Denmark lost vast amounts of territory to its bitter rival.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]In 1849 the Danish constitution was altered to create a constitutional monarchy for Denmark, and under Christian IX, the country embarked on several social reforms. During this period the Danish monarchy established through marriage, close ties to the ruling royal dynasties of Britain, Russia, Norway, Greece and the kingdom of Hanover, earning Christian IX the title "the Father-in-law of Europe." To this day the Danish Royal Family are related to most other reigning European royal families.

TEXT.English: Greetings, [CT_NAME], governor of the [CT_EMPIRE]. I am [OUR_NAME], and I present you the friendship of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. I hope we can establish a lasting friendship on this day.
TEXT.French: Ïðèâåòñòâóþ òåáÿ, [CT_NAME], ãóáåðíàòîð [CT_EMPIRE]. ß - [OUR_NAME], è ÿ ïðåäñòàâëÿþ âàì äðóæáó íàðîäà [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. ß íàäåþñü, ÷òî â ýòîò äåíü ìû ñìîæåì óñòàíîâèòü ïðî÷íóþ äðóæáó.
TEXT.German: Ich fühle mich geehrt, das große Staatsoberhaupt [CT_NAME] kennenlernen zu dürfen! Wie kann das [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3] Volk Euch heute helfen?
TEXT.Italian: Sono onorato di incontrarti, grande [CT_NAME]! Come può aiutarti, oggi, la civiltà [OUR_CIV_ADJ] ?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un honor conocer al gran [CT_NAME]. ¿En qué pueden ayudaros hoy los [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3]?

TEXT.English: Your traitorous nation is not welcome any longer in this world. There will be no negotiations.
TEXT.French: Âàøåé ïðåäàòåëüñêîé íàöèè áîëüøå íå ðàäû â ýòîì ìèðå. Íèêàêèõ ïåðåãîâîðîâ íå áóäåò.
TEXT.German: Ich fürchte, es wäre momentan nicht von Vorteil, mit Euch zu reden.
TEXT.Italian: Ho paura che non sia conveniente parlarti in questo momento.
TEXT.Spanish: Me temo que no me sería ventajoso hablar con vos en este momento.

TEXT.English: Peace would be grossly disadvantageous for the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] at this moment. Your place is on the bottom of the sea.
TEXT.French: Ìèð áûë áû êðàéíå íåâûãîäåí äëÿ [OUR_CIV_ADJ] â äàííûé ìîìåíò. Âàøå ìåñòî - íà äíå ìîðÿ.
TEXT.German: Ich traue weder Euch, noch Eurem Volk. Frieden steht nicht zur Debatte.
TEXT.Italian: Non mi fido di te o del tuo popolo. La pace chiaramente non è contemplabile.
TEXT.Spanish: No confío en vos ni en vuestro pueblo. Obviamente, la paz no es una opción.

TEXT.English: Welcome, friend! Let us have dinner together, and share stories of our latest discoveries.
TEXT.French: Äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü, äðóã! Äàâàéòå âìåñòå ïîóæèíàåì è ïîäåëèìñÿ èñòîðèÿìè î íàøèõ ïîñëåäíèõ îòêðûòèÿõ.
TEXT.German: Ich bin froh, dass Ihr Euch die Zeit genommen habt, mich zu treffen. Was steht heute auf der Tagesordnung?
TEXT.Italian: Mi rallegra vedere che hai il tempo per venirmi a trovare. Cosa dobbiamo fare oggi?
TEXT.Spanish: Estoy encantado de que hayáis conseguido sacar el tiempo para venir a verme. ¿Qué tenemos hoy en la agenda?

TEXT.English: Your past transgressions have greatly saddened me. I can barely keep my fleet from attacking and scuttling yours. Do you have anything to say in your defense?
TEXT.French: Âàøè ïðîøëûå ïðîñòóïêè î÷åíü îãîð÷èëè ìåíÿ. ß åäâà ìîãó óäåðæàòü ñâîé ôëîò îò íàïàäåíèÿ è óíè÷òîæåíèÿ âàøåãî. Ó âàñ åñòü ÷òî ñêàçàòü â ñâîþ çàùèòó?
TEXT.German: Sprecht Euch ruhig aus und ich werde so tun, als ob ich zuhöre.
TEXT.Italian: Avanti, parla: farò finta di ascoltare.
TEXT.Spanish: Adelante, hablad. Yo haré ver que os escucho.

TEXT.English: Can you please help my people? We would help you if the tables were turned.
TEXT.French: Íå ìîãëè áû âû ïîìî÷ü ìîåìó íàðîäó? Ìû ïîìîãëè áû âàì, åñëè áû ñèòóàöèÿ èçìåíèëàñü.
TEXT.German: Könnt Ihr meinem Volk bitte helfen? Ich würde Euch auch helfen, wenn die Situation umgekehrt wäre.
TEXT.Italian: Puoi aiutare il mio popolo? Noi ti aiuteremmo, se le nostre posizioni fossero invertite.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Podéis ayudar a mi pueblo, por favor? Os ayudaremos si alguna vez cambian las tornas.

TEXT.English: We are in need, but do not have the surplus to trade. Please find it in your heart to donate what we need.
TEXT.French: Ìû íóæäàåìñÿ, íî íå èìååì èçëèøêîâ äëÿ òîðãîâëè. Ïîæàëóéñòà, íàéäèòå â ñåáå ñèëû ïîæåðòâîâàòü òî, ÷òî íàì íóæíî.
TEXT.German: Wir sind in Not, haben aber nicht genug, um zu handeln. Fasst Euch doch bitte ein Herz und spendet, was wir benötigen.
TEXT.Italian: Abbiamo bisogno di aiuto, ma non abbiamo niente da scambiare. Spero che trovi nel tuo cuore la volontà di donarci quello che ci serve.
TEXT.Spanish: Estamos necesitados, pero no tenemos excedentes que poder intercambiar. Por favor, buscad en vuestro corazón la voluntad para ayudarnos.

TEXT.English: The weakness of your civilization makes us laugh. Give us what we want or pay the consequences.
TEXT.French: Ñëàáîñòü âàøåé öèâèëèçàöèè çàñòàâëÿåò íàñ ñìåÿòüñÿ. Äàéòå íàì òî, ÷òî ìû õîòèì, èëè ïîïëàòèòåñü çà ïîñëåäñòâèÿ.
TEXT.German: Ich verabscheue es, auf den Friedfertigen herumzuhacken, aber ich werde es trotzdem tun. Gebt uns, was wir wollen, oder tragt die Konsequenzen.
TEXT.Italian: Odio approfittare degli umili, ma lo farò ugualmente. Dacci ciò che vogliamo o preparati ad affrontare le conseguenze.
TEXT.Spanish: Odio meterme con los pacíficos, pero lo haré de todas formas. Dadnos lo que queremos o sufrid las consecuencias.

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people welcomes [CT_NAME] to the nation God gave us as an inheritance for our grandchildren. Join us in our newly built stave church to give thanks to the Lord for bringing us together in these lands.
TEXT.French: Íàðîä [OUR_CIV_ADJ] ïðèâåòñòâóåò [CT_NAME] â íàöèè, êîòîðóþ Áîã äàë íàì â íàñëåäñòâî äëÿ íàøèõ âíóêîâ. Ïðèñîåäèíÿéòåñü ê íàì â íàøåé íåäàâíî ïîñòðîåííîé öåðêâè, ÷òîáû âîçáëàãîäàðèòü Ãîñïîäà çà òî, ÷òî îí ñîáðàë íàñ âìåñòå íà ýòèõ çåìëÿõ.

TEXT.Italian: Sono onorato di incontrarti, grande [CT_NAME]! Come può aiutarti, oggi, la civiltà [OUR_CIV_ADJ] ?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un honor conocer al gran [CT_NAME]. ¿En qué pueden ayudaros hoy los [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3]?

TEXT.English: The apostle Paul urged us in 2nd Corinthians 6:17 to be separate from infidels, idolaters and unclean things. Leave my presence now.
TEXT.French: Àïîñòîë Ïàâåë ïðèçûâàë íàñ âî 2-ì Ïîñëàíèè ê Êîðèíôÿíàì 6:17 áûòü îòäåëåííûìè îò íåâåðíûõ, èäîëîïîêëîííèêîâ è íå÷èñòûõ âåùåé. Ïîêèíüòå ìîå ïðèñóòñòâèå ñåé÷àñ æå.

TEXT.Italian: Ho paura che non sia conveniente parlarti in questo momento.
TEXT.Spanish: Me temo que no me sería ventajoso hablar con vos en este momento.

TEXT.English: As 2nd Chronicles 19:2 says: "Should you help the wicked and love those who hate the Lord?" There can be no peace with the sinful [CT_EMPIRE]/

TEXT.English: Welcome, brother, to the god-fearing [OUR_EMPIRE]. Let us celebrate our friendship in modesty, and give thanks to the Lord in Heaven.
TEXT.French: Äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü, áðàò, ê áîãîáîÿçíåííîìó [OUR_EMPIRE]. Äàâàéòå îòïðàçäíóåì íàøó äðóæáó â ñêðîìíîñòè è âîçáëàãîäàðèì Ãîñïîäà íà íåáåñàõ.

TEXT.English: Your evil nation is destined for a bloody, fiery end, but let me tell you, there will be even more fire waiting for you after the end. I hope you have come to confess your sins and surrender your belongings to the people of God.
TEXT.French: Âàø çëîé íàðîä æäåò êðîâàâûé, îãíåííûé êîíåö, íî ïîçâîëüòå ìíå ñêàçàòü âàì, ÷òî ïîñëå êîíöà âàñ áóäåò æäàòü åùå áîëüøèé îãîíü. ß íàäåþñü, ÷òî âû ïðèøëè èñïîâåäàòü ñâîè ãðåõè è îòäàòü ñâîå èìóùåñòâî íàðîäó Áîæüåìó.

TEXT.English: Can you please help my people? If we were in your place we would do the same.

TEXT.English: I despise picking on the meek, but I will do it anyway. Give us what we want or pay the consequences.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Soon after the recession of the last ice age, Sweden became populated by hunters and gatherers, during the Stone Age (6000 BC - 4000 BC). The region developed rather slowly compared to southern Europe; while the Romans wrote poetry, Scandinavia had just entered the Iron Age.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sweden was first mentioned in the 1st century, by Roman historian Tacitus, who wrote that the Suiones tribe lived out in the sea and were powerful in both arms and ships. This referred to the inhabitants of eastern Sweden: Svealand, primarily around lake Mälaren; towns of Stockholm, Sigtuna, and Birka. From this tribe, Sweden derived its name. The southern parts, on the other hand, were inhabited by Geats (Götar) in the Götaland territory. Little is known for certain about that time, but chronicles based on Norse sagas and the Beowulf epos go back about 2,000 years.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the Viking Age of the 9th and 10th century, Swedish vikings travelled east setting its mark on the Baltic countries, Russia, the Black Sea, further through the rivers of Russia down south to Constantinople and southern Europe.[PARAGRAPH:1]With Christianization in the 12th century, the country became consolidated, with its centre in the water-ways of the northern Baltic and the Gulf of Finland. In the 14th century Sweden, like the rest of Europe, was struck by the Black Death (the Plague), with all its effect.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the middle ages, the expansion of Sweden into the northern wilderness of Laplandia, the Scandinavian peninsula, and present-day Finland continued. Finland was a part of Sweden proper from 1362 until 1809.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1389, Norway, Denmark and Sweden were united under a single monarch in a treaty known as the Kalmar Union. After several wars and disputes between these nations, King Gustav I of Sweden (House of Vasa) broke free in 1521 and established a nation state, considered the foundation of modern Sweden. Shortly afterwards he rejected Catholicism and led Sweden to the Protestant Reformation. Gustav I is considered to be Sweden's "Father of the Nation". He was the first monarch from the House of Vasa. The House of Vasa also ruled between 1587 and 1668 in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. Between 1592 and 1599 Sweden and Poland were ruled in a personal union by Sigismund I Vasa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rise of Sweden as a Great Power, Swedish Empire, Sweden and the Great Northern War, Absolute Monarchy in Sweden, Sweden-Finland and Union between Sweden and Norway.[PARAGRAPH:1]The 17th century saw the rise of Sweden as one of the great powers in Europe, due to successful participation, initiated by King Gustav II Adolph, in the Thirty Years' War and by Charles X Gustav of Sweden in the The Deluge of Poland. Mighty as it was, it crumbled in the 18th century with Imperial Russia taking the reins of northern Europe in the Great Northern War, and finally in 1809 when the autonomous Grand Duchy of Finland was created out of the eastern half of Sweden.[PARAGRAPH:1]After Denmark was defeated in the Napoleonic wars, Norway was ceded to Sweden in the Treaty of Kiel. This led to the Campaign against Norway, which was fought in 1814, and ended with the Convention of Moss, which forced Norway into a union with Sweden that was not dissolved until 1905. But the campaign also signified the last of the Swedish wars and its 200 years of peace are arguably unique in the world today.[PARAGRAPH:1]The 19th century saw a significant population increase, generally attributed to peace, vaccination, and potatoes, doubling the population from 1750 to 1850. Many people in the countryside, where most Swedes lived, found themselves unemployed. The result was poverty, alcoholism, and massive emigration; it is believed that between 1850 and 1910 more than one million Swedes moved to the United States alone. In the early 20th century, more Swedes lived in Chicago than in Sweden's second biggest city, Gothenburg. However, as the Industrial revolution progressed during the century, people gradually began moving into cities to work in factories, and became involved in Socialistic unions. A threatening Socialist revolution was avoided in 1917, following the re-introduction of Parliamentarism, and the country was democratized.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sweden remained neutral during World War I and World War II, although its neutrality during World War II has been disputed. Sweden was part of the Marshall aid package but continued to stay non-aligned during the Cold War, and is still not a member of any military alliance. Following the second World War, Sweden made use of its natural resources and undemolished state, making it possible to expand its industry to supply the rebuilding of Europe, leading it to be one of the richest countries in the world by 1960. During most of the post-war era, the country was ruled by the Swedish Social Democratic Party that established a welfare state, striving for a "well being for all"-policy.[PARAGRAPH:1]As other economies were re-established, Sweden was surpassed in the 1970s, and had to adjust its politics in the 1990s, but still ranks among the top nations concerning well being of its inhabitants.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Âñêîðå ïîñëå îêîí÷àíèÿ ïîñëåäíåãî ëåäíèêîâîãî ïåðèîäà Øâåöèÿ áûëà çàñåëåíà îõîòíèêàìè è ñîáèðàòåëÿìè â ïåðèîä êàìåííîãî âåêà (6000 ã. äî í. ý. - 4000 ã. äî í. ý.). Ýòîò ðåãèîí ðàçâèâàëñÿ äîâîëüíî ìåäëåííî ïî ñðàâíåíèþ ñ þæíîé Åâðîïîé; êîãäà ðèìëÿíå ïèñàëè ñòèõè, Ñêàíäèíàâèÿ òîëüêî âñòóïèëà â æåëåçíûé âåê.[PARAGRAPH:1]Âïåðâûå Øâåöèÿ óïîìèíàåòñÿ â I âåêå ðèìñêèì èñòîðèêîì Òàöèòîì, êîòîðûé ïèñàë, ÷òî ïëåìÿ ñóéîíîâ æèëî çà ìîðåì è áûëî ñèëüíî êàê â îðóæèè, òàê è â êîðàáëÿõ. Ýòî îòíîñèëîñü ê æèòåëÿì âîñòî÷íîé Øâåöèè: Ñâåàëàíä, â îñíîâíîì âîêðóã îçåðà Ìäëàðåí; ãîðîäà Ñòîêãîëüì, Ñèãòóíà è Áèðêà. Îò ýòîãî ïëåìåíè Øâåöèÿ è ïîëó÷èëà ñâîå íàçâàíèå. Â þæíûõ ðàéîíàõ, íàïðîòèâ, æèëè ãåàòû (Götar) íà òåððèòîðèè Götaland. Î òîì âðåìåíè èçâåñòíî íåìíîãî, íî õðîíèêè, îñíîâàííûå íà íîðâåæñêèõ ñàãàõ è ýïîñå "Áåîâóëüô", íàñ÷èòûâàþò îêîëî 2 000 ëåò.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â ýïîõó âèêèíãîâ IX-X âåêîâ øâåäñêèå âèêèíãè îòïðàâèëèñü íà âîñòîê, îñòàâèâ ñâîé ñëåä íà Áàëòèêå, Ðóñè, ×åðíîì ìîðå, äàëåå ïî ðåêàì Ðîññèè íà þã äî Êîíñòàíòèíîïîëÿ è Þæíîé Åâðîïû. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ïîñëå õðèñòèàíèçàöèè â XII âåêå ñòðàíà ñòàëà êîíñîëèäèðîâàííîé, åå öåíòð íàõîäèëñÿ â âîäíûõ ïóòÿõ ñåâåðíîé Áàëòèêè è Ôèíñêîãî çàëèâà. Â XIV âåêå Øâåöèþ, êàê è âñþ Åâðîïó, ïîðàçèëà ×åðíàÿ ñìåðòü (÷óìà) ñî âñåìè åå ïîñëåäñòâèÿìè.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â ñðåäíèå âåêà ïðîäîëæàëàñü ýêñïàíñèÿ Øâåöèè â ñåâåðíóþ Ëàïëàíäèþ, íà Ñêàíäèíàâñêèé ïîëóîñòðîâ è â ñîâðåìåííóþ Ôèíëÿíäèþ. Ôèíëÿíäèÿ âõîäèëà â ñîñòàâ Øâåöèè ñ 1362 ïî 1809 ã.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â 1389 ã. Íîðâåãèÿ, Äàíèÿ è Øâåöèÿ áûëè îáúåäèíåíû ïîä âëàñòüþ åäèíîãî ìîíàðõà â ñîîòâåòñòâèè ñ äîãîâîðîì, èçâåñòíûì êàê Êàëüìàðñêàÿ óíèÿ. Ïîñëå íåñêîëüêèõ âîéí è ñïîðîâ ìåæäó ýòèìè ñòðàíàìè øâåäñêèé êîðîëü Ãóñòàâ I (äîì Âàñà) â 1521 ãîäó âûðâàëñÿ íà ñâîáîäó è ñîçäàë íàöèîíàëüíîå ãîñóäàðñòâî, êîòîðîå ñ÷èòàåòñÿ îñíîâîé ñîâðåìåííîé Øâåöèè. Âñêîðå ïîñëå ýòîãî îí îòâåðã êàòîëèöèçì è ïðèâåë Øâåöèþ ê ïðîòåñòàíòñêîé Ðåôîðìàöèè. Ãóñòàâ I ñ÷èòàåòñÿ "îòöîì íàöèè" Øâåöèè. Îí áûë ïåðâûì ìîíàðõîì èç äîìà Âàñà. Äîì Âàñà òàêæå ïðàâèë ñ 1587 ïî 1668 ãîä â Ðå÷è Ïîñïîëèòîé. Ñ 1592 ïî 1599 ãîä Øâåöèåé è Ïîëüøåé â ëè÷íîé óíèè ïðàâèë Ñèãèçìóíä I Âàçà.[PARAGRAPH:1]Âîçâûøåíèå Øâåöèè êàê âåëèêîé äåðæàâû, Øâåäñêàÿ èìïåðèÿ, Øâåöèÿ è Ñåâåðíàÿ âîéíà, Àáñîëþòíàÿ ìîíàðõèÿ â Øâåöèè, Øâåöèÿ-Ôèíëÿíäèÿ è ñîþç Øâåöèè è Íîðâåãèè.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â XVII âåêå Øâåöèÿ ñòàëà îäíîé èç âåëèêèõ äåðæàâ Åâðîïû áëàãîäàðÿ óñïåøíîìó ó÷àñòèþ, èíèöèèðîâàííîìó êîðîëåì Ãóñòàâîì II Àäîëüôîì, â Òðèäöàòèëåòíåé âîéíå è Êàðëîì X Ãóñòàâîì Øâåäñêèì â Ïîòîïå Ïîëüøè. Ìîãóùåñòâåííàÿ, îíà ðàñïàëàñü â XVIII âåêå, êîãäà èìïåðàòîðñêàÿ Ðîññèÿ âçÿëà áðàçäû ïðàâëåíèÿ Ñåâåðíîé Åâðîïîé â Ñåâåðíîé âîéíå, è, íàêîíåö, â 1809 ãîäó, êîãäà èç âîñòî÷íîé ïîëîâèíû Øâåöèè áûëî ñîçäàíî àâòîíîìíîå Âåëèêîå êíÿæåñòâî Ôèíëÿíäñêîå.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ïîñëå ïîðàæåíèÿ Äàíèè â íàïîëåîíîâñêèõ âîéíàõ Íîðâåãèÿ áûëà óñòóïëåíà Øâåöèè ïî Êèëüñêîìó äîãîâîðó. Ýòî ïðèâåëî ê êàìïàíèè ïðîòèâ Íîðâåãèè, êîòîðàÿ âåëàñü â 1814 ãîäó è çàêîí÷èëàñü Ìîññêîé êîíâåíöèåé, âûíóäèâøåé Íîðâåãèþ âñòóïèòü â ñîþç ñî Øâåöèåé, êîòîðûé íå áûë ðàñòîðãíóò äî 1905 ãîäà. Íî ýòà êàìïàíèÿ òàêæå îçíàìåíîâàëà ñîáîé ïîñëåäíþþ èç øâåäñêèõ âîéí, è 200 ëåò ìèðà â Øâåöèè ÿâëÿþòñÿ, ïîæàëóé, óíèêàëüíûì ñîáûòèåì â ñîâðåìåííîì ìèðå.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â XIX âåêå ïðîèçîøåë çíà÷èòåëüíûé ðîñò íàñåëåíèÿ, êîòîðûé îáû÷íî ñâÿçûâàþò ñ ìèðîì, âàêöèíàöèåé è êàðòîôåëåì. Ñ 1750 ïî 1850 ãîä íàñåëåíèå ñòðàíû óäâîèëîñü. Ìíîãèå æèòåëè ñåëüñêîé ìåñòíîñòè, ãäå ïðîæèâàëî áîëüøèíñòâî øâåäîâ, îêàçàëèñü áåçðàáîòíûìè. Ðåçóëüòàòîì ñòàëè áåäíîñòü, àëêîãîëèçì è ìàññîâàÿ ýìèãðàöèÿ; ñ÷èòàåòñÿ, ÷òî ñ 1850 ïî 1910 ãîä áîëåå ìèëëèîíà øâåäîâ ïåðååõàëè â îäíè òîëüêî Ñîåäèíåííûå Øòàòû. Â íà÷àëå XX âåêà â ×èêàãî æèëî áîëüøå øâåäîâ, ÷åì âî âòîðîì ïî âåëè÷èíå ãîðîäå Øâåöèè, Ãåòåáîðãå. Îäíàêî ïî ìåðå ðàçâèòèÿ ïðîìûøëåííîé ðåâîëþöèè â òå÷åíèå âåêà ëþäè ïîñòåïåííî ñòàëè ïåðååçæàòü â ãîðîäà, ÷òîáû ðàáîòàòü íà ôàáðèêàõ, è âñòóïàòü â ñîöèàëèñòè÷åñêèå ïðîôñîþçû. Óãðîæàþùåé ñîöèàëèñòè÷åñêîé ðåâîëþöèè óäàëîñü èçáåæàòü â 1917 ãîäó ïîñëå ââåäåíèÿ ïàðëàìåíòàðèçìà, è ñòðàíà áûëà äåìîêðàòèçèðîâàíà.[PARAGRAPH:1]Øâåöèÿ ñîõðàíÿëà íåéòðàëèòåò âî âðåìÿ Ïåðâîé è Âòîðîé ìèðîâûõ âîéí, õîòÿ åå íåéòðàëèòåò âî âðåìÿ Âòîðîé ìèðîâîé âîéíû îñïàðèâàëñÿ. Øâåöèÿ áûëà ÷àñòüþ ïàêåòà ïîìîùè Ìàðøàëëà, íî ïðîäîëæàëà îñòàâàòüñÿ íåïðèñîåäèíèâøåéñÿ âî âðåìÿ õîëîäíîé âîéíû è äî ñèõ ïîð íå ÿâëÿåòñÿ ÷ëåíîì êàêîãî-ëèáî âîåííîãî àëüÿíñà. Ïîñëå Âòîðîé ìèðîâîé âîéíû Øâåöèÿ âîñïîëüçîâàëàñü ñâîèìè ïðèðîäíûìè ðåñóðñàìè è íåðàçðóøåííûì ãîñóäàðñòâîì, ÷òî ïîçâîëèëî åé ðàñøèðèòü ñâîþ ïðîìûøëåííîñòü äëÿ îáåñïå÷åíèÿ âîññòàíîâëåíèÿ Åâðîïû, è ê 1960 ãîäó îíà ñòàëà îäíîé èç ñàìûõ áîãàòûõ ñòðàí â ìèðå. Â òå÷åíèå áîëüøåé ÷àñòè ïîñëåâîåííîãî ïåðèîäà ñòðàíîé óïðàâëÿëà Øâåäñêàÿ ñîöèàë-äåìîêðàòè÷åñêàÿ ïàðòèÿ, êîòîðàÿ ñîçäàëà ãîñóäàðñòâî âñåîáùåãî áëàãîñîñòîÿíèÿ, ñòðåìÿñü ê ïîëèòèêå "áëàãîñîñòîÿíèÿ äëÿ âñåõ".[PARAGRAPH:1]Êàê è äðóãèå ýêîíîìè÷åñêèå
TEXT.German: [TAB]Bald nach dem Rückgang der letzten Eiszeit wurde Schweden in der Steinzeit durch Jäger und Sammler bevölkert. (6000 BC - 4000 BC). Die Region entwickelte sich im Vergleich zu Südeuropa sehr langsam. Während die Römer bereits Gediche schrieben und eine ausgeprägte Kultur aufwiesen, hatte Skandinavien gerad erst die Eisenzeit erreicht.[PARAGRAPH:1]Schweden wird zum ersten Mal im 1ten Jahrhunder schriftlich erwähnt. Der römische Historiker Tacitus schrieb, dass der Stamm der Suionen im offenen Meer beheimatet sei und sowohl erfahrene Seefahere, wie auch mächtige Krieger seien. Dies bezog sich auf die Einwohner des östlichen Schwedens, Svealand, in der Nähe der heutigen Städte Stockholm und Birka. Durch diesen Stamm bekam Schweden seinen Namen. Die südlichen Teile wurden von den Geaten beheimatet. Wenig ist über diese Völker sicher bekannt, aber einige Chroniken und Sagen, wie das Beowulf Epos, reichen fast 2000 Jahre bis ins 1te Jahrhundert zurück.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im Wikingerzeitalter des 9ten und 10ten Jahrhunderts, bereisten Schwedische Wikinger ostwärts in die baltischen Gebiete und hinterliesen dort, in Russland und in der Gegend des Scharzen Meeres ihre Spuren. Sie reisten sogar über die Flüsse Russlands bis nach Konstantinopel und nach Südeuropa. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mit der Christianisierung im 12ten Jahrhundert wurde das Land konsolidiert. Das Zentrum waren die Wasserstrassen im Baltikum und im Golf von Finnland. Im 14ten Jahrhundert wurde Schweden, wie der Rest Europas auch, von der Pest heimgesucht. [PARAGRAPH:1]Im Mittelalter schritt die Expansion Schwedens nach Lapland, die Skandinavische Peninsula und das heuteige Finnland weiter fort. Zwischen 1362 und 1809 war Finnland Teil Schwedens. [PARAGRAPH:1]1389, wurden Norwegen, Dänemark und Schweden unter einem einzigen Monarchen in der Kalmar Union vereint. Nach mehreren Konflikten und sogar Kriegen zwischen diesen drei Mächten brach King Gustav I von Schweden jedoch das Abkommen 1521 und etablierte einen Nationalstaat, der heute als Ursprung des modernen Schwedens betrachtet wird. Kurz danach sagte er sich vom Katholizismus los und führte Schweden in die Protestantische Reformation. Zwischen 1592 und 1599 wurden Schweden und Polen in einer Personalunion durch Sigismund I Vasa regiert.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das 17te Jahrhunder sah Schwede zu einer Grossmacht in Europa aufsteigen, die im 30-jährigen Krieg eine wichtige Rolle spielte. So mächtig Schweden auch war, zerbrach es schliesslich daran, dass Russland die Vormachtstellung in Nordosteuropa übernahm und Finnland sich 1809 loslöste. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nachdem Dänemark im Napoleonischen Krieg besiegt war, wurde Norwegen im Vertrag von Kiel Schweden zugesprochen. Dies führte zu einer Kampagne gegen Norwegen, die 1814 heftige Kämpfe verursachte und mit der Konvention von Moss beendet wurde, die Norwegen schliesslich in eine Union mit Schweden zwang, die erst 1905 wieder aufgelöst wurde. Diese Kampagne war jedoch der letzte signifikante Konflikt Schwedens und die 200 Jahre Frieden, die das Land seitdem erlebt, sind zweifellos einzigartig auf der Welt.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Soon after the recession of the last ice age, Sweden became populated by hunters and gatherers, during the Stone Age (6000 BC - 4000 BC). The region developed rather slowly compared to southern Europe; while the Romans wrote poetry, Scandinavia had just entered the Iron Age.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sweden was first mentioned in the 1st century, by Roman historian Tacitus, who wrote that the Suiones tribe lived out in the sea and were powerful in both arms and ships. This referred to the inhabitants of eastern Sweden: Svealand, primarily around lake Mälaren; towns of Stockholm, Sigtuna, and Birka. From this tribe, Sweden derived its name. The southern parts, on the other hand, were inhabited by Geats (Götar) in the Götaland territory. Little is known for certain about that time, but chronicles based on Norse sagas and the Beowulf epos go back about 2,000 years.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the Viking Age of the 9th and 10th century, Swedish vikings travelled east setting its mark on the Baltic countries, Russia, the Black Sea, further through the rivers of Russia down south to Constantinople and southern Europe.[PARAGRAPH:1]With Christianization in the 12th century, the country became consolidated, with its centre in the water-ways of the northern Baltic and the Gulf of Finland. In the 14th century Sweden, like the rest of Europe, was struck by the Black Death (the Plague), with all its effect.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the middle ages, the expansion of Sweden into the northern wilderness of Laplandia, the Scandinavian peninsula, and present-day Finland continued. Finland was a part of Sweden proper from 1362 until 1809.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1389, Norway, Denmark and Sweden were united under a single monarch in a treaty known as the Kalmar Union. After several wars and disputes between these nations, King Gustav I of Sweden (House of Vasa) broke free in 1521 and established a nation state, considered the foundation of modern Sweden. Shortly afterwards he rejected Catholicism and led Sweden to the Protestant Reformation. Gustav I is considered to be Sweden's "Father of the Nation". He was the first monarch from the House of Vasa. The House of Vasa also ruled between 1587 and 1668 in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. Between 1592 and 1599 Sweden and Poland were ruled in a personal union by Sigismund I Vasa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rise of Sweden as a Great Power, Swedish Empire, Sweden and the Great Northern War, Absolute Monarchy in Sweden, Sweden-Finland and Union between Sweden and Norway.[PARAGRAPH:1]The 17th century saw the rise of Sweden as one of the great powers in Europe, due to successful participation, initiated by King Gustav II Adolph, in the Thirty Years' War and by Charles X Gustav of Sweden in the The Deluge of Poland. Mighty as it was, it crumbled in the 18th century with Imperial Russia taking the reins of northern Europe in the Great Northern War, and finally in 1809 when the autonomous Grand Duchy of Finland was created out of the eastern half of Sweden.[PARAGRAPH:1]After Denmark was defeated in the Napoleonic wars, Norway was ceded to Sweden in the Treaty of Kiel. This led to the Campaign against Norway, which was fought in 1814, and ended with the Convention of Moss, which forced Norway into a union with Sweden that was not dissolved until 1905. But the campaign also signified the last of the Swedish wars and its 200 years of peace are arguably unique in the world today.[PARAGRAPH:1]The 19th century saw a significant population increase, generally attributed to peace, vaccination, and potatoes, doubling the population from 1750 to 1850. Many people in the countryside, where most Swedes lived, found themselves unemployed. The result was poverty, alcoholism, and massive emigration; it is believed that between 1850 and 1910 more than one million Swedes moved to the United States alone. In the early 20th century, more Swedes lived in Chicago than in Sweden's second biggest city, Gothenburg. However, as the Industrial revolution progressed during the century, people gradually began moving into cities to work in factories, and became involved in Socialistic unions. A threatening Socialist revolution was avoided in 1917, following the re-introduction of Parliamentarism, and the country was democratized.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sweden remained neutral during World War I and World War II, although its neutrality during World War II has been disputed. Sweden was part of the Marshall aid package but continued to stay non-aligned during the Cold War, and is still not a member of any military alliance. Following the second World War, Sweden made use of its natural resources and undemolished state, making it possible to expand its industry to supply the rebuilding of Europe, leading it to be one of the richest countries in the world by 1960. During most of the post-war era, the country was ruled by the Swedish Social Democratic Party that established a welfare state, striving for a "well being for all"-policy.[PARAGRAPH:1]As other economies were re-established, Sweden was surpassed in the 1970s, and had to adjust its politics in the 1990s, but still ranks among the top nations concerning well being of its inhabitants.

TEXT.English: [H1]Johan Risingh[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Last Governor of New Sweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1617 - 1672 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Johan Risingh was born in 1617 in Risinge, Östergötland, Sweden. Educated at the Universities Upsala and Leyden, he held the office of the Commercial College of Sweden from 1651-53. In 1653 Risingh wrote the first Swedish treaties on trade and economics, for which he received a knighthood and was given the position of Governor of New Sweden. He set out for the New World in early 1654. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Rislingh's first act as governor of New Sweden was to neutralize the mounting threat of Dutch encroachment by seizing the Dutch outpost of Fort Casimir, erected just to the south of the Swedish settlement of Fort Christina. The Dutch responded by mounting a military campaign that not only retook the fort, but saw the successive capitulation of each Swedish settlement to Dutch control, thus ending the short lived colony of New Sweden.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]After the surrender, those colonists unwilling to become Dutch subjects were transported back to Europe, Risingh along with other officials and many soldiers was amongst them. He died in poverty at Stockholm in 1672.
TEXT.French: [H1]Þõàí Ðèçèíãõ[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ïîñëåäíèé ãóáåðíàòîð Íîâîé Øâåöèè[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Æèë: [\BOLD]1617 - 1672 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Áèîãðàôèÿ:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Þõàí Ðèçèíãõ ðîäèëñÿ â 1617 ãîäó â Ðèçèíãå, ÖÑòåðãöòëàíä, Øâåöèÿ. Îí ïîëó÷èë îáðàçîâàíèå â Óïñàëüñêîì è Ëåéäåíñêîì óíèâåðñèòåòàõ, à â 1651-53 ãã. çàíèìàë äîëæíîñòü â Êîììåð÷åñêîì êîëëåäæå Øâåöèè. Â 1653 ãîäó Ðèçèíãõ íàïèñàë ïåðâûå øâåäñêèå äîãîâîðû ïî òîðãîâëå è ýêîíîìèêå, çà ÷òî ïîëó÷èë ðûöàðñêîå çâàíèå è äîëæíîñòü ãóáåðíàòîðà Íîâîé Øâåöèè. Â íà÷àëå 1654 ãîäà îí îòïðàâèëñÿ â Íîâûé Ñâåò. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ïåðâûì äåéñòâèåì Ðèñëèíãà â êà÷åñòâå ãóáåðíàòîðà Íîâîé Øâåöèè ñòàëà íåéòðàëèçàöèÿ ðàñòóùåé óãðîçû âòîðæåíèÿ ãîëëàíäöåâ ïóòåì çàõâàòà ãîëëàíäñêîãî ôîðïîñòà Ôîðò-Êàçèìèð, âîçâåäåííîãî ê þãó îò øâåäñêîãî ïîñåëåíèÿ Ôîðò-Êðèñòèíà. Â îòâåò ãîëëàíäöû íà÷àëè âîåííóþ êàìïàíèþ, â õîäå êîòîðîé íå òîëüêî îòáèëè ôîðò, íî è ïîñëåäîâàòåëüíî êàïèòóëèðîâàëè âñå øâåäñêèå ïîñåëåíèÿ ïîä ãîëëàíäñêèì êîíòðîëåì, ïîëîæèâ òåì ñàìûì êîíåö íåäîëãîâå÷íîé êîëîíèè Íîâàÿ Øâåöèÿ.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ïîñëå êàïèòóëÿöèè êîëîíèñòû, íå æåëàâøèå ñòàíîâèòüñÿ ãîëëàíäñêèìè ïîääàííûìè, áûëè âûâåçåíû îáðàòíî â Åâðîïó, ñðåäè íèõ áûë è Ðèçèíãõ âìåñòå ñ äðóãèìè ÷èíîâíèêàìè è ìíîæåñòâîì ñîëäàò. Îí óìåð â íèùåòå â Ñòîêãîëüìå â 1672 ãîäó.
TEXT.German: [H1]Johan Risingh[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Letzter Gouvernuer von Neu-Schweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte: [\BOLD] 1617 - 1672 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Johan Risingh wurde 1617 in Risinge in Schweden geboren. Ausbebildet an den Universitäten Upsala und Leyden, führte er von 1651-53 das Finanzministerium von Schweden. 1653 schrieb Risingh die erste Schwedische Abhandlung zu Handel und Wirtschaft, wofür er sogar zum Ritter geschlagen wurde und die Position des Gouverneurs von Neu Schweden erhielt. Er brach 1654 in die Neue Welt auf. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Rislinghs erste Amtshandlung als Gouverneur von Neu Schweden bestand daraus, die wachsenden Bedrohung einer Umschliessung durch die Niederlande zu neutralisieieren indem er den niederländischen Aussenposten Fort Casimier einnahm, der etwas südlich der schwedischen Siedlung Fort Christina errichtet worden war. Die Niederlande reagierten mit einer militärische Kampagne, die nicht nur das Fort wieder einnahm, sondern auch schritteweise zur Kapitulation einer jeden einzelnen schwedischen Siedlung führte, wodurch die kurze Geschichte von Neu-Schweden beendet wurde.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Nach der Unterwerfung wurden die Siedler, die nicht niederländische Untertanen werden wollten, zurück nach Europa verschifft. Risingh und die verbliebenen Beamten und Soldaten waren unter diesen. Er starb 1672 verarmt in Stockholm.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Johan Risingh[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Last Governor of New Sweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1617 - 1672 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Johan Risingh was born in 1617 in Risinge, Östergötland, Sweden. Educated at the Universities Upsala and Leyden, he held the office of the Commercial College of Sweden from 1651-53. In 1653 Risingh wrote the first Swedish treatise on trade and economics, for which he received a knighthood and was given the position of Governor of New Sweden. He set out for the New World in early 1654. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Rislingh's first act as governor of New Sweden was to neutralize the mounting threat of Dutch encroachment by seizing the Dutch outpost of Fort Casimir, erected just to the south of the Swedish settlement of Fort Christina. The Dutch responded by mounting a military campaign that not only retook the fort, but saw the successive capitulation of each Swedish settlement to Dutch control, thus ending the short lived colony of New Sweden.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]After the surrender, those colonists unwilling to become Dutch subjects were transported back to Europe, Risingh along with other officials and many soldiers was amongst them. He died in poverty at Stockholm in 1672.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Johan Risingh[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Last Governor of New Sweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1617 - 1672 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Johan Risingh was born in 1617 in Risinge, Östergötland, Sweden. Educated at the Universities Upsala and Leyden, he held the office of the Commercial College of Sweden from 1651-53. In 1653 Risingh wrote the first Swedish treatise on trade and economics, for which he received a knighthood and was given the position of Governor of New Sweden. He set out for the New World in early 1654. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Rislingh's first act as governor of New Sweden was to neutralize the mounting threat of Dutch encroachment by seizing the Dutch outpost of Fort Casimir, erected just to the south of the Swedish settlement of Fort Christina. The Dutch responded by mounting a military campaign that not only retook the fort, but saw the successive capitulation of each Swedish settlement to Dutch control, thus ending the short lived colony of New Sweden.[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]After the surrender, those colonists unwilling to become Dutch subjects were transported back to Europe, Risingh along with other officials and many soldiers was amongst them. He died in poverty at Stockholm in 1672.

TEXT.English: [H1]Johan Printz[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Fourth Governor of New Sweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD] 1592 - 1663 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Born the son of a Lutheran pastor, Johan Printz received his early education in Sweden followed by theological studies at German Universities. His career choice was interrupted in 1620 when he was pressed into military service, a change that would ultimately prove to suit him. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]During the Thirty Years War, Printz served as a mercenary for the Archduke Leopold of Austria, Duke Christian of Brunswick and King Christian IV of Denmark, before joining the Swedish Army and rising to the rank of lieutenant colonel. Dismissed from the army for surrendering the Saxon town of Chemitz, Printz had returned to royal favor by 1642, and after receiving a title of nobility was appointed to the post of governor of New Sweden. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Under his rule, the colony of New Sweden initially prospered, Forts Nya Elfsborg and New Gothenburg were built and Printz secured amicable relations with the local Indians as well as New Sweden's closest European neighbors in the New World, the English and the Dutch. Positioned between the much larger and better supplied colonies of the Dutch and the English, Printz was unable to prevent his European rivals from monopolizing the beaver fur trade in the area, and as New Sweden's future became more tenuous, Printz's autocratic style of governance increased, leading to several colonists petitioning to take their grievances directly to the Swedish government. Printz hanged the leader of the dissidents, but his position as governor quickly became untenable and in 1653 he returned to Sweden. Upon his return to Sweden Printz was made a general and in 1658 was appointed governor of Jönköping. He died in 1663 of injuries after being thrown from his horse.
TEXT.French: [H1]Þõàí Ïðèíö[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]×åòâåðòûé ãóáåðíàòîð Íîâîé Øâåöèè[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Æèë: [\BOLD]1592 - 1663 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Áèîãðàôèÿ:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Ðîäèâøèñü â ñåìüå ëþòåðàíñêîãî ïàñòîðà, Þõàí Ïðèíö ïîëó÷èë ðàííåå îáðàçîâàíèå â Øâåöèè, à çàòåì èçó÷àë òåîëîãèþ â íåìåöêèõ óíèâåðñèòåòàõ. Åãî êàðüåðà áûëà ïðåðâàíà â 1620 ãîäó, êîãäà îí áûë ïðèçâàí íà âîåííóþ ñëóæáó, è ýòà ïåðåìåíà â êîíå÷íîì èòîãå îêàçàëàñü åìó íà ðóêó. Óâîëåííûé èç àðìèè çà ñäà÷ó ñàêñîíñêîãî ãîðîäà Õåìèòö, Ïðèíö ê 1642 ãîäó âåðíóëñÿ ê êîðîëåâñêîé ìèëîñòè è, ïîëó÷èâ äâîðÿíñêèé òèòóë, áûë íàçíà÷åí íà ïîñò ãóáåðíàòîðà Íîâîé Øâåöèè. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Ïðè åãî ïðàâëåíèè êîëîíèÿ Íîâàÿ Øâåöèÿ ïîíà÷àëó ïðîöâåòàëà, áûëè ïîñòðîåíû ôîðòû Íüÿ-Ýëüôñáîðã è Íîâûé Ãåòåáîðã, è Ïðèíö íàëàäèë äðóæåñêèå îòíîøåíèÿ ñ ìåñòíûìè èíäåéöàìè, à òàêæå áëèæàéøèìè åâðîïåéñêèìè ñîñåäÿìè Íîâîé Øâåöèè â Íîâîì Ñâåòå - àíãëè÷àíàìè è ãîëëàíäöàìè. Îêàçàâøèñü ìåæäó ãîðàçäî áîëåå êðóïíûìè è õîðîøî ñíàáæàåìûìè êîëîíèÿìè ãîëëàíäöåâ è àíãëè÷àí, Ïðèíòö íå ñìîã ïîìåøàòü ñâîèì åâðîïåéñêèì êîíêóðåíòàì ìîíîïîëèçèðîâàòü òîðãîâëþ áîáðîâûì ìåõîì â ýòîì ðàéîíå, à ïîñêîëüêó áóäóùåå Íîâîé Øâåöèè ñòàíîâèëîñü âñå áîëåå øàòêèì, àâòîêðàòè÷åñêèé ñòèëü ïðàâëåíèÿ Ïðèíòöà óñèëèëñÿ, ÷òî ïðèâåëî ê òîìó, ÷òî íåñêîëüêî êîëîíèñòîâ ïîäàëè ïåòèöèþ ñ òðåáîâàíèåì îáðàòèòüñÿ ñî ñâîèìè ïðåòåíçèÿìè íåïîñðåäñòâåííî ê øâåäñêîìó ïðàâèòåëüñòâó. Ïðèíòö ïîâåñèë ëèäåðà äèññèäåíòîâ, íî åãî ïîëîæåíèå ãóáåðíàòîðà áûñòðî ñòàëî íåñîñòîÿòåëüíûì, è â 1653 ãîäó îí âåðíóëñÿ â Øâåöèþ. Ïî âîçâðàùåíèè â Øâåöèþ Ïðèíö ïîëó÷èë çâàíèå ãåíåðàëà, à â 1658 ãîäó áûë íàçíà÷åí ãóáåðíàòîðîì Éöíêöïèíãà. Îí óìåð â 1663 ãîäó îò ðàí, ïîëó÷åííûõ ïîñëå òîãî, êàê åãî ñáðîñèëè ñ ëîøàäè.
TEXT.German: [H1]Johan Printz[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vierter Gouvernuer von Neu-Schweden[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte: [\BOLD] 1592 - 1663 [PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Als Sohn eine lutheranischen Pastors geboren, erhielt Johan Printz seine frühe Erziehung in Schweden, gefolgt von theologischen Studien an deutschen Universitäten. Seine theologische Karriere wurde jedoch 1620 unterbrochen, als er in den Militärdienst gezwungen wurde, was sich letztlich als passend für ihn erwies. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Im 30jährigen Krieg diente Printz als Söldner für den Erzherzog von österreich und König Christian IV von Dänemark, bevor er der Schwedischen Armee beitrat und zum Rang eines Lieutnant-Major aufstieg. Aus der Armee entlassen, weil er die sächsische Stadt Chemnitz in einer Kapitulation übergab, erhob er sich 1642 wieder in königliche Gunst und wurde zum Gouverneur von Neu-Schweden. [PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Zu Beginn seiner Herrschaft über Neu-Schweden, wuchs der Wohlstand der Kolonie. Forts Nya Elfsborg und New Gothenburg wurden erbaut und Printz sicherte freundschaftliche Beziehungen zu den örtlichen Ureinwohnern, wie auch den europäischen Nachbarn in der Neuen Welt, den Engländern und den Niederländern. In einer Position zwischen den viel grösseren und besser ausgerüsteten Kolonien dieser Nationen, konnte Printz nicht verhindern, dass der Pelzhandel von diesen Nationen monopolisiert wurde. Als die Lage von Neu-Schweden immer angespannter wurde, wurde auch der Führungsstil von Printz immer autokratischer, was einige Kolonisten veranlasste eine Petition and die Schwedische Regierung zu schicken. Printz lies den Führer dieser Dissidenten hängen, aber seine Position als Gouverneur wurde dennoch schon bald untragbar und 1653 musste er nach Schweden zurückkehren. Nach seiner Rückkehr 1658 wurde Printz zum Gouverneur von Jönköping ernannt. Er starb 1663 durch Verletzungen, die er sich zuzog als er von eine Pferd abgeworfen wurde.

Upon his return to Sweden Printz was made a general and in 1658 was appointed governor of Jönköping. He died in 1663 of injuries after being thrown from his horse.
