Ñ÷èòàåòñÿ, ÷òî îí ðîäèëñÿ íà îñòðîâå Ãâàäåëóïà âî âòîðîé ïîëîâèíå XV âåêà. Êàñèê - ñëîâî ÿçûêà òàèíî, êîðåííîãî íàñåëåíèÿ Àíòèëüñêèõ îñòðîâîâ, îçíà÷àþùåå âîæäÿ. Â èñïàíñêîì âïîñëåäñòâèè ñòàëî èñïîëüçîâàòüñÿ äëÿ îáîçíà÷åíèÿ âîæäåé èíäåéöåâ.[PARAGRAPH:1] Õîðåéýáî ïðèîáðåë èçâåñòíîñòü óæàñàþùåãî âîæäÿ êàðàèáîâ, ïîñëå òîãî êàê îòâåòèë íà ïðèçûâ î ïîìîùè èíäåéöåâ ñ îñòðîâà Ïóýðòî-Ðèêî â èõ áîðüáå ñ èñïàíñêèìè çàõâàò÷èêàìè. Ñ ïåðèîä ñ 1511 ïî 1514 îí íåîäíîêðàòíî ðàçðóøàë èñïàíñêèå ïîñåëåíèÿ è óáèâàë æèòåëåé, òåððîðèçèðóÿ ïîáåðåæüå. Â 1514, Õîðåéýáî îòïðàâèëñÿ ìñòèòü çà ñìåðòü áðàòà, Êàöèìåñà, óáèòîãî ïðèìåðíî çà ãîä äî ýòîãî. Âûñàäèâøèñü ñ äâóìÿ ñîòíÿìè âîèíîâ íà ñåâåðî-âîñòî÷íîì ïîáåðåæüå Ïóýðòî-Ðèêî, Õîðåéýáî íåìåäëåííî íàïàë íà ôåðìû èñïàíöåâ, ñæèãàÿ è óáèâàÿ. Îäèí èç êîíêèñòàäîðîâ, êàïèòàí Ñàí÷î äå Àðàãîí, âçÿâ èìåâøèõñÿ ñîëäàò, âûäâèíóëñÿ, ÷òîáû îñòàíîâèòü åãî, è áûë ðàçáèò íàãîëîâó.[PARAGRAPH:1] Ïîáåäèâ ñïåøíî ñîáðàííûå âîéñêà èñïàíöåâ, Õîðåéýáî îòïëûë íà Ìàëûå Àíòèëüñêèå îñòðîâà, óâîçÿ ñ ñîáîé íàãðàáëåííîå è ïëåííûõ. Åãî ïðåñëåäîâàëè òðè êîðàáëÿ ïîä êîìàíäîâàíèåì ãóáåðíàòîðà Ïóýðòî-Ðèêî, äîíà Êðèñòîáàëÿ äå Ìåíäîçû, è ê çàêàòó äîãíàëè åãî âîçëå îñòðîâà Âüåêåñ, îäíàêî Õîðåéýáî, âìåñòî òîãî ÷òîáû óéòè îò íèõ, ëàâèðóÿ â íàñòóïàþùèõ ñóìåðêàõ âîçëå ïîáåðåæüÿ îñòðîâà, ïðèíÿë áîé. Îí íàïðàâèë ñâîè ëîäêè íà êîðàáëè èñïàíöåâ, ïûòàÿñü âçÿòü èõ íà àáîðäàæ, íî ïîñëå îæåñòî÷åííîé áîðüáû ôëîò èíäåéöåâ áûë ðàçáèò à Õîðåéýáî óáèò.
TEXT.German: [H1]Jaureybo[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Karibischer Cacique[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1465 - 1514[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Wenig ist über das Leben Jaureybos vor seinem Tod bekannt. Man glaubt, dass er in der letzten Hälfte des 15ten Jahrhunderts auf der Insel Guadeloupe geboren wurde.[PARAGRAPH:1] Auf den Ruf der Ureinwohner von Porto Rico hörend, um die spanischen Invasoren abzuwehren, entwickelte Jaureybo sich schnell zum fähigsten Führer der Caribs. Von 1511 bis 1514, störte er die Spanier wiederholt durch überfälle auf spanische Siedlungen. 1514 brach Jaureybo auf um den Tod seinens Bruders Cazimes zu rächen, der durch die Spanier getötet wurde. Er landetet mit einer grossen Kriegstrube an der nordöstlichen Küste von Porto Rico und beagann Spanische Farmen zu überfallen und deren Einwohner zu töten. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nachdem er die schnell zusammengezogenen spärlichen spanischen Truppen, die ihn daran hindern sollten, brach Jaureybo mit seinen Gefangen und seiner Beute in Richtung der Unteren Antillen auf. Dabei wurde er von 3 Schiffen verfolgt, die vom Gouverneur von Porto Rico befehltigt wurden und ihn schliesslich bei Sonnenaufgang in der Nähe der Inseln Vieques stellten. Anstatt im Schutze der Dunkelheit zu fliehen, entschloss er sich zum Kampf und führte seine Kanus, im Versuch diese zu entern, gegen die spanischen Schiffe. Dabei wurde sein Kanu zerstört und Jaureybo starb.

It is believed he was born on the island of Guadeloupe in the last half of the 15th century.[PARAGRAPH:1] Responding to the call from the Indians of Porto Rico to help them fight off the Spanish invaders, Jaureybo, quickly emerged as the Caribs most formidable leader. From 1511 to 1514, he harassed the Spanish repeatedly, raiding their settlements and killing Spanish colonists. In 1514, Jaureybo set out to revenge the death of his brother Cazimes, who had been killed by the Spanish earlier in the year. Landing with a large war-party on the north eastern coast of Porto Rico, Jaureybo quickly set to attacking Spanish farms and killing the inhabitants.[PARAGRAPH:1] Defeating the Spanish force hastily assembled to oppose him, Jaureybo set out for the Lesser Antilles with his prisoners and plunder. He was pursued by three ships commanded by the governor of Porto Rico, who caught up with him by sunset near the island of Vieques. Rather than use the cover of darkness to slip away to the protection of neighboring islands, Jaureybo decided to fight, leading his canoes towards the Spanish ships in an attempt to board them. After a fierce struggle his canoes were destroyed and Jaureybo was killed.

TEXT.English: My name is [OUR_NAME], and I greet you on behalf of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. If you are peaceful, we consider you to be a friend. If you are warlike, we consider you to be food. What is your choice?
TEXT.French: Ìåíÿ çîâóò [OUR_NAME], è ÿ ïðèâåòñòâóåþ âàñ îò èìåíè ëþäåé ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Åñëè âû êàê äðóã, ìû ñòàíåì äðóçüÿìè. Åñëè âû ïðèøëè êàê âðàã, ìû ïðèãîòîâèì îáåä èç âàøèõ òåë.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Carib. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: You want me to speak with you? I'm sorry, I consider it inappropriate to play with my dinner.
TEXT.French: Óõ òû, õî÷åøü, ÷òîáû ÿ ïîãîâîðèë ñ òîáîé? ß íå èãðàþ ñî ñâîèì îáåäîì, ó ìåíÿ íåò âðåìåíè, à òâîè ëþäè áûëè íåìíîãî æåñòêîâàòû, âñå èç-çà òîãî, ÷òî ìû íå óñïåëè âûäåðæàòü èõ â ðó÷üå.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Peace? Never! My men are hungry.
TEXT.French: Êàêîé ìîæåò áûòü ìèð, êîãäà ìû ãîëîäíû?
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the lands of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us discuss our options as friends and dinner companions.
TEXT.French: Äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü íà çåìëè ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Âû ïðèÿòíûé ñîáåñåäíèê è ñîòðàïåçíèê.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Häuptling Jaureybo aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: If it isn't the most unappetizing of my enemies! Have you come solely to annoy us, or is that just an unfortunate side effect?
TEXT.French: Òâîè ëþäè èñêëþ÷èòåëüíî íåâêóñíûå! ß ñúåë âñåãî îäíîãî ÷åëîâåêà, è ó ìåíÿ èçæîãà! Ïðèøëîñü îòïóñòèòü îñòàëüíûõ. Óõîäè, ïîêà ÿ íå ïðèäóìàë, êàê áû òåáÿ ïðèãîòîâèòü!
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe has suffered misfortune and is in need. Will the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: Íåóäà÷è ñûïëþòñÿ íà ìîå ïëåìÿ, è ÿ íå ìîãó ïîìåøàòü ýòîìó, íî êàê âîæäü è ìóæ÷èíà ÿ îáÿçàí ýòî èçìåíèòü. Ìîãóò ëè ëþäè [CT_EMPIRE] ïîìî÷ü íàì?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. Will you turn us away?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøåë ñ ìèðîì è ïðîñüáîé. ×òî âû îòâåòèòå?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: My warriors could destory the [CT_EMPIRE] with ease. Give me all I desire.
TEXT.French: Âîèíû ïëåìåíè [OUR_EMPIRE] ëåãêî ñúåäÿò ïëåìÿ [CT_EMPIRE] íà îáåä, åñëè îíî íå äàñò ÷òî-íèáóäü âçàìåí.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Navajo
TEXT.German: Navajo:Navajo:Navajo

TEXT.English: Navajo
TEXT.German: Navajo

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Navajo (also known as the Dine or Naabeeho), like the Apache, are of Athapaskan descent. Their ancestors migrated from Eastern Alaska and Northwestern Canada, and by 1400 AD, had settled in the American southwest.[PARAGRAPH:1] With the arrival of the Spanish in the southwest, during the 16th century, the Navajo practice of raiding their neighbors steadily increased, aided by the new additions of Spanish horses and guns. As the Spanish missions became more heavy handed, many Pueblo Indians fled to the Navajo, whom the Spanish missionaries had never established much success with, given the Navajo's semi-nomadic nature. Those Pueblo that remained organized a successful resistance to Spanish authority and drove the Spanish away from New Mexico. With the Spanish gone the Navajo turned to increased raids against Pueblo villages. In 1692, the Spanish re-conquered New Mexico, driving some Pueblo Indians again to live with friendly Navajo groups.[PARAGRAPH:1] By the beginning of the 18th century, hostilities between the Spanish and the Pueblo Indians had subsided, leading to many Pueblo families returning to their Pueblo homes, and siding with the Spanish to fight off raids made by the Navajo, Apache and Ute. By the end of the 18th century, many Navajo groups facing increased raids from the Ute's, Comanche's and Apaches, moved their livestock to lands further west. The Navajo continued to engage in a series of sporadic raids and counter- raids, throughout the first half of the 19th century, fighting against not only their Indian neighbors and the Spanish, but later the Mexicans, and finally the United States. This cycle finally culminated in the Long Walk of 1864, when the United States Army forced the Navajo from their lands in what is now Arizona onto a reservation in eastern New Mexico. By 1868, attempts to sustain the reservation had failed and the Navajo were relocated back to their traditional boundaries, being granted 3.5 million acres of land between their four sacred mountains.

In 1692, the Spanish re-conquered New Mexico, driving some Pueblo Indians again to live with friendly Navajo groups.[PARAGRAPH:1] By the beginning of the 18th century, hostilities between the Spanish and the Pueblo Indians had subsided, leading to many Pueblo families returning to their Pueblo homes, and siding with the Spanish to fight off raids made by the Navajo, Apache and Ute. By the end of the 18th century, many Navajo groups facing increased raids from the Ute's, Comanche's and Apaches, moved their livestock to lands further west. The Navajo continued to engage in a series of sporadic raids and counter- raids, throughout the first half of the 19th century, fighting against not only their Indian neighbors and the Spanish, but later the Mexicans, and finally the United States. This cycle finally culminated in the Long Walk of 1864, when the United States Army forced the Navajo from their lands in what is now Arizona onto a reservation in eastern New Mexico. By 1868, attempts to sustain the reservation had failed and the Navajo were relocated back to their traditional boundaries, being granted 3.5 million acres of land between their four sacred mountains.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Navajo (auch als Dine oder Naabeeho bekannt) stammen, wie die Apachen, von den Athapaskan ab. Ihre Vorfahren migrierten um 1400 AD vom östlichen Alaska und nordwestlichen Kanada, in den amerikanischen Südwesten um sich dort niederzulassen.[PARAGRAPH:1] Als die Spanier während des 16ten Jarhunderts in dieser Gegend eintrafen, nahm der Brauch der Navajo ihre Nachbarn zu überfallen stetig, durch die von den Spaniern erworbenen Waffen und Pferde unterstützt, zu. Als die spanischen Missionen ihren Druck erhöhten, flohen viele Pueblo Indianer zu den Navajo, da dort die spanischen Missionen, aufgrund der halbnomadischen Lebensweise der Navajo, nie erfolgreich etabliert werden konnten. Die Pueblo Indianer die zurückblieben organisierten erfolgreich einen Widerstand, der die Spanier wieder aus Neu-Mexiko vertrieb. Als die Spanier verschwunden waren, wurden die Dörfer der Pueblo Indianer jedoch von verstärkten überfällen der Najao heimgesucht. 1692 erorberten die Spanier Neu-Mexiko zurück, was erneut dazu führte das einige Pueblo Indianer zu freundlich gesinnten Najao flohen.[PARAGRAPH:1] Zu Beginn des 18ten Jahrhunderts fanden die Feindseligkeiten zwischen den Spaniern und den Pueblo Indianern ein Ende und viele Pueblo kehrten in ihre Heimatgebiete zurück. Manche kämpften sogar auf deren Seite gegen Navajo, Apachen und Ute Indianer. Zu dieser Zeit sahen sich die Najao auch verstärkten überfällen von Ute Indianern, Commanchen und Apachen ausgesetzt. Die Navajo ihrerseits setzte ebenfalls die überfälle und Gegenangriffe fort. Bis in die erste Hälfte des 19ten Jahrhunderts waren die Navaj fortwährend in Kämpfe mit ihren Indianischen Nachbarn und den Spaniern, dann mit den Mexikanern und letztlich mit den United States, verstrickt. Dies fand schliesslich im sogenanten 'Long Walk' 1864 seinen Höhepunkt als die United States Army die Navajo von ihren angestammten Ländern in ein Reservat im östlichen Neu-Mexiko, heute Arizona, vertrieb. 1868 durften die Najao wieder zurück in ihr altes Gebiet und bekamen 3.5 million Ar Land zwischen ihren vier heiligen Bergen zugesprochen.

As the Spanish missions became more heavy handed, many Pueblo Indians fled to the Navajo, whom the Spanish missionaries had never established much success with, given the Navajo's semi-nomadic nature. Those Pueblo that remained organized a successful resistance to Spanish authority and drove the Spanish away from New Mexico. With the Spanish gone the Navajo turned to increased raids against Pueblo villages. In 1692, the Spanish re-conquered New Mexico, driving some Pueblo Indians again to live with friendly Navajo groups.[PARAGRAPH:1] By the beginning of the 18th century, hostilities between the Spanish and the Pueblo Indians had subsided, leading to many Pueblo families returning to their Pueblo homes, and siding with the Spanish to fight off raids made by the Navajo, Apache and Ute. By the end of the 18th century, many Navajo groups facing increased raids from the Ute's, Comanche's and Apaches, moved their livestock to lands further west. The Navajo continued to engage in a series of sporadic raids and counter- raids, throughout the first half of the 19th century, fighting against not only their Indian neighbors and the Spanish, but later the Mexicans, and finally the United States. This cycle finally culminated in the Long Walk of 1864, when the United States Army forced the Navajo from their lands in what is now Arizona onto a reservation in eastern New Mexico. By 1868, attempts to sustain the reservation had failed and the Navajo were relocated back to their traditional boundaries, being granted 3.5 million acres of land between their four sacred mountains.

TEXT.English: Navajo
TEXT.German: Navajo:Navajo:Navajo:Navajo
TEXT.Italian: Navajo
TEXT.Spanish: Navajo

TEXT.English: Narbona

[H1]Narbona[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Navajo[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1766 - 1849[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Narbona was a Navajo chief who participated in the Navajo Wars. He became one of the most prominent Navajo leaders after the massacre of 24 Navajo leaders in 1822 at Jemez Pueblo. In 1835 he led the Navajo to a decisive victory in an ambush of a Mexican expedition in the Chuska Mountains. The site of the battle, Copper Pass, is now known as Narbona Pass. [PARAGRAPH:1] In 1849, Narbona, with several hundred of his warriors, rode to meet a delegation to discuss peace terms between the Navajo and the Americans who had driven the Mexicans from what is now the Southwestern United States. After several misunderstandings, translators managed to work out terms for peace between the two parties. As the peace council broke up, the Americans accused the Navajo of stealing a horse and demanded its return. The Navajo refused, and the horse and its rider departed. The Americans again demanded the return of the horse, threatening force if their demand was not met. Narbona again denied the request, and the Americans fired upon the Navajo with cannon and rifles. Several Navajo were killed and wounded in the fusillade including a mortally wounded Narbona.
TEXT.French: [H1]Narbona[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Navajo[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1766 - 1849[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Narbona was a Navajo chief who participated in the Navajo Wars. He became one of the most prominent Navajo leaders after the massacre of 24 Navajo leaders in 1822 at Jemez Pueblo. In 1835 he led the Navajo to a decisive victory in an ambush of a Mexican expedition in the Chuska Mountains. The site of the battle, Copper Pass, is now known as Narbona Pass. [PARAGRAPH:1] In 1849, Narbona, with several hundred of his warriors, rode to meet a delegation to discuss peace terms between the Navajo and the Americans who had driven the Mexicans from what is now the Southwestern United States. After several misunderstandings, translators managed to work out terms for peace between the two parties. As the peace council broke up, the Americans accused the Navajo of stealing a horse and demanded its return. The Navajo refused, and the horse and its rider departed. The Americans again demanded the return of the horse, threatening force if their demand was not met. Narbona again denied the request, and the Americans fired upon the Navajo with cannon and rifles. Several Navajo were killed and wounded in the fusillade including a mortally wounded Narbona.
TEXT.German: [H1]Narbona[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Navajo[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1766 - 1849[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Narbona war ein Navajo Häuptling während der Navajo Kriege. Er wurde nach dem Massaker von Jemez Peublo 1822, in welchem 24 anderen Navajo Führer getötet wurden, einer der bekanntesten Führer der Navajo. 1835 war er für einen entscheidenden Sieg der Navajo bei einem Hinterhalt auf eine mexikanische Expedition in den Chuska Mountains verantwortlich. Die Stelle, der Copper Pass, ist auch als Narbona Pass bekannt. [PARAGRAPH:1] 1849 ritt Narbona mit einigen hundert seiner Krieger, um eine Delegation zu treffen, mit der Friedensgespräche zwischen Navajo und Amerikanern stattfinden sollten, die die Mexikaner aus den südwestlichen United States vertrieben hatten. Nach einigen Misverständnissen gelang es den übersetzern die Punkte des Friedensabkommens auszuhandeln. Als die Delegation jedoch aufbrechen wollte, beschuldigten die Amerikaner die Navajo ein Pferd gestohlen zu haben und verlangten dessen Rückgabe. Die Navajo verweigerten dies und Pferd und Reiter flüchteten. Daraufhin drohten die Amerikaner mit Gewalt, falls das Pferd nicht zurückgegeben werden sollte. Narbona wies die Forderung zurück und die Amerikaner eröffneten das Feuer mit Kannonen und Gewehren. Viele Navajo wurden dabei verletzt oder getötet. Narbona selbst erhielt ebenfalls eine tödliche Verletzung.

The Americans again demanded the return of the horse, threatening force if their demand was not met. Narbona again denied the request, and the Americans fired upon the Navajo with cannon and rifles. Several Navajo were killed and wounded in the fusillade including a mortally wounded Narbona.

TEXT.English: Welcome to the hunting grounds of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. I am [OUR_NAME], and I hope the relationship between the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] and the [CT_EMPIRE] will be to the benefits of both. Let us exchange stories of our peoples under the light of the moon.
TEXT.French: Äîáðî ïîæàëîâàòü â çåìëè îõîòû ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ìîå èìÿ [OUR_NAME], è ÿ âîçëàãàþ íàäåæäû íà òî, ÷òî îòíîøåíèÿ ìåæäó ïëåìåíàìè [OUR_CIV_ADJ] è [CT_EMPIRE] ïðèíåñóò ïîëüçó ëþäÿì êàæäîãî èç ýòèõ ïëåìåí. Ïîêà æå ðàññêàæåì äðóã-äðóãó ñóäüáû íàøèõ íàðîäîâ, è íå áåäà, åñëè ðàçãîâîð ïðîäëèòñÿ çà ïîëíî÷ü.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Navjo. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: I'd rather listen to the jabbering of a prairie dog all evening than listen to your words for a minute.
TEXT.French: Ëó÷øå ñëóøàòü òÿâêàíüå øàêàëà âñþ íî÷ü, ÷åì òâîå áîðìîòàíèå!
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: So now you've had some taste of your own blood, you beg for mercy? We will not dishonor you by conceding to your cowardice.
TEXT.French: À, âû îùóòèëè âêóñ ñîáñòâåííîé êðîâè? È ñðàçó æå ìàëîäóøíî ïðèïîëçëè ïðîñèòü ïîùàäû? Âåäèòå ñåáÿ, êàê ïîëîæåíî ìóæ÷èíàì. Óìðèòå, åñëè íåò äðóãîãî âûõîäà.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: I gladly welcome my friends of the [CT_EMPIRE]. What do you desire to discuss with the great warriors of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]?
TEXT.French: ß î÷åíü ðàä âèäåòü äðóçåé èç íàðîäà [CT_EMPIRE]. ×òî âû õîòèòå îáñóäèòü ñ õðàáðûì âîèíîì ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ]?
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Häuptling Narbona aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: My warriors are itching to teach your people the meaning of honor. I advise you to convince me that that wouldn't be necessary, as it would be a messy business.
TEXT.French: Ìîè âîèíû ãîðÿò æåëàíèåì íàó÷èòü òåáÿ ñìûñëó ñëîâà ''õðàáðîñòü''. Íàäåñü, òû ñóìååøü óáåäèòü ìåíÿ, ÷òî â ýòîì íåò íóæäû, ïîòîìó ÷òî öåíîé ýòîãî çíàíèÿ áóäåò òâîÿ æèçíü.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is suffering, will the [CT_EMPIRE] ease our hardship?
TEXT.French: Ìîå ïëåìÿ ñòðàäàåò, ìîæåò ëè íàðîä ïëåìåíè [CT_EMPIRE] ïðîòÿíóòü ðóêó ïîìîùè?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for your assistance. Will you honor your freindship with us?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøåë ñ ìèðîì è, âî èìÿ íàøåé äðóæáû, ïðîøó ïîìîùè.
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I hold the future survival of the [CT_EMPIRE] in my hand. Give me what I demand or die this day.
TEXT.French: Áóäóùåå ïëåìåíè [CT_EMPIRE] â ðóêàõ ìîèõ âîèíîâ. Äàéòå ìíå òî, ÷òî ÿ òðåáóþ, èíà÷å óìðåòå ñåãîäíÿ æå.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Algonquian
TEXT.German: Algonquian:Algonquian:Algonquian

TEXT.English: Algonquian
TEXT.German: Algonquian

TEXT.English: [TAB]Unlike the Algonkin tribe, Algonquian, refers to not one single tribe, but to the Algonquin language or to the group of tribes that speak one of the nearly fifty related dialects.[PARAGRAPH:1] When the Europeans arrived in North America, the Algonquian tribes were the most populous and widely distributed Native American linguistic group, with numerous tribes occupying swaths of territory along the eastern seaboard, the Canadian interior south of the Hudson Bay, and parts of the mid-west and the great lakes. Often engaged in border wars, particularly with English settlements, the Algonquians for a time made a futile struggle for the possession of their territory. Rarely able to form even regional alliances with any endurance or cohesion, Algonquian resistance from Maine to the Carolinas was defeated leaving the remnants of their tribal organizations scattered. Some tribes withdrew to Canada whereas others migrated over the Allegheny mountains into the Ohio valley. Only the Virginia tribes under the rule of Powhatan and Opechancanough, presented a united opposition against the English for several decades until they were eventually overwhelmed and their tribes destroyed or driven to near extinction. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the middle of the 17th century, the Algonquians found themselves facing simultaneous threats to their lands from not only the Europeans, but also from their traditional Iroquoian enemies. After defeating the Huron and the Erie in the 1650's the Iroquois turned their attention to the Algonquians, already weakened by disease and war with the English and Dutch settlements, and drove the Algonquians north to the region of the upper great lakes and westward into Indiana territory. The Algonquians that crossed into Ohio, formed themselves into a loose confederacy with other tribes driven west, allying themselves first with the French and later the English in the hopes of preserving the territory against further white settlement. The tribes in the Ohio valley continued their resistance through and beyond the Revolution, but were eventually defeated in the Northwest Indian War, 1785-95. The Treaty of Greenville in 1795, saw them cede the first of their lands west of the Ohio. Tecumseh tried to revive a united Indian resistance again in 1811, but his death in 1813 all but ended any continued Algonquian opposition. Over the next thirty years the Algonquian tribes signed a series of treaties that in effect led to them ceding most of their remaining lands and moving west of the Mississippi.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Als die Europäer in Nord Amerika eingrafen, waren die Algonquian, die bevölkerungsreichse und am weitesten verbreitete Sprachgruppe der Ureinwohner, die mehrere Stämme an der Ostküste, dem kanadischen Inland und der Gegend um die Hudson Bay einschloss, wie auch Stämme im Mittleren Westen und an den Great Lakes. Die Algonquian waren oft in Grenzkriegen, speziell mit den Engländern verwickelt, jedoch war der Kampf um den Besitz ihres Territoriums letztlich aussichtslos. Kaum fähig eine regionale standhafte und andauernde Allianz zu bilden, wurde der Wiederstand der Algonquian von Maine bis in den Mittleren Westen zerschlagen und lies nur Bruchstücke der Stammesorganisationen zurück. Eine Stämme flohen nach Kanada, andere migrierten über die Allegheny Berge in das Ohio Tal. Nur die Stämme in Virginia unter der Führung von Powhatan und Opechancanough, stellten für einige Dekaden eine verreinte Oppositioon gegen die Engländer bis sie dennoch überweltigt und beinahe ausgelöscht wurden.[PARAGRAPH:1] In der Mitte des 17ten Jahrhunderts, wurde das Land der Algonquians gleichzeitig durch die Europäer und ihre traditionellen Feinde die Irokesen bedroht. Nachdem die Irokesen in den 1650ern die Huron und Erie besiegt hatten wandten sie ihre Aufmerksamkeit den Algonquian zu, die bereits durch Krankheiten und Kriege mit den englischen und holländischen Siedlungen geschwächt waren. Die Irokesen trieben die Algonquians nach Norden in die Region der Oberen Great Lakes und westlich in die Indiana Territorien. Die Algonquian, die den Ohio überschritten, bildeten eine lose Konfödertaion mit anderen Stämmen die nach Westen vertrieben wurden und alliierten sich zuerst mit den Franzosen und später mit den Engländern in der Hoffnung so ihr Territorium for weiterer Besiedelung durch den Weissen Mann zu schützen. Die Stämme im Ohio Tal hielten ihren Wiederstand bis nach der Revolution aufrecht, wurden aber letztlich im Northwest Indian War in den Jahren 1785-95 besiegt. Der Vertrag von Greenville 1795 besiegelte die Aufgabe aller Länder westlich des Ohio. Tecumseh versuchte den indianischen Wiederstand 1811 wiederzubeleben, aber sein Tod 1813 beendete alle Opposition der Algonquian. In den nächsten 30 Jahren unterzeichneten die Algonquian eine Reihe von Verträgen, die schrittweise zur Abtretung der meisten verbliebenen Territorien und zur Zurückdrängung westlich des Mississippi führten.

TEXT.English: Oppussoquionuske

[H1]Oppussoquionuske[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Weroansqua of the Appomattoc[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1580 - 1611[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Oppussoquionuske, with her brother Coquonasum, co-led the Appomattoc Indians, one of the many tribes that were governed under the larger Powhatan Confederacy during the time the English first landed in Virginia. The Appomattoc first encountered the English in May 1607, and despite initially welcoming the Europeans, they soon along with other neighboring tribes were making sporadic raids against the English until Chief Powhatan ordered a ceasefire. [PARAGRAPH:1] By 1609, relations between the English and the Powhatan had greatly deteriorated, resulting in the First Anglo-Powhatan War, 1610-1611. Ever short of food, and unable to grow it for themselves, the English sent out parties to either trade for or raid food from the local Indian tribes. In the fall of 1610, Oppussoquionuske took advantage of this weakness and invited an English trading party to her village, killing all but one of the party in an ambush. In reprisal for the attack, the English under Sir Thomas Dale, raided the Appomattoc around Christmas 1611. Oppussoquionuske's village was seized and burnt to the ground, and Oppussoquinuske who was mortally wounded in the attack died shortly afterwards. Dale renamed the site of the former Appomattoc village New Bermuda, and the settlement of Bermuda Hundred was incorporated there in 1614.

The Appomattoc first encountered the English in May 1607, and despite initially welcoming the Europeans, they soon along with other neighboring tribes were making sporadic raids against the English until Chief Powhatan ordered a ceasefire. [PARAGRAPH:1] By 1609, relations between the English and the Powhatan had greatly deteriorated, resulting in the First Anglo-Powhatan War, 1610-1611. Ever short of food, and unable to grow it for themselves, the English sent out parties to either trade for or raid food from the local Indian tribes. Oppussoquionuske's village was seized and burnt to the ground, and Oppussoquinuske who was mortally wounded in the attack died shortly afterwards. Dale renamed the site of the former Appomattoc village New Bermuda, and the settlement of Bermuda Hundred was incorporated there in 1614.
TEXT.German: [H1]Oppussoquionuske[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Weroansqua der Appomattoc[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1580 - 1611[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Oppussoquionuske führte zusammen mit ihrem Bruder Coquonasum die Appomattoc, einer von vielen Stämmen, die in der grossen Powhatan Konföderation vereinigt waren, als die Engländer in Virginia landeten. Die Appomattoc trafen zum ersten Mal im Mai 1607 auf die Engländer und obwohl sie diese anfangs Willkommen hiessen, begannen sie bald zusammen mit anderen benachbarten Stämmen mit sporadischen überfällen auf die Engländer, bis Häuptling Powhatan eine Waffenruhe befahl. [PARAGRAPH:1] Bis 1609, hatten die Beziehungen zwischen den Engländern und der Powathan Konföderation starken Schaden genommen, was 1610-1611 zum ersten Anglo-Powhatan Krieg führte. Knapp an Essen und unfähig Nahrung selber ausreichend anzubauen, entsandten die Engländer Gruppen um entweder um Nahrung zu handeln oder dies von den lokalen Stämmen zu rauben. Im Herbst 1610 nutzte Oppussoquionuske diese Schwäche aus und lud eine englische Handelsgesandschaft in ihr Dorf ein und tötete in einem Hinterhalt alle bis auf einen einzigen Mann. Als Rache für diesen Angriff überfielen wiederum die Engländer unter Sir Thomas Dale die Appomattoc im Winter 1611. Oppussoquionuskes Dorf wurde vollständig niedergebrannt und Oppussoquinuske selbst während des Angriffs tödlich verwundet, wodurch sie kurz danach auch starb. Dale benannte die Stätte der früheren Appomattoc Siedlung in New Bermuda um und 1614 wurde dort die Siedlung Bermuda Hundred gegründet.

TEXT.English: Hello. My name is [OUR_NAME], and I speak on behalf of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] tribes. We gladly welcome you to our lands, and we hope we can grow to be friends and trading partners. Join me in my longhouse and tell me about your strange customs.
TEXT.French: Ïðèâåòñòâóþ. Ìîå èìÿ [OUR_NAME], ÿ ãîâîðþ îò èìåíè ïëåìåí [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ìû ñ óâàæåíèåì ïðèâåòñòâóåì âàø íàðîä íà íàøèõ çåìëÿõ, è ïîëíû íàäåæä, ÷òî îáðåòåì â âàøåì ëèöå õîðîøèõ äðóçåé. Ïðîøó, ðàññêàæèòå î âàøèõ îáû÷àÿõ è òðàäèöèÿõ.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Algonquian. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: I have nothing to discuss with you. Be on your way, and prepare to pay the price for your atrocities against the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people.
TEXT.French: Ñ òîáîé íå î ÷åì ãîâîðèòü. Ó òåáÿ ñâîé ïóòü, è ýòî ïóòü ñìåðòè. Ãîòîâüñÿ çàïëàòèòü çà çâåðñòâà, ïðè÷èíåííûå ëþäÿì [OUR_CIV_ADJ].
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: A treaty? One of those things the [CT_CIV_ADJ] love to break whenever they feel like it? In your dreams!
TEXT.French: Äîãîâîðåííîñòè? Íó êîíå÷íî, ýòî òî, î ÷åì íàðîä [CT_CIV_ADJ] çàáûâàåò, êîãäà èì ýòî âûãîäíî. Çàïèøèòå èõ ñïåðâà íà áóìàãå, ñêðåïèòå áîëüøèìè ïå÷àòÿìè, à çàòåì ó âàñ áóäåò âðåìÿ ÷òîáû ïîíÿòü, ÷òî ñäåëàòü!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The honorable people of the [CT_EMPIRE] are always welcome in the woods of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Come to my longhouse and let us speak of our friendship.
TEXT.French: ×åñòíûõ ëþäåé ïëåìåíè [CT_EMPIRE] âñåãäà ðàäû âèäåòü â ëåñàõ [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ïðîøó â äëèííûé äîì, êîòîðûé ñëóæèò íàì ìåñòîì ïåðåãîâîðîâ è äðóæáû.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Oppussoquionuske aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Your people have beat the drum that will lead to war. If you wish to avoid your destruction, then now is the time to avert bloodshed and explain yourself.
TEXT.French: Ñëîâà òâîèõ ëþäåé ïîäîáíû êîëîòóøêå, óäàðÿþùåé â áàðàáàí, è èõ çâó÷àíèå âîçâåùàåò âîéíó. Åñëè íå õî÷åøü, ÷òîáû òåáÿ óæå çàâòðà ñìåëè ìîè âîèíû, îáúÿñíè, çà÷åì ïðèøåë.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My people suffer from much hardship and are in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] stay true to their friendship with us and help?
TEXT.French: Ìîè ëþäè çàäûõàþòñÿ ïîä ãíåòîì òÿæåëûõ èñïûòàíèé, è òåðïÿò ëèøåíèÿ, ïîñëàííûå Âåëèêèì Äóõîì. Ìîæåò ëè ïëåìÿ [CT_EMPIRE] ïðîòÿíóòü ðóêó ïîìîùè?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for your assistance. Will you prove a loyal brother and friend?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøëà ñ ìèðîì ïðîñèòü î ïîìîùè, è âåðþ, ÷òî âû ïðîÿâèòå ñåáÿ êàê áðàò è äðóã.
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: My warriors tomahawks are bright. If I willed it, they could soon be red with the blood of the [CT_EMPIRE]. If you wish to save you seed in this land, then you will yield to my demands.
TEXT.French: Òîïîðû ìîèõ âîèíîâ ÿðêî ñâåðêàþò, íî, åñëè ÿ ïîæåëàþ, îíè ñòàíóò êðàñíûìè îò êðîâè ëþäåé ïëåìåíè [CT_EMPIRE]. Åñëè âû õîòèòå æèòü â ýòèõ çåìëÿõ, âû äîëæíû âûïîëíèòü ìîè òðåáîâàíèÿ.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Machiparo
TEXT.German: Machiparo:Machiparo:Machiparo

TEXT.English: Machiparo
TEXT.German: Machiparo

TEXT.English: [TAB]The first significant reports of the Machiparo, were recorded by Gaspar de Carvajal, a Dominican priest who accompanied Francisco de Orellana's 1542 expedition that traversed the Amazon River. Carvajal reported a populous, organized society whose control extended hundreds of miles along the river, though wrote very little about the people of the Amazon, mostly because they were always trying to kill him. Orellana's party received a cold reception on the Amazon from the Machipara and then the Omagua's, who attacked the Spanish incessantly, killing and wounding several. In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, 1542, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception from the Machipara that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Machipara, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The first significant reports of the Machiparo, were recorded by Gaspar de Carvajal, a Dominican priest who accompanied Francisco de Orellana's 1542 expedition that traversed the Amazon River. Carvajal reported a populous, organized society whose control extended hundreds of miles along the river, though wrote very little about the people of the Amazon, mostly because they were always trying to kill him. Orellana's party received a cold reception on the Amazon from the Machipara and then the Omagua's, who attacked the Spanish incessantly, killing and wounding several. In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, 1542, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception from the Machipara that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Machipara, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die ersten nennenswerten Berichte über die Machiparo wurden von Gaspar de Carvajal aufgezeichnet. Er war ein dominikanischer Priester, der 1542 die Expedition von Francisco de Orellana entlang des Amazonas begleitete. Carvajal berichtete von einer bevölkerungsreichen und organisierten Gesellschaft, die hunderte von Meilen entlang des Amazonas kontrollierte, schrieb jedoch sehr wenig über die Menschen des Amazonas selbst, was hauptsächlich daran lag, dass diese versuchten ihn zu töten. Orellanas Gruppe erhielt einen eisigen Empfang durch die Machipara und später durch die Omagua, die unaufhörlich die Spanier angriffenund viele töteten oder verwundeten. Um Vorräte zu erhalten befahl Orellana seinen Männern in seiner Verzweiflung die Dörfer dieser Ureinwohner anzugreifen. Am 21. Mai 1542 passierte Orellana den Mündung des Madeira und lies die Machipara und Omagua Gebiete hinter sich. Orellana starb 1546 bei seiner zweiten Reise in den Amazonas.[PARAGRAPH:1] Pedro de Ursua, der Geschichten über den Reichtum der Omagua gehört hatte, führte 1560 eine weitere Expedition entlang des Amazonas. Die Machipara empfingen ihn auf die selbe Art, wie Orellana 20 Jahre zuvor. Ausser Gerüchten über die mystische Stadt El Dorado fand er nichts.[PARAGRAPH:1] Im 16ten und 17ten Jahrhundert führte Krankheiten, die durch die Europäer eingeschleppt worden waren zu einem Bevölkerungskollaps unter den Machipara, worauf diese ihre Städte verliesen, in den Regenwald flohen und einen nomadischen Lebensstil annahmen.

In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, 1542, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception from the Machipara that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Machipara, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.

TEXT.English: Machiparo
TEXT.German: Machiparo:Machiparo:Machiparo:Machiparo
TEXT.Italian: Machiparo
TEXT.Spanish: Machiparo

TEXT.English: Machipara

[H1]Machipara[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Machiparo[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]early -mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Little is known of any individual Machiparo cacique. The expeditions of Orellana and Ursua, rarely mentioned the names of native individuals, and when they did they often confused the name of the tribe with that of the village and its leader. Thus the leader of the Machiparo is often referred to as Machipara. [PARAGRAPH:1] What is known is that Machipara ordered several waves of attacks against the Spanish under Orellana in an attempt to wear the Spanish down and defeat them. His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. Twenty years later the expedition of Ursua was met with similar hostility, forcing a second wave of Spanish to quickly leave Machiparo territory. Whether or not Machipara was still alive to order these attacks is unknown.
TEXT.French: [H1]Machipara[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Machiparo[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]early -mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Little is known of any individual Machiparo cacique. [PARAGRAPH:1] What is known is that Machipara ordered several waves of attacks against the Spanish under Orellana in an attempt to wear the Spanish down and defeat them. His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. Twenty years later the expedition of Ursua was met with similar hostility, forcing a second wave of Spanish to quickly leave Machiparo territory. Whether or not Machipara was still alive to order these attacks is unknown.
TEXT.German: [H1]Machipara[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique der Machiparo[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]Mitte des 16ten Jahrhunderts[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Wenig ist über einzelne Cacique der Machiparo bekannt. Die Expeditionen von Orellana und Ursua, nannten kaum Namen einzelner Individuen, und falls doch wurden oft Namen von Stämmen mit Ortschaften oder deren Anführern durcheinander gebracht. Daher wird der Anführer der Machiparo oft als Machipara bezeichnet. [PARAGRAPH:1] Es ist jedoch bekannt, dass der Machipara mehrere Angriffswellen gegen die Spanier unter Orellana befahl, um die Spanier aufzureiben und letztlich zu besiegen. Seine Anstrengungen waren nicht erfolgreich aber die fortwährende Aggression war genug, um die Orellana zu überzeugen schnellstmöglich das Territorium zu durchqueren. Auch die Expedition unter Ursua 20 Jahre später war gezwungen das Gebiet der Machipara schnell wieder zu verlassen. Ob Machipara zu dieser Zeit noch lebte um auch diese Angriffe zu befehligen ist unbekannt.

TEXT.English: I, [OUR_NAME], cacique of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people, offer my friendship to the strangers with the pale complexions and the hair-covered chins. If you are friendly, the forests of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] will be a haven to you. But if you are traitorous, our poisonous blowdarts will not err in piercing your throats.
TEXT.French: ß, [OUR_NAME], êàñèê ëþäåé [OUR_CIV_ADJ], ïðåäëàãàþ ñâîþ äðóæáó. Åñëè âû äðóã, òî ëåñà ïëåìåíè [OUR_CIV_ADJ] ñòàíóò äëÿ âàñ íåáîì. Åñëè æå âû âû ïðèøëè ñî çëûìè íàìåðåíèÿìè, ÿäîâèòûå äðîòèêè ïðîíçÿò âàì ãîðëî.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Machiparo. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Go away. Your words are a poison fouler than the poison of the frogs we dip our arrows in.
TEXT.French: Óõîäè. Òâîè ñëîâà ýòî ÿä, à îò òåáÿ âîíÿåò õóæå, ÷åì îò ïðîòóõøåé ëÿãóøêè.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: We can only have peace after the gods of the jungle are sated with your blood!
TEXT.French: Òîïè äæóíãëåé âïèòàþò âñþ êðîâü, ÷òî âûëüåòñÿ èç òâîèõ âîèíîâ!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: If it isn't my good friend [CT_NAME]! Let us discuss matters of gravity under the enjoyment of the rainforest's bounty.
TEXT.French: Äà ýòî æå ìîé äðóã, [CT_NAME]! ß ñ ðàäîñòüþ îáñóæó ñ òîáîé äàæå âîïðîñû ãðàâèòàöèè!.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Machipara aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: The wise men of our tribes informed me that the rain gods plan to wash your nation off the face of the earth for your disrespect. Are you here to redeem yourself, or do you wish to anger them even further?
TEXT.French: Íåäàâíî øàìàí ñêàçàë ìíå, ÷òî áîãè äîæäÿ ñìîþò òâîå ïëåìÿ ñ îêåàí çà íåóâàæåíèå ê äæóíãëÿì. Òû õî÷åøü èñêóïèòü ñâîþ âèíó ïåðåä íèìè, èëè ïðîäîëæèøü ÿðîñòíî ïëåâàòü ÿäîì âî âñå âîêðóã?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in great need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] show their generosity and help?
TEXT.French: Ìîå ïëåìÿ â áîëüøîé íóæäå, ìîæåò ëè [CT_EMPIRE] ïîìî÷ü íàì?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for your help. Will your words of friendship be proven true?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøåë ñ ìèðîì, ïðîñèòü î ïîìîùè. Åñëè âû äðóçüÿ, òî âû æå íå îòêàæåòå íàì?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: On my command, my warriors are ready to destroy the [CT_EMPIRE]. Save yourselves and give me what I demand.
TEXT.French: Ìîè âîèíû ãîòîâû óíè÷òîæèòü æàëêîå ïëåìÿ [CT_EMPIRE]. Ñïàñèòå ñåáÿ, îòäàéòå òî, ÷òî ÿ òðåáóþ.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Mixtec
TEXT.German: Mixtec:Mixtec:Mixtec

TEXT.English: Mixtec
TEXT.German: Mixtec

TEXT.English: [TAB]The term Mixtec comes from the Nahuatl word mixtecah, meaning cloud people. Before the arrival of Europeans, the Mixtec were one of the most prominent civilizations in Mesoamerica, known for their proficient buildings, a renowned knowledge of astronomy, and being one of the finest goldsmiths in the Americas. Migrating into the Oaxaca valley, the Mixtec came into contact with the aged Zapotec civilization, rebuilding many abandoned Zapotec cities. In a long and sporadic war the Mixtec gradually wrestled control of the Oaxaca valley from the Zapotec. However, their conquest of the Central Valleys was interrupted in the 14th and 15th centuries by the emergence and increasing dominance of the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Mixtec and Zapotec both allied themselves against the Aztecs, however the alliance was an uneasy one and after the Zapotec made a separate peace with the Aztec, the Mixtec were left to fight the Aztec alone, finally being defeated the Aztecs in 1494. Yet the vast distance of Mixtec territory from Aztec capital ensured that not all Mixtec towns fell under Aztec control. After the fall of the Aztec empire the Mixtec fought the Spanish to a standstill, but were eventually defeated by the Zapotec when they allied with the Spanish.

Migrating into the Oaxaca valley, the Mixtec came into contact with the aged Zapotec civilization, rebuilding many abandoned Zapotec cities. In a long and sporadic war the Mixtec gradually wrestled control of the Oaxaca valley from the Zapotec. However, their conquest of the Central Valleys was interrupted in the 14th and 15th centuries by the emergence and increasing dominance of the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Mixtec and Zapotec both allied themselves against the Aztecs, however the alliance was an uneasy one and after the Zapotec made a separate peace with the Aztec, the Mixtec were left to fight the Aztec alone, finally being defeated the Aztecs in 1494. Yet the vast distance of Mixtec territory from Aztec capital ensured that not all Mixtec towns fell under Aztec control. After the fall of the Aztec empire the Mixtec fought the Spanish to a standstill, but were eventually defeated by the Zapotec when they allied with the Spanish.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff Mixtec stammt von dem Nahuatl Wort 'mixtecah' ab, welches 'Wolkenvok' bedeutet. Vor der Ankunft der Europäer, waren die Mixtec eine der bekannteste Zivilisatione in Mittelamerika, aufgrund ihrer fortschrittlichen Gebäude, weitreichendem Wissen in der Astronomie und ihrer feinen Goldschmiedearbeiten. Durch Migration in das Oaxca Tal begegneten die Mixtec der alten Zapotec Zivilisation und bauten viele verlassene Städte der Zapotec wieder auf. In einem lang andauernden Kampf erlangten die Mixtec schrittweise die Kontrolle über das Oaxca Tal von den Zapotec. Jedoch wurde ihre Eroberung der zetralen Täler im 14ten und 15ten Jahrhundert durch die wachsende Dominanz der Azteken verhindert. [PARAGRAPH:1] Die Mixtec und Zapotec verbündeten sich gegen die Azteken, jedoch war die Allianz brüchig und nachdem die Zapotec einen separaten Frieden mit den Azteken schlossen, mussten die Mixtec die Azteken alleine bekämpfen und wurden letzlich 1494 von den Azteken besiegt. Jedoch fielen nicht alle Mixtec Territorien unter die Kontrolle der Azteken, weil die Distanz zur Haupstadt der Azteken sehr gross war. Nach dem Untergang des Imperiums der Azteken bekämpften die Mixtec die Spanier bis zu einem Stillstand, wurden dann jedoch durch die Zapotec besiegt, nach dem diese ein Bündniss mit den Spaniern eingingen.

Migrating into the Oaxaca valley, the Mixtec came into contact with the aged Zapotec civilization, rebuilding many abandoned Zapotec cities. In a long and sporadic war the Mixtec gradually wrestled control of the Oaxaca valley from the Zapotec. However, their conquest of the Central Valleys was interrupted in the 14th and 15th centuries by the emergence and increasing dominance of the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Mixtec and Zapotec both allied themselves against the Aztecs, however the alliance was an uneasy one and after the Zapotec made a separate peace with the Aztec, the Mixtec were left to fight the Aztec alone, finally being defeated the Aztecs in 1494. Yet the vast distance of Mixtec territory from Aztec capital ensured that not all Mixtec towns fell under Aztec control. After the fall of the Aztec empire the Mixtec fought the Spanish to a standstill, but were eventually defeated by the Zapotec when they allied with the Spanish.

[PARAGRAPH:1] The Mixtec and Zapotec both allied themselves against the Aztecs, however the alliance was an uneasy one and after the Zapotec made a separate peace with the Aztec, the Mixtec were left to fight the Aztec alone, finally being defeated the Aztecs in 1494. TEXT.English: Serpent Quechquemitl

[H1]Serpent Quechquemitl[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen of the Xaltepec Mixtec[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1073-1101[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Serpent Quechquemitl is one of the last Mixtec warrior queens documented in the Mixtec codices that escaped destruction by the Spanish. She was also known as Lady Six Monkey, which refers to her day of birth within the 260-day Aztec calendar, which cycled through 13 numbers and 20 various signs. Lady Six Monkey became heir of Xaltepec after a dynastic struggle for power, which resulted in the deaths of several elder siblings. The crisis impelled her to seek guidance from the priestess of the Death Cave (Huahi Cahi) in Chalcatongo. The priestess, Lady Nine Grass, instructed her to marry Lord Eleven Wind, heir to the Xipe Bundle, a marriage which would secure both of their monarchial claims. On the way to her husband's town, her party passed through the settlements of Mountain of the Moon and Mountain of the Insect (probably Yucu Yoo-Tiyuqh). There her ambassadors were insulted with the words "knife, knife," which in Mixtec usually meant a curse or threat. Lady Six Monkey used these words as a pretext for declaring war and launched an attack, leaving both settlements in flames. She captured the offending princes and sacrificed them. Following her military victory, her name was changed from "Serpent Quechquemitl" to "War Quechquemitl." She had two children, Lord Four Wind, who became the ruler of Town of Flints (Ñuu Yuchi), and Lord One Lizard, who was her successor in Xaltepec. In 1101 her archrival, the great Mixtec warchief, Lord Eight Deer, attacked the town of Xipe Bundle and killed both Lady Six Monkey and her husband. Lord Eight Deer himself was eventually captured and sacrificed in 1115 by Lady Six Monkey's son, Lord Four Wind.
TEXT.French: [H1]Serpent Quechquemitl[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen of the Xaltepec Mixtec[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1073-1101[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Serpent Quechquemitl is one of the last Mixtec warrior queens documented in the Mixtec codices that escaped destruction by the Spanish. She was also known as Lady Six Monkey, which refers to her day of birth within the 260-day Aztec calendar, which cycled through 13 numbers and 20 various signs. Lady Six Monkey became heir of Xaltepec after a dynastic struggle for power, which resulted in the deaths of several elder siblings. The crisis impelled her to seek guidance from the priestess of the Death Cave (Huahi Cahi) in Chalcatongo. The priestess, Lady Nine Grass, instructed her to marry Lord Eleven Wind, heir to the Xipe Bundle, a marriage which would secure both of their monarchial claims. On the way to her husband's town, her party passed through the settlements of Mountain of the Moon and Mountain of the Insect (probably Yucu Yoo-Tiyuqh). Following her military victory, her name was changed from "Serpent Quechquemitl" to "War Quechquemitl." She had two children, Lord Four Wind, who became the ruler of Town of Flints (Ñuu Yuchi), and Lord One Lizard, who was her successor in Xaltepec. In 1101 her archrival, the great Mixtec warchief, Lord Eight Deer, attacked the town of Xipe Bundle and killed both Lady Six Monkey and her husband. Lord Eight Deer himself was eventually captured and sacrificed in 1115 by Lady Six Monkey's son, Lord Four Wind.
TEXT.German: [H1]Serpent Quechquemitl[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Königin der Xaltepec Mixtec[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1073-1101[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Serpent Quechquemitl ist eine der letzten Mixtec Kriegerköniginnen, die in den Kodizes der Mixctec aufgezeichnet wurden, die der Vernichtung durch die Spanier entgingen. Sie war auch unter dem Namen 'Herrin Sechs Affen' bekannt, was sich auf den Tag ihrer Geburt im 260-Tage-Kalender der Azteken bezieht. Sie wurde Führerin der Xaltepec nachdem sie in einem Dynastiekonflikt um die Macht als Siegerin hervorging, der den Tod mehrere älterer Geschwister zur Folge hatte. Die Krise zwang sie bei einer Priesterin der Todeshöhlen (Huahi Cahi) in Chalcatongo um Rat zu suchen. Die Priesterin, 'Herrin Neun Gräser' instruierte sie den 'Herrn Elf Winde" zu heiraten, der Erbe von Xipe Bundle war, um die Herrschaftsansprüche beider Parteien zu sichern. Auf dem Weg in die Stadt ihres Ehemannes, passierte ihre Gruppe die Dörfer 'Berg des Mondes' und 'Berg des Insekts' (wahrscheinlich Yucu Yoo-Tiyuqh). Dort wurden sie mit den Worten 'Messer, Messer' empfangen, was in der Sprache der Mixtec eine Verwünschung darstellte. 'Herrin Sechs Affen' griff daraufhin die Siedlungen an und lies sie brennend zurück. Die verantwortliche Prinzessin wurde gefangen und den Göttern geopfert. Nach diesem militärischen Sieg änderte sie ihren Namen von "Serpent Quechquemitl" in "War Quechquemitl." Sie hatte zwei Kinder, 'Herr Vier Winde', der Herrscher über die Stadt Nuu Yuchi wurde, und 'Herr Eine Eidechse', der ihr Nachfolger als Herrscher über die Xaltepec wurde. 1101 griff ihr Erzfeind, der Mixtec Kriegshäuptling 'Herr Acht Rehe' die Stadt Xipe Bundle und tötete sie und ihren Ehemann. 'Herr Acht Rehe' selbst wurde später durch ihren Sohn 'Herr Vier Winde' gefangen und 1115 den Göttern geopfert.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Serpent Quechquemitl[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen of the Xaltepec Mixtec[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1073-1101[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Serpent Quechquemitl is one of the last Mixtec warrior queens documented in the Mixtec codices that escaped destruction by the Spanish. She was also known as Lady Six Monkey, which refers to her day of birth within the 260-day Aztec calendar, which cycled through 13 numbers and 20 various signs. Lady Six Monkey became heir of Xaltepec after a dynastic struggle for power, which resulted in the deaths of several elder siblings. The crisis impelled her to seek guidance from the priestess of the Death Cave (Huahi Cahi) in Chalcatongo. The priestess, Lady Nine Grass, instructed her to marry Lord Eleven Wind, heir to the Xipe Bundle, a marriage which would secure both of their monarchial claims. On the way to her husband's town, her party passed through the settlements of Mountain of the Moon and Mountain of the Insect (probably Yucu Yoo-Tiyuqh). There her ambassadors were insulted with the words "knife, knife," which in Mixtec usually meant a curse or threat. Lady Six Monkey used these words as a pretext for declaring war and launched an attack, leaving both settlements in flames. She captured the offending princes and sacrificed them. Following her military victory, her name was changed from "Serpent Quechquemitl" to "War Quechquemitl." She had two children, Lord Four Wind, who became the ruler of Town of Flints (Ñuu Yuchi), and Lord One Lizard, who was her successor in Xaltepec. In 1101 her archrival, the great Mixtec warchief, Lord Eight Deer, attacked the town of Xipe Bundle and killed both Lady Six Monkey and her husband. Lord Eight Deer himself was eventually captured and sacrificed in 1115 by Lady Six Monkey's son, Lord Four Wind.

In 1101 her archrival, the great Mixtec warchief, Lord Eight Deer, attacked the town of Xipe Bundle and killed both Lady Six Monkey and her husband. Lord Eight Deer himself was eventually captured and sacrificed in 1115 by Lady Six Monkey's son, Lord Four Wind.

TEXT.English: My name is [OUR_NAME], and I bid you welcome to the great empire of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. I expect that your presence here will beneficial to the interests of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. If not, expect to expire either on the battlefield or on the tops of our glorious pyramid temples.
TEXT.French: Ìîå èìÿ [OUR_NAME], ÿ ñ óâàæåíèåì ïðèâåòñòâóþ òåáÿ íà çàìëÿõ [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. ß îæèäàþ, ÷òî âàøå ïðèñóòñòâèå íà çåìëÿõ [OUR_CIV_ADJ] ïîéäåò íàì íà ïîëüçó. Åñëè æå íåò, âû áóäåòå áèòüñÿ ñ íàìè íàñìåðòü, à ñàìûå íåóäà÷ëèâûå áóäóò ïðèíåñåíû â æåðòâó íà âåðøèíå îäíîé èç ïèðàìèä âî ñëàâó Êîñèõî-Ïèòàî.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Mixtec. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: I have no words to waste on a barbaric people such as yours.
TEXT.French: ß íå áóäó òðàòèòü ñëîâ íà äóðàêà âðîäå òåáÿ.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: You have an urgent appointment with the gods of the underworld. Who am I to delay you?
TEXT.French: Æðåö ñêàçàë ìíå, ÷òî Òåñêàòëèïîêà óæå æäåò òåáÿ. Íîæ íàòî÷åí, àëòàðü ãîòîâ, ïðèìè ñâîþ ñìåðòü!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: I, [OUR_NAME], welcome you to my palace. Let us discuss how the gods have strengthened our nations and ruined our enemies.
TEXT.French: ß, [OUR_NAME], ñ óâàæåíèåì ïðèãëàøàþ òåáÿ â ìîé äâîðåö. Ïîãîâîðèì î òîì, êàê óñèëèòü íàøè íàðîäû è ñîêðóøèòü âðàãîâ.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Serpent Quechquemitl aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Your thuggish actions have greatly angered the gods. But because my patience and empathy extend even to the likes of you, I am willing to listen to your pleas for forgiveness and your promises to make amends.
TEXT.French: Òâîè ðàçáîéíèêè íàñòîëüêî ðàçîçëèëè Ïèòàî-Øîî, ÷òî îí òðÿñåò çåìëè, ïî êîòîðûì îíè øëè. Íî ÿ òåðïåëèâ è ñî÷óâñòâóþ òåáå, ÿ ãîòîâ âûñëóøàòü òâîè ìîëüáû î ñïàñåíèè.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: Our people are in great need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] deliver us from our hardship?
TEXT.French: Ìû â âåëèêîé íóæäå è ñòðàäàåì, ìîæåò ëè íàðîä [CT_EMPIRE] ïîìî÷ü íàì, ÷òîáû íàøà íîøà íå áûëà òàê òÿæåëà?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for your help. What do you say?
TEXT.French: ß ïðèøëà ñ ìèðîì ïðîñèòü î ïîìîùè. Êàêîâ âàø îòâåò?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: The [CT_EMPIRE] is weak. I could destroy you at will. Give me what I demand and I may spare you.
TEXT.French: Íàðîä [CT_EMPIRE] ñëàá, ÿ ñîêðóøó åãî, åñëè ïîæåëàþ. Åñëè îí îòäàñò íàì ñâîå, ÿ ïîçâîëþ åìó æèòü.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Muisca
TEXT.German: Muisca:Muisca:Muisca

TEXT.English: Muisca
TEXT.German: Muisca

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Muisca are the Chibca-speaking peoples that inhabited the central highlands of present-day Columbia. The Muisca were the third largest indigenous group in America, although they were not a united people. The majority of power was divided between two confederations, the Hunza, of the northern highland area, whose ruler was known as the Zaque; and the Bacatá of the southern highland area, whose ruler was known as the Zipa. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Hunza and Bacata were regularly at war with one another, with each continually enlisting the loyalty and support of neighboring city states against the other. When the Spanish arrived in 1537, the Hunza and Bacatá both tried to use the Spanish in the same way, hoping that a war between the Spanish and one confederation would leave both combatants weakened enough for the remaining confederation to take power and establish a single Muisca political state. However, the Spanish quickly took advantage of the Muisca rivalry, and killed the last Muisca sovereigns, Sagipa and Aquiminzaque. In 1542 the Spanish put down the last Muisca resistance and the territories of both Confederations were included in a new Colonial Spanish political division named Nuevo Reino de Granada. [PARAGRAPH:1]The origin of the legend of El Dorado -gilded person- may have be located in the Muisca Confederation. The Zaque and the Zipa would often cover themselves in gold when offering tributes and other treasure to their gods, a practice that was well known outside of the confederation as far off as the Caribbean. The Spanish were attracted by such stories of gold, and eventually the legend grew to represent a mythical city of gold.

In 1542 the Spanish put down the last Muisca resistance and the territories of both Confederations were included in a new Colonial Spanish political division named Nuevo Reino de Granada. [PARAGRAPH:1]The origin of the legend of El Dorado -gilded person- may have be located in the Muisca Confederation. The Spanish were attracted by such stories of gold, and eventually the legend grew to represent a mythical city of gold.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Muisca sind ein Chibca-sprchendes Volk, welches die zentralen Hochlande des heutigen Kolumbien bewohnte. Sie waren die dritt grösste gruppe von Ureinwohnern in Amerika, allerdings keint vereintes Volk. Die meiste Macht war zwischen zwei Konföderationen aufgeteilt, den Hunza im Norden, deren Anführer als Zaque bekannt war, und die Bacata im Süden, deren Anführer als Zipa bekannt war. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Hunza und Bacata waren regelmässig miteinander im Krieg. Loyalität und Unterstützung von benachbarten Stadtstaaten wechselte oft die Seiten. Als die Spanier 1537 eintrafen, versuchte sowohl die Hunza, wie auch die Bacata diese auf die selbe Art und Weise einzusetzen und hofften, dass ein Konflikt mit den Spaniern die Gegenseite geschwächt genug zurücklassen würde um es der verbliebenen Seite zu erlauben die gesamte Macht zu übernehmen und einen vereinten Muisca Staat zu schaffen. Die Spanier zogen jedoch schnell ihre eigenen Vorteile aus der Rivalität der Musica und töteten die letzten Herrscher der Musisca, Sagipa und Aquiminzaque. 1542 rangen die Spanier den letzten Muisca Wiederstand nieder und die Territorien beider Konföderationen wurden unter dem Namen 'Nuevo Reino de Granada' Teil des spanischen Kolonialreiches. [PARAGRAPH:1]Der Ursprung der El Dorado legende könnte in der Muisca Konföderation begründet sein. Sowohl der Zaque, wie auch der Zipa, bedeckten sich oft mit Gold um ihren Götter Tribute und Schätze anzubieten. Dies war auch ausserhalb der Konföderationen, sogar bis in die Karibik, wohl bekannt. Die Spanier wurden natürlich von solchen Geschichten von Gold und Reichtum angezogen und irgendwann wuchs diese Geschichte zu der Legende der msystischen Stadt aus Gold.

TEXT.English: Quemuenchatocha

[H1]Quemuenchatocha[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zaque of the Hunza Confederation[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1468-1538[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Quemuenchatocha became Zaque of the Hunza in 1490, after a battle between the Hunza and the Bacatá, resulted in the death of both sovereigns. Quemuenchatocha ceased hostilities and managed to forge an uneasy truce with the Zipa of the Bacatá, Nemequene, which lasted until 1514. Aware of Nemequene attempts to build alliances amongst neighboring tribes, Quemuenchatocha declared war on the Bacatá. Both armies met in at the Stream of the Laps in 1514, where Quemuenchatocha allegedly suggested he and Nemequene fight hand to hand so to avoid bloodshed. Nemequene rejected the offer and his army won the battle, yet Nemequene was mortally wounded, and his army retreated. [PARAGRAPH:1] Learning of the Spanish in his lands, Quemuenchatocha, withdrew to his palace, and maintained a repressive policy with his town, which increased its incapacity to govern. He sent gifts and envoys of peace to the Spanish, seeking to slow them down so he could hide his wealth. Finally in August 1537, the Spanish arrived finding Quemuenchatocha in his throne room, decorated in fine fabrics and gold, though alone, his advisors and guards having fled before the Spanish advance. The Spanish took him to the nearby city of Suesca hoping to find where he had hidden the rest of his treasure, but were unsuccessful. Quemuenchatocha was forced to abdicate in favor of his nephew Aquiminzaque, and died soon after in 1538.

TEXT.German: [H1]Quemuenchatocha[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zaque der Hunza Konföderation[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1468-1538[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Quemuenchatocha wurde 1490 Zaque der Hunza, als in einem Kampf zwischen Hunza und Bacata beide Herrscher starben. Quemuenchatocha beendete die Gewalt und schuff ein brüchiges Abkommen mit dem Zipa der Bacata, Nemequene, welches bis 1514 hielt. Der Anstrengungen Nemequene bewusst, mit anderen benachbarten Stämmen Bündnisse einzugehen, erklärte Quemuenchatocha den Bacata erneut den Krieg. Beide Armeen trafen sich 1514 und Quemuenchatocha schlug angeblich vor dass er und Nemequene Mann gegen Mann kämpfen sollten um ein Blutbad zu verhindern. Nemequene lehnte dies jedoch ab und seine Armee gewann den folgenden Kampf. Alledings wurde Nemequene tödlich verwundet, woraufhin sich seine Armee zurückzog. [PARAGRAPH:1] Als Quemuenchatocha vom Eintreffen der Spanier erfuhr, zog er sich in seinen Palast zurück und etablierte eine repressive Politik in seiner Stadt, was zu wachsender Unfähigkeit der Regierung führte das Land zu führen. Er schickte Geschenke und Abgesandte zu den Spaniern um deren Voranschreiten zu verlangsamen und während dessen seine Reichtümer zu verstecken. August 1537 trafen die Spanier ein und fanden Quemuenchatocha alleine in seinem Thronsaal vor, der mit feinsten Stoffen und Gold dekoriert war. Seine Berater und Wachen waren geflohen. Die Spanier brachten ihn in die nahegelegene Stadt Suesca um herauszufinden, wo er den Rest seines Reichtums versteckt hatte, waren dabei aber unerfolgreich. Quemuenchatocha wurde gezwungen zu Gunsten seines Neffen Aquiminzaque abzutreten und starb kurze Zeit später im Jahre 1538.
