The Spanish took him to the nearby city of Suesca hoping to find where he had hidden the rest of his treasure, but were unsuccessful. Quemuenchatocha was forced to abdicate in favor of his nephew Aquiminzaque, and died soon after in 1538.

TEXT.English: My name is [OUR_NAME], zaque of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ], and I welcome you, stranger, to our golden lands. If you are a loyal friend to us, perhaps we will share a little of our great wealth with you.
TEXT.French: My name is [OUR_NAME], zaque of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ], and I welcome you, stranger, to our golden lands. If you are a loyal friend to us, perhaps we will share a little of our great wealth with you.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Muisca. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: The sound of a defecating llama is more pleasing to the ear than anything you have to say. Leave us alone!
TEXT.French: The sound of a defecating llama is more pleasing to the ear than anything you have to say. Leave us alone!
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: By the ancient gods of my people, I will not stay my hand until every last one of you lies dead!
TEXT.French: By the ancient gods of my people, I will not stay my hand until every last one of you lies dead!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: We are honored that you have come to visit us. Let us chew some coca leaves, and tell us how we can help you.
TEXT.French: We are honored that you have come to visit us. Let us chew some coca leaves, and tell us how we can help you.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Quemuenchatocha aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Oh, it's you. Have your say, and leave us then. Don't get any ideas, we'll keep our women and children inside while you're here.
TEXT.French: Oh, it's you. Have your say, and leave us then. Don't get any ideas, we'll keep our women and children inside while you're here.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in desperate need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] find it in their hearts to assist us?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in desperate need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] find it in their hearts to assist us?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for your help. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for your help. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: The survival of the [CT_EMPIRE] depends on my goodwill. Give me what I wish and pray my will does not change.
TEXT.French: The survival of the [CT_EMPIRE] depends on my goodwill. Give me what I wish and pray my will does not change.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Comanche
TEXT.German: Comanchen:Comanchen:Comanchen

TEXT.English: Comanche
TEXT.German: Comanchen

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Comanche emerged as a separate group shortly before 1700, when they parted from the Shoshone people. This separation occurred at the same time the Comanche acquired the horse from the Pueblo Indians, which then enabled them to expand their search for new hunting grounds. The Comanche migration took them to the southern great plains, which the Comanche named Comancheria, a territory that extended from the present day Arkansas River to central Texas. During this migration the Comanche's population significantly increased largely due to ample food in the form of buffalo, the arrival of Shoshone migrants and the adoption of captive women and children from other tribes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Despite their increased numbers the Comanche never formed a single cohesive people, but rather a dozen separate and autonomous tribes. Horses became a key factor in the emergence of the Comanche culture, and the Comanche may have been the first group of plains Indians to fully incorporate the horse into their culture. The Comanche had access to vast numbers of horses, which were estimated to have numbered close to 2,000,000 in and around Comancheria. The Comanche possessed 40,000 horses, with a surplus of 90,000 to 120,000 horses and by the mid-19th century they were supplying horses to French and American traders and settlers. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Comanche maintained strained relations with European and later American settlers who attempted to settle within the borders of their territory, being simultaneously valued trading partners and feared as fierce opponents. Warfare was a part of Comanche life, and they adapted many strategies for fighting on horseback, especially mounted raids, which inevitably led to the Comanche at one time or another being at war with almost every other tribe on the great plains. Throughout the 1860's the Comanche continued to fight against United States forces, but by 1875, with their Buffalo herds decimated and their own numbers reduced from disease and war, the last Comanche bands surrendered and moved onto reservations.

During this migration the Comanche's population significantly increased largely due to ample food in the form of buffalo, the arrival of Shoshone migrants and the adoption of captive women and children from other tribes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Despite their increased numbers the Comanche never formed a single cohesive people, but rather a dozen separate and autonomous tribes. Horses became a key factor in the emergence of the Comanche culture, and the Comanche may have been the first group of plains Indians to fully incorporate the horse into their culture. The Comanche had access to vast numbers of horses, which were estimated to have numbered close to 2,000,000 in and around Comancheria. The Comanche possessed 40,000 horses, with a surplus of 90,000 to 120,000 horses and by the mid-19th century they were supplying horses to French and American traders and settlers. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Comanche maintained strained relations with European and later American settlers who attempted to settle within the borders of their territory, being simultaneously valued trading partners and feared as fierce opponents. Warfare was a part of Comanche life, and they adapted many strategies for fighting on horseback, especially mounted raids, which inevitably led to the Comanche at one time or another being at war with almost every other tribe on the great plains. Throughout the 1860's the Comanche continued to fight against United States forces, but by 1875, with their Buffalo herds decimated and their own numbers reduced from disease and war, the last Comanche bands surrendered and moved onto reservations.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Comanchen erschienen als eigenständiger Stamm kurz vor 1700, als sie sich vom Volk der Shoshonen lösten. Diese Abspaltung geschah zur selben Zeit, als sie von den Pueblo Indianern Pferde erwarben, was ihnen ermöglichte ihre Jagdgebiete stark auszuweiten. Die Migration der Comanchen führte sie zu den südlichen Great Plains, die die Comanchen Comancheria nannten, ein Gebiet, dass sich vom heutigen Arkansas Fluss bis in das zentrale Texas erstreckte. Während der Migration wuchs die Bevölerkung der Comanchen signifikant aufgrund des reichen Nahrungsvorkommens in Form von Büffeln, die Ankunft von weiteren Shoshone Migranten, und die Aufnahme von geraubten Kindern und Frauen aus anderen Stämmen. [PARAGRAPH:1]Trotz ihrer stark gewachsenen Zahl bildeten die Comanchen nie ein geeintes Volk, sondern blieben stets ein Dutzend eigenständige Stämme. Pferde wurden ein Schlüsselfaktor der Kultur der Comanchen und die Comanchen waren wohl die ersten Ureinwohnder der Prärie, die diese vollständig in ihre Lebensweise integrierten. Die Zahl der Pferde in der Comancheria zu dieser Zeit wird auf 2 Millionen geschätzt. Mitte des 19ten Jahrhunderts verkaufeten sie Pferde and französische und amerikansiche Händler. [PARAGRAPH:1] Die Beziehungen der Comachen zu den Europäern und später zu den Amerikanern, die in ihrem Gebiet zu siedeln versuchten, blieben angespannt, da diese gleichzeitig geschätzte Handelspartner aber auch Gegner in Bezug auf die territorialen Rechte waren. Krieg war Teil des normalen Lebens der Comanchen und sie entwickelten viele Strategien um auf Pferden zu kämpfen, wie berittene überfälle, die unausweichlich dazu führten, dass sich die Comachen mit fast jedem anderen Stamm in den Great Plains im Krieg befanden. In den 1860ern kämpften die Comachen gegen die Truppen der United States. Als aber um 1875, die Büffelherden dezimiert wurden und ihre Bevölkerung durch Krankheiten und Kriege geschwächt war, ergaben sich die letzten Comanche und zogen sichin Reservate zurück.

This separation occurred at the same time the Comanche acquired the horse from the Pueblo Indians, which then enabled them to expand their search for new hunting grounds. The Comanche migration took them to the southern great plains, which the Comanche named Comancheria, a territory that extended from the present day Arkansas River to central Texas. During this migration the Comanche's population significantly increased largely due to ample food in the form of buffalo, the arrival of Shoshone migrants and the adoption of captive women and children from other tribes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Despite their increased numbers the Comanche never formed a single cohesive people, but rather a dozen separate and autonomous tribes. Horses became a key factor in the emergence of the Comanche culture, and the Comanche may have been the first group of plains Indians to fully incorporate the horse into their culture. The Comanche had access to vast numbers of horses, which were estimated to have numbered close to 2,000,000 in and around Comancheria. The Comanche possessed 40,000 horses, with a surplus of 90,000 to 120,000 horses and by the mid-19th century they were supplying horses to French and American traders and settlers. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Comanche maintained strained relations with European and later American settlers who attempted to settle within the borders of their territory, being simultaneously valued trading partners and feared as fierce opponents. Warfare was a part of Comanche life, and they adapted many strategies for fighting on horseback, especially mounted raids, which inevitably led to the Comanche at one time or another being at war with almost every other tribe on the great plains. Throughout the 1860's the Comanche continued to fight against United States forces, but by 1875, with their Buffalo herds decimated and their own numbers reduced from disease and war, the last Comanche bands surrendered and moved onto reservations.

Warfare was a part of Comanche life, and they adapted many strategies for fighting on horseback, especially mounted raids, which inevitably led to the Comanche at one time or another being at war with almost every other tribe on the great plains. Throughout the 1860's the Comanche continued to fight against United States forces, but by 1875, with their Buffalo herds decimated and their own numbers reduced from disease and war, the last Comanche bands surrendered and moved onto reservations.

TEXT.English: Comanche
TEXT.German: Comanche:Comanche:Comanche:Comanche
TEXT.Italian: Comanche
TEXT.Spanish: Comanche

TEXT.English: Iron Jacket

[H1]Iron Jacket[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Noconi Comanche[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1780 - 1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Po-hebitsquash was a war chief and medicine man who believed he possessed the power to defend against bullets. He wore a Spanish coat of mail into battle, which protected him from small arms fire and most likely gave him the name Iron Jacket. Little is known of Iron Jacket's early life, other than he was chief of the Noconi Comanche tribe, and that he was a hereditary chief. From the 1820s to the 1850s he led dozens of raids in Texas and Mexico, being considered a supernatural being by many of his victims due to his ability to appear seeming invulnerable to gunfire. [PARAGRAPH:1] Frustrated by increasingly bloody raids by the Comanche on the Texas Frontier, the Texas militia and their Tonkawa Indian allies forces attacked several Comanche villages along the South Canadian River, at the Battle of Little Robe Creek, on May 12, 1858. During the battle Iron Jacket repeatedly rode down the firing line of his enemy taunting them. However, his jacket failed to protect him from the Buffalo gun of the Tonkawa Indian Jim Pockmark, who shot and killed the Comanche chief. Discouraged by their chief's death, Iron Jacket's forces began to waver and was only saved by the timely arrival of his son Peta Nocona, and his warriors, allowing the members of his father's village to retreat. Iron Jacket's body could not be recovered, and was eventually scalped, and partially eaten by the cannibalistic Tonkawas.
TEXT.French: [H1]Iron Jacket[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Noconi Comanche[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1780 - 1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Po-hebitsquash was a war chief and medicine man who believed he possessed the power to defend against bullets. He wore a Spanish coat of mail into battle, which protected him from small arms fire and most likely gave him the name Iron Jacket. Little is known of Iron Jacket's early life, other than he was chief of the Noconi Comanche tribe, and that he was a hereditary chief. From the 1820s to the 1850s he led dozens of raids in Texas and Mexico, being considered a supernatural being by many of his victims due to his ability to appear seeming invulnerable to gunfire. [PARAGRAPH:1] Frustrated by increasingly bloody raids by the Comanche on the Texas Frontier, the Texas militia and their Tonkawa Indian allies forces attacked several Comanche villages along the South Canadian River, at the Battle of Little Robe Creek, on May 12, 1858. During the battle Iron Jacket repeatedly rode down the firing line of his enemy taunting them. However, his jacket failed to protect him from the Buffalo gun of the Tonkawa Indian Jim Pockmark, who shot and killed the Comanche chief. Discouraged by their chief's death, Iron Jacket's forces began to waver and was only saved by the timely arrival of his son Peta Nocona, and his warriors, allowing the members of his father's village to retreat. Iron Jacket's body could not be recovered, and was eventually scalped, and partially eaten by the cannibalistic Tonkawas.
TEXT.German: [H1]Iron Jacket[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Noconi Comanchen[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]1780 - 1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Po-hebitsquash war ein Kriegshäuptling und Medizinman, der glaubte die Macht zu besitzen Kugeln abwehren zu können. Er trug einen spanischen Plattenpanzer im Kampf, der ihn vor kleinere Geschossen schützte und ihm wahrscheinlich den Namen Iron Jacket gab. Wenig ist über das frühe Leben von Iron Jacket bekannt. Nur dass er Kriegshäuptling der Noconi Comanchen war und dass er dieses amt geerbt hatte. Zwischen 1820 und 1850 führte er dutzende Raubzüge in Texas und Mexiko an und wurde von manchen seinen Opfern als übernatürliches Wesen gefürchtet, da er die Fähigkeit zu haben schien gegen Feuerwaffen gefeit zu sein.[PARAGRAPH:1] Durch die zunehmend blutigen überfälle der Comanchen an der Grenze von Texas frustriert, unernahm die Miliz von Texas mit ihren Alliierten, den Tonkawa Indianern, mehrere Angriffe gegen Dörfer der Comanchen entlang des South Canadian River, darunter auch die Schlacht von Little Robe Creek am 12. Mai 1858. Während dieser Schlacht ritt Iron Jacket wiederholt entlang der feindlichen Linien und verhöhnte den Gegner. Jedoch versagte dieses mal sein Panzer gegen das Büffelgewehr des Tonkawa Jim Pockmark, der den Comanchen Häuptling traf und tötete. Durch den Tod ihres Häuptlings entmutig begannen die Truppen von Iron Jacket zu wanken und wurden nur durch die rechtzeitige Ankunft seines Sohnes Peta Nocona und dessen Krieger gerettet, dies es ihnen erlaubte zu fliehen. Iron Jackets Körper konnte nicht geborgen werden. Er wurde skaplpiert und sogar teilweise von den kanibalischen Tonkawa Indianern gegessen.

Iron Jacket's body could not be recovered, and was eventually scalped, and partially eaten by the cannibalistic Tonkawas.

TEXT.English: Greetings, white faced stranger. I am [OUR_NAME], leader of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] warriors. I hope this day is the beginning of a long and fruitful friendship.
TEXT.French: Greetings, white faced stranger. I am [OUR_NAME], leader of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] warriors. I hope this day is the beginning of a long and fruitful friendship.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Häuptling der Commachen. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Negotiations with you have proven to be a bad medicine in the past. We learn from our mistakes.
TEXT.French: Negotiations with you have proven to be a bad medicine in the past. We learn from our mistakes.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Our warriors will not wash off their war paint solely to be betrayed again by you!
TEXT.French: Our warriors will not wash off their war paint solely to be betrayed again by you!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome, friend. Let us share hunting stories around the campfire this evening, and make trades that benefit both our nations.
TEXT.French: Welcome, friend. Let us share hunting stories around the campfire this evening, and make trades that benefit both our nations.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Iron Jacket aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Your people are walking down the warpath. If you continue, you will find the deadly bows of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] at its end. I hope you have come to let yourself be educated instead on the subject of honor.
TEXT.French: Your people are walking down the warpath. If you continue, you will find the deadly bows of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] at its end. I hope you have come to let yourself be educated instead on the subject of honor.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] help their brothers?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] help their brothers?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. Will you help or cast aside our friendship?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. Will you help or cast aside our friendship?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could destroy the [CT_EMPIRE] with great ease. Give me what I demand and I will spare your people.
TEXT.French: I could destroy the [CT_EMPIRE] with great ease. Give me what I demand and I will spare your people.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Shoshone
TEXT.German: Shoshonen:Shoshonen:Shoshonen

TEXT.English: Shoshone
TEXT.German: Shoshonen

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Shoshone, sometimes called the Snake Indians by early European trappers, travelers, and settlers, are members of the much larger Uto-Aztecan language group. Residing in an area from the Great Basin to coastal Southern California in present-day United States, the Shoshoni were divided into three branches, the Northern, Eastern, and Western Shoshoni. From the 1700's onwards, warfare and pressure from rival tribes, pushed the Eastern Shoshone south and westward, resulting in some of the Shoshoni moving as far south as Texas where they were become the Comanche. [PARAGRAPH:1] With the European-American migration westwards into Shoshone lands, the Shoshone often found themselves at war with the whites, especially in the second half of the 19th century. Under the leadership of Chief Pocatello, the Northern Shoshone fought settlers in Idaho throughout the 1860's raiding their farms and ranches. These raids led to the Bear River Massacre of 1863, where US forces trapped and murdered 350-500 Shoshone who were in their winter camps. [PARAGRAPH:1] Allied with the Bannock and Paiute people, the Shoshone continued to sporadically fight against the United States in the Snake War, 1864-1868, and the Bannock War of 1878. The most renowned Shoshone is probably Sacagawea, from the Northern Shoshone's Lemhi band. Sacagawea is famous for being a key participant in Lewis and Clark's, Corps of Discovery during its expedition of the Western United States, 1804-1806.
TEXT.French: [TAB]The Shoshone, sometimes called the Snake Indians by early European trappers, travelers, and settlers, are members of the much larger Uto-Aztecan language group. Residing in an area from the Great Basin to coastal Southern California in present-day United States, the Shoshoni were divided into three branches, the Northern, Eastern, and Western Shoshoni. From the 1700's onwards, warfare and pressure from rival tribes, pushed the Eastern Shoshone south and westward, resulting in some of the Shoshoni moving as far south as Texas where they were become the Comanche. [PARAGRAPH:1] With the European-American migration westwards into Shoshone lands, the Shoshone often found themselves at war with the whites, especially in the second half of the 19th century. Under the leadership of Chief Pocatello, the Northern Shoshone fought settlers in Idaho throughout the 1860's raiding their farms and ranches. These raids led to the Bear River Massacre of 1863, where US forces trapped and murdered 350-500 Shoshone who were in their winter camps. [PARAGRAPH:1] Allied with the Bannock and Paiute people, the Shoshone continued to sporadically fight against the United States in the Snake War, 1864-1868, and the Bannock War of 1878. The most renowned Shoshone is probably Sacagawea, from the Northern Shoshone's Lemhi band. Sacagawea is famous for being a key participant in Lewis and Clark's, Corps of Discovery during its expedition of the Western United States, 1804-1806.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Shoshonen, die manchmal von den ersten Europäern auch Schlangenindianer genannt wurde, sind Teil der viel grösseren Uto-Azteken-Sprachgruppe. Angesiedelt in dem Gebiet des Great Basin bis in das heutige Süd-Kalifornien, waren sie in drei Hauptzweige aufgeteilt, die Nord-, Ost- und West-Shoshonen. Um 1700 wurden die Ost-Shoshonen durch Kriege und den Druck der rivalisierende Stämme nach Süden und Westen gezwungen, was dazu führte, dass einige sogar bis nach Texas migrierten, wo sie zu den Comanchen wurden. [PARAGRAPH:1] Mit der immer weiter westlich in das Land der Shoshonen vordringenden Europäisch-Amerikanischen Besiedlung, befanden sich die Shoshonen oft im Krieg mit dem Weissen Mann, besonders in der zweiten Hälfte des 19ten Jahrhunderts. Unter der Führung von Häuptling Pocatello, bekämpften die Nord-Shoshonen die Siedler in Idaho bis in die 1860er hinein, indem sie Farmen und Ranches überfielen. Dies führte 1863 zum Bear River Massaker bei dem US Truppen 350 bis 500 Shoshonen, die gerade ihre Winterlager errichtet hatten, einschlossen und ermordeten. [PARAGRAPH:1] Mit den Bannock and Paiute verbündet, setzten die Shoshonen sporadisch ihren Kampf gegen die United States fort. Bedeutendere Ereignisse dabei sind der Schlangenkrieg 1864 bis 1868 und der Bannock Krieg von 1878. Der bekannteste Shoshone ist vermutlich Sacagawea von den Nord-Shoshonen, weil er als ein Schlüsselteilnehmer der Expedition von Lewis and Clark gilt, die 1804-1806 weite Teile des bis dahin kaum kartographierten westliche Nordamerika erkundete.

Residing in an area from the Great Basin to coastal Southern California in present-day United States, the Shoshoni were divided into three branches, the Northern, Eastern, and Western Shoshoni. From the 1700's onwards, warfare and pressure from rival tribes, pushed the Eastern Shoshone south and westward, resulting in some of the Shoshoni moving as far south as Texas where they were become the Comanche. [PARAGRAPH:1] With the European-American migration westwards into Shoshone lands, the Shoshone often found themselves at war with the whites, especially in the second half of the 19th century. Under the leadership of Chief Pocatello, the Northern Shoshone fought settlers in Idaho throughout the 1860's raiding their farms and ranches. These raids led to the Bear River Massacre of 1863, where US forces trapped and murdered 350-500 Shoshone who were in their winter camps. [PARAGRAPH:1] Allied with the Bannock and Paiute people, the Shoshone continued to sporadically fight against the United States in the Snake War, 1864-1868, and the Bannock War of 1878. The most renowned Shoshone is probably Sacagawea, from the Northern Shoshone's Lemhi band. Sacagawea is famous for being a key participant in Lewis and Clark's, Corps of Discovery during its expedition of the Western United States, 1804-1806.

From the 1700's onwards, warfare and pressure from rival tribes, pushed the Eastern Shoshone south and westward, resulting in some of the Shoshoni moving as far south as Texas where they were become the Comanche. [PARAGRAPH:1] With the European-American migration westwards into Shoshone lands, the Shoshone often found themselves at war with the whites, especially in the second half of the 19th century. Under the leadership of Chief Pocatello, the Northern Shoshone fought settlers in Idaho throughout the 1860's raiding their farms and ranches. These raids led to the Bear River Massacre of 1863, where US forces trapped and murdered 350-500 Shoshone who were in their winter camps. [PARAGRAPH:1] Allied with the Bannock and Paiute people, the Shoshone continued to sporadically fight against the United States in the Snake War, 1864-1868, and the Bannock War of 1878. The most renowned Shoshone is probably Sacagawea, from the Northern Shoshone's Lemhi band. Sacagawea is famous for being a key participant in Lewis and Clark's, Corps of Discovery during its expedition of the Western United States, 1804-1806.

TEXT.English: Shoshone
TEXT.German: Shoshone:Shoshone:Shoshone:Shoshone
TEXT.Italian: Shoshone
TEXT.Spanish: Shoshone

TEXT.English: Washakie

[H1]Washakie[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Eastern Shoshone[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c 1798 - 1900[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little of Washakie's early life is known. His father was from the Salish tribe and his mother was a Lemhi Shoshone. In 1851 at the urging of the trapper Jim Bridger, whom had married one of his daughters, Washakie represented the Shoshone at the Treaty of Fort Laramie in 1851, and the Treaties of Fort Bridger, in 1863 and 1868 respectively. The treaties established the Shoshone and Bannock Indian Agency, along with reservation of about three million acres in Wyoming's Wind River country for Washakie's people. In 1872 land cession reduced the size of the reservation by 800,000 acres, yet the land that remained in Shoshone possession continues to be the home of the Eastern Shoshones to this day. [PARAGRAPH:1] Eager for his people to be educated, Washakie gave land for a boarding school to be established where Shoshone girls could learn traditional languages and crafts. Washakie's prowess in battle, his efforts to work with the white settlers and his commitment to his people's interests led him be considered by the United States government as the head of the Eastern Shoshone until his death, and one of the most respected leaders in Native American history.
TEXT.French: [H1]Washakie[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Eastern Shoshone[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]c 1798 - 1900[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little of Washakie's early life is known. His father was from the Salish tribe and his mother was a Lemhi Shoshone. In 1851 at the urging of the trapper Jim Bridger, whom had married one of his daughters, Washakie represented the Shoshone at the Treaty of Fort Laramie in 1851, and the Treaties of Fort Bridger, in 1863 and 1868 respectively. The treaties established the Shoshone and Bannock Indian Agency, along with reservation of about three million acres in Wyoming's Wind River country for Washakie's people. In 1872 land cession reduced the size of the reservation by 800,000 acres, yet the land that remained in Shoshone possession continues to be the home of the Eastern Shoshones to this day. [PARAGRAPH:1] Eager for his people to be educated, Washakie gave land for a boarding school to be established where Shoshone girls could learn traditional languages and crafts. Washakie's prowess in battle, his efforts to work with the white settlers and his commitment to his people's interests led him be considered by the United States government as the head of the Eastern Shoshone until his death, and one of the most respected leaders in Native American history.
TEXT.German: [H1]Washakie[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Ost-Shoshonen[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1798 - 1900[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Wenig ist über Washakies frühes Leben bekannt. Sein Vater war vom Stamm der Salish und seine Mutter eine Lemhi Shoshonin. 1851 den Bitten des Trappers Jim Bridger nachgebend, der mit einer seiner Töchter verheiratet war, repräsentierte Washakie die Shoshonen beim Vertrag von Fort Laramie und später dann auch bein den Verträgen von Fort Bridger, in den Jahren 1863 und 1868. Die Verträge etablierten die Shoshone und Bannock Indianer Agentur und 3 Millionen Acres Land als Reservat in Wyoming. 1872 wurde dieses Reservat jedoch auf ein Drittel der ursprünglichen Grösse reduziert blieb jedoch bis heute die Heimat der Ost-Shoshonen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Washakies Erfolgen im Kampf, sein Einsatz um friedliche mit den weissen Siedlern zu leben und seine Hingabe an die Interessen seines Volkes liesen ihn bis zu seinem Tode der Führer der Ost-Shoshonen bleiben und zu einem der am meisten respektierten Personen in der Geschichte der amerikanischen Ureinwohner werden.

His father was from the Salish tribe and his mother was a Lemhi Shoshone. In 1851 at the urging of the trapper Jim Bridger, whom had married one of his daughters, Washakie represented the Shoshone at the Treaty of Fort Laramie in 1851, and the Treaties of Fort Bridger, in 1863 and 1868 respectively. In 1872 land cession reduced the size of the reservation by 800,000 acres, yet the land that remained in Shoshone possession continues to be the home of the Eastern Shoshones to this day. [PARAGRAPH:1] Eager for his people to be educated, Washakie gave land for a boarding school to be established where Shoshone girls could learn traditional languages and crafts. Washakie's prowess in battle, his efforts to work with the white settlers and his commitment to his people's interests led him be considered by the United States government as the head of the Eastern Shoshone until his death, and one of the most respected leaders in Native American history.

TEXT.English: I am [OUR_NAME], leader of the great [OUR_CIV_ADJ] nation. Let us share this land and hunt our bisons as friends.
TEXT.French: I am [OUR_NAME], leader of the great [OUR_CIV_ADJ] nation. Let us share this land and hunt our bisons as friends.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Häuptling der Shoshonen. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: The hunter never heeds his prey's pleas for mercy. I will speak you again on the day we are both at the happy hunting ground.
TEXT.French: The hunter never heeds his prey's pleas for mercy. I will speak you again on the day we are both at the happy hunting ground.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: On behalf of our fallen kinsmen, we will continue our fight until justice is served!
TEXT.French: On behalf of our fallen kinsmen, we will continue our fight until justice is served!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the camps of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Share some peyote with me and tell me about your business.
TEXT.French: Welcome to the camps of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Share some peyote with me and tell me about your business.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Washakie aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: I can't remember having invited you for dinner, so why are you here?
TEXT.French: I can't remember having invited you for dinner, so why are you here?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. Will you neglect your friends at such a time?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. Will you neglect your friends at such a time?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: My warriors and gods are stronger than those of the [CT_EMPIRE]. It would best serve you to yield to what I demand.
TEXT.French: My warriors and gods are stronger than those of the [CT_EMPIRE]. It would best serve you to yield to what I demand.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Toromona
TEXT.German: Toromona:Toromona:Toromona

TEXT.English: Toromona
TEXT.German: Toromona

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Toromona are a tribe that belong to the group of uncontacted peoples living in the Amazon region of northwest Bolivia. [PARAGRAPH:1] According to legend, the Toromona were an ally to the Inca, and helped the remnants of the Inca disappear into the forests to the city of Paititi, the fabled city that was the alleged hiding place of Inca treasure which had been concealed from the conquistadores. During the 16th century Father Miguel Cavello Balboa wrote about a city of gold that he identified as Paititi, protected by the Toromona, a tribe he noted that had no mercy in killing. [PARAGRAPH:1] During the 16th and 17th centuries the Spanish motivated by such stories, encroached upon Toromona lands, yet they were unable to explore or settle the area, meeting fierce resistance from the Toromona warriors who drove the Spanish back out of the forests. British explorer Percy Harrison Fawcett, traveled through the area in 1911, yet failed to make contact with the Toromona. Lars Hafskjold, the Norwegian biologist, tried also to make contact in 1997 and was never seen again.
TEXT.French: [TAB] The Toromona are a tribe that belong to the group of uncontacted peoples living in the Amazon region of northwest Bolivia. [PARAGRAPH:1] According to legend, the Toromona were an ally to the Inca, and helped the remnants of the Inca disappear into the forests to the city of Paititi, the fabled city that was the alleged hiding place of Inca treasure which had been concealed from the conquistadores. During the 16th century Father Miguel Cavello Balboa wrote about a city of gold that he identified as Paititi, protected by the Toromona, a tribe he noted that had no mercy in killing. [PARAGRAPH:1] During the 16th and 17th centuries the Spanish motivated by such stories, encroached upon Toromona lands, yet they were unable to explore or settle the area, meeting fierce resistance from the Toromona warriors who drove the Spanish back out of the forests. British explorer Percy Harrison Fawcett, traveled through the area in 1911, yet failed to make contact with the Toromona. Lars Hafskjold, the Norwegian biologist, tried also to make contact in 1997 and was never seen again.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Toromona sind ein Stamm, der in der Amazonasgegend des heutigen nordwestlichen Bolivien lebte aber nie von den Europäern zu Gesprächen kontaktiert werden konnte. [PARAGRAPH:1] Den Legenden zu Folge waren sie auch Verbündete der Inka und halfen den überresten der Inka in der Regenwald zu der mystischen Stadt Paititi zu verschwinden, welche angeblich auch der Ort ist, an dem die sagenhaften Schätze der Inka vor den Conquistadores versteckt wurden. Im 16ten Jahrhundert schrieb Pater Miguel Cavello Balboa über die Stad aus Gold, die er Paititi nannte und von den Toromona, einem blutrünstigen Stamm ohne Gnade, bewacht würde. [PARAGRAPH:1] Durch solche Geschichte motiviert erreichten die Spanier am Ende des 16ten Jahrhunderts das Land der Toromona, waren jedoch nicht fähig die Gegend zu besiedeln oder auch nur ausreichend zu erkunden, da sie auf heftigen Wiederstand durch die Toromona Krieger trafen und aus deren Wäldern zurück getrieben wurden. Der Britische Entdecker Percy Harrison Fawcett bereiste 1911 dieses Gebiet konnte jedoch ebenfalls keinen Kontakt mit den Toromona herstellen. Lars Hafskjold, ein norwegischer Biologe, versuchte 1997 ebenfalls die Kontaktaufnahme, wurde jedoch nie wieder gesehen.

During the 16th century Father Miguel Cavello Balboa wrote about a city of gold that he identified as Paititi, protected by the Toromona, a tribe he noted that had no mercy in killing. [PARAGRAPH:1] During the 16th and 17th centuries the Spanish motivated by such stories, encroached upon Toromona lands, yet they were unable to explore or settle the area, meeting fierce resistance from the Toromona warriors who drove the Spanish back out of the forests. British explorer Percy Harrison Fawcett, traveled through the area in 1911, yet failed to make contact with the Toromona. Lars Hafskjold, the Norwegian biologist, tried also to make contact in 1997 and was never seen again.

During the 16th century Father Miguel Cavello Balboa wrote about a city of gold that he identified as Paititi, protected by the Toromona, a tribe he noted that had no mercy in killing. [PARAGRAPH:1] During the 16th and 17th centuries the Spanish motivated by such stories, encroached upon Toromona lands, yet they were unable to explore or settle the area, meeting fierce resistance from the Toromona warriors who drove the Spanish back out of the forests. TEXT.English: Toromona
TEXT.German: Toromona:Toromona:Toromona:Toromona
TEXT.Italian: Toromona
TEXT.Spanish: Toromona

TEXT.English: Tarano

[H1]Tarano[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Toromona[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early-mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of this Toromona leader. Legend states that it was Tarano who guided the last of the Inca and their treasure through the forests to the mythical city of Paititi. Tarano was renowned as a great war chieftain, whose ferocity and skill in battle against the conquistadores in the 1560's was enough for him to be recorded by the Spanish as notable opponent.
TEXT.French: [H1]Tarano[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Toromona[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early-mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of this Toromona leader. Legend states that it was Tarano who guided the last of the Inca and their treasure through the forests to the mythical city of Paititi. Tarano was renowned as a great war chieftain, whose ferocity and skill in battle against the conquistadores in the 1560's was enough for him to be recorded by the Spanish as notable opponent.
TEXT.German: [H1]Tarano[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Toromona[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]Anfang bis Mitte des 16ten Jahrhunderts[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] über diesen Anführer der Toromana ist fast nichts belegt. Die Legenden berichten, dass es Tarano war, der die letzten Inka durch die Regenwälder zu der mystischen Stadt Paititi führte. Tarano soll ein mächtiger Kriegshäuptling gewesen sein, dessen Wildheit und Fähigkeiten im Kampf gegen die Conquistadores in den 1560ern ausreichend waren um als würdiger Gegner in die Geschichtsschreibung der Spanier einzugehen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Tarano[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Toromona[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early-mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of this Toromona leader. Legend states that it was Tarano who guided the last of the Inca and their treasure through the forests to the mythical city of Paititi. Tarano was renowned as a great war chieftain, whose ferocity and skill in battle against the conquistadores in the 1560's was enough for him to be recorded by the Spanish as notable opponent.

Legend states that it was Tarano who guided the last of the Inca and their treasure through the forests to the mythical city of Paititi. Tarano was renowned as a great war chieftain, whose ferocity and skill in battle against the conquistadores in the 1560's was enough for him to be recorded by the Spanish as notable opponent.

TEXT.English: I am [OUR_NAME], first warrior of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] tribes. I hope you leave our pristine lands unspoiled whenever you pass through them, for we do not allow anyone to disturb our peace.
TEXT.French: I am [OUR_NAME], first warrior of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] tribes. I hope you leave our pristine lands unspoiled whenever you pass through them, for we do not allow anyone to disturb our peace.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Toromona. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Your words are as pale as your skin. Leave my presence now!
TEXT.French: Your words are as pale as your skin. Leave my presence now!
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: As long as you live, there will be no peace in any [OUR_CIV_ADJ] heart!
TEXT.French: As long as you live, there will be no peace in any [OUR_CIV_ADJ] heart!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the sheltered valleys of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Why did you make this perilous journey to meet us?
TEXT.French: Welcome to the sheltered valleys of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Why did you make this perilous journey to meet us?
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Tarano aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: My patience with you grows thinner every day. I cannot think of a single reason why we shouldn't throw you back into the sea from which you emerged. Can you?
TEXT.French: My patience with you grows thinner every day. I cannot think of a single reason why we shouldn't throw you back into the sea from which you emerged. Can you?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Crow
TEXT.German: Crow:Crow:Crow

TEXT.English: Crow
TEXT.German: Crow

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Crow, are also known as the Apsaalooke or the Absaroka, which in their own Siouan language means either Sparrowhawk or bird people. The French who were the first Europeans to encounter the Crow in the mid 18th century, mistranslated the name to gens du corbeaux (people of the crows), thereafter becoming known in English as the Crow. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Crow resided on the Great Plains within the Yellowstone River valley, although they were originally believed to have been from the Ohio valley region, but migrated west in the face of the better armed Cree and Ojibwas, and then forced further westward by the Cheyenne and then the Sioux. Encountering Europeans in 1743, the Crow quickly acquired and became adept horsemen, though consequently found themselves regularly raided by the Blackfoot Confederacy, Gros Ventre, Assiniboine, Pawnee, Ute and Lakota tribes, who chose to steal horses rather than trade for them. [PARAGRAPH:1] The 1851 Treaty of Fort Laramie with the United States, guaranteed the Crow 38 million acres of territory, but with the more numerous Lakota and Cheyenne settled to the south and east, it was not long before Crow lands were invaded. Through the right of conquest the Cheyenne and Lakota claimed much of the Crow's ancestral land, and pushed them ever westward. The second Treaty of Fort Laramie, signed in 1868, reduced even further what was left of the Crow's territory to just over 8 million acres. Subsequent Acts of Congress reduced the Crow's territory and by 1904 only 2.3 million acres remained located in present day Montana.

[PARAGRAPH:1] The Crow resided on the Great Plains within the Yellowstone River valley, although they were originally believed to have been from the Ohio valley region, but migrated west in the face of the better armed Cree and Ojibwas, and then forced further westward by the Cheyenne and then the Sioux. [PARAGRAPH:1] The 1851 Treaty of Fort Laramie with the United States, guaranteed the Crow 38 million acres of territory, but with the more numerous Lakota and Cheyenne settled to the south and east, it was not long before Crow lands were invaded. Through the right of conquest the Cheyenne and Lakota claimed much of the Crow's ancestral land, and pushed them ever westward. The second Treaty of Fort Laramie, signed in 1868, reduced even further what was left of the Crow's territory to just over 8 million acres. Subsequent Acts of Congress reduced the Crow's territory and by 1904 only 2.3 million acres remained located in present day Montana.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Crow sind auch als die Apsaalooke oder die Absaroka bekannt, was in ihrer eigenen Sprache Siouan 'Sperbervolk' oder 'Vogelvolk' bedeutet. Die Franzosen waren die ersten Europäer, die Mitte des 18ten Jahrhunderts auf die Crow trafen. Diese übersetzten deren Namen fälschlicherweise als 'Krähenvolk'. Diese falsche übersetzung wurden von den Engländern als 'Crow' übernommen.[PARAGRAPH:1] Die Crow siedelten in den Great Plains im Yellowstone River Tal, obwohl sie ursprünglich wohl aus der Gegend des Ohio Tals stammen und weiter westlich zogen um den besser bewaffneten Cree und Ojibwas auszuweichen und dann durch Cheyenne und Sioux sogar noch weiter westlich gezwungen wurden. Nachdem sie 1743 auf die Europäer trafen, erwarben die Crow bald Pferde und wurden geschickte Reiter. Sie wurden jedoch oft von Blackfoot, Gros Ventre, Assiniboine, Pawnee, Ute und Lakota Stämmen überfallen, die lieber Pferde stahlen, als sie selbst zu züchten. [PARAGRAPH:1] 1851 garantierte der Vertrag von Fort Laramie mit den United States den Crow 38 Millionen Acres Territorium aber aufgrund der zahlenmässig überlegenen Lakota und Cheyenne, die südlich und östlich davon siedelten wurde dieses Gebiet bald umkämpft und teilweise verloren. Durch das Recht der Eroberung beanspruchten die Cheyenne und Lakota bald einen Gossteil des Landes der Vorfahren der Crow und zwangen sie immer weiter westlich. Der zweite Vertrag von Fort Laramie im Jahre 1868 reduzierte das verbliebene Land der Crow sogar noch weiter auf nunmehr lediglich 8 Millionen Acres. Weitere Beschlüsse des Kongresses liesen dieses Gebiet bis 1904 auf lediglich 2.3 Millionen Acres im heutingen Montana schrumpfen.

TEXT.English: Pine Leaf

[H1]Pine Leaf[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War chief of the Crow[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1806 -1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Pine Leaf was born a member of the Gros Ventres tribe, but at the age of 10 she was captured and taken prisoner by a Crow raiding party. Although she was very feminine in her dress and appearance, Pine Leaf demonstrated a strong partiality towards masculine habits, often besting her male counterparts in shooting, hunting and horse riding. Accounts state that as a child her twin brother had been killed by the Blackfoot and subsequently she vowed to take no husband until she had killed 100 enemy warriors with her own hands. She achieved the status of a warrior when she single handedly turned back a Blackfoot attack upon a fort that was sheltering Crow and white families. Pine Leaf continued to increase her standing within her village often raiding Blackfoot villages, and adding to her collection of scalps and horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Made part of the Council of Chiefs, there she became known as Woman Chief, earning a strong voice in the tribes council, ranking the third most prominent person in the whole tribe of 160 lodges. She gave up her position as Chief at age forty-five after over two decades of brave leadership into battle. In 1858, visiting the Gros Ventre tribe, Pine Leaf was ambushed and killed by Gros Ventre warriors.
TEXT.French: [H1]Pine Leaf[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War chief of the Crow[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1806 -1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Pine Leaf was born a member of the Gros Ventres tribe, but at the age of 10 she was captured and taken prisoner by a Crow raiding party. Accounts state that as a child her twin brother had been killed by the Blackfoot and subsequently she vowed to take no husband until she had killed 100 enemy warriors with her own hands. She achieved the status of a warrior when she single handedly turned back a Blackfoot attack upon a fort that was sheltering Crow and white families. Pine Leaf continued to increase her standing within her village often raiding Blackfoot villages, and adding to her collection of scalps and horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Made part of the Council of Chiefs, there she became known as Woman Chief, earning a strong voice in the tribes council, ranking the third most prominent person in the whole tribe of 160 lodges. She gave up her position as Chief at age forty-five after over two decades of brave leadership into battle. In 1858, visiting the Gros Ventre tribe, Pine Leaf was ambushed and killed by Gros Ventre warriors.
TEXT.German: [H1]Pine Leaf[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kriegshäuptling der Crow[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]1806 -1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Pine Leaf wurde als Mitglied des Gros Ventres Stammes geboren aber im Alter von 10 Jahren von einer Crow überfallsgruppe gefangen genommen. Obwohl sie in ihrer Erscheinung sehr weiblich war, demonstrierte Pine Leaf eine starke Neigung für männliche Tätigkeiten und überflügelte oft gleichaltrige Jungen und Männer beim Bogenschiessen, Jagen oder Reiten. Berichte bezeugen, dass ihr Zwillingsbruder als Kind von Blackfoot Indianern getötet wurde, worauf sie schwor keinen Ehemann zu nehmen bis sie 100 feindliche Krieger mit ihren eigenen Händen getötet hätte. Sie erreichte den Status eines Krieger als sie einen Angriff der Blackfoot auf ein Fort abwehrte, welches Crow und weisse Familien beherbergte. Pine Leaf fuhr fort ihren Stand als Krieger auszubauen, indem sie Blackfoot Dörfer angriff und ihrer Sammlung weitere Skalps und Pferde hinzufügte.[PARAGRAPH:1] Als sie Teil des Rates der Häuptlinge wurde, erlangte sie eine starke Stimme im und hielt den dritt höchsten Rang innerhalb des Stammes. Im Alter von 45 Jahren gab sie die Position des Häuptlings, nach über zwei Dekaden mutiger Führung im Kampf, auf. 1858 bei einem Besuch des Gros Ventre Stammes geriet Pine Leaf in eine Hinterhalt durch deren Krieger und wurde getötet.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Pine Leaf[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War chief of the Crow[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1806 -1858[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Pine Leaf was born a member of the Gros Ventres tribe, but at the age of 10 she was captured and taken prisoner by a Crow raiding party. Pine Leaf continued to increase her standing within her village often raiding Blackfoot villages, and adding to her collection of scalps and horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Made part of the Council of Chiefs, there she became known as Woman Chief, earning a strong voice in the tribes council, ranking the third most prominent person in the whole tribe of 160 lodges. She gave up her position as Chief at age forty-five after over two decades of brave leadership into battle. In 1858, visiting the Gros Ventre tribe, Pine Leaf was ambushed and killed by Gros Ventre warriors.

Although she was very feminine in her dress and appearance, Pine Leaf demonstrated a strong partiality towards masculine habits, often besting her male counterparts in shooting, hunting and horse riding. Accounts state that as a child her twin brother had been killed by the Blackfoot and subsequently she vowed to take no husband until she had killed 100 enemy warriors with her own hands. She achieved the status of a warrior when she single handedly turned back a Blackfoot attack upon a fort that was sheltering Crow and white families. Pine Leaf continued to increase her standing within her village often raiding Blackfoot villages, and adding to her collection of scalps and horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Made part of the Council of Chiefs, there she became known as Woman Chief, earning a strong voice in the tribes council, ranking the third most prominent person in the whole tribe of 160 lodges. She gave up her position as Chief at age forty-five after over two decades of brave leadership into battle. In 1858, visiting the Gros Ventre tribe, Pine Leaf was ambushed and killed by Gros Ventre warriors.

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the bearded visitors to their camps. We are a peaceful people, and if you treat us honorably, you will enjoy our enduring friendship. My name is [OUR_NAME], war chief of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us share the songs of our ancestors at the communal fire tonight.
TEXT.French: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the bearded visitors to their camps. We are a peaceful people, and if you treat us honorably, you will enjoy our enduring friendship. My name is [OUR_NAME], war chief of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us share the songs of our ancestors at the communal fire tonight.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Crow. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Your past treacheries have filled the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] with a great sadness. We do not want to speak with you anymore.
TEXT.French: Your past treacheries have filled the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] with a great sadness. We do not want to speak with you anymore.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: There is nothing to be gained by making peace with you again. We will drive you off the cliffs of this life like bisons.
TEXT.French: There is nothing to be gained by making peace with you again. We will drive you off the cliffs of this life like bisons.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: I have always time to speak with my good friends of the [CT_EMPIRE]. How can the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] aid you?
TEXT.French: I have always time to speak with my good friends of the [CT_EMPIRE]. How can the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] aid you?
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Pine Leaf aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: I'm sorry to inform you that the [CT_CIV_ADJ] are not welcome visitors to our lands, as the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] are greatly troubled by your actions of late. Why do you disturb our peace?
TEXT.French: I'm sorry to inform you that the [CT_CIV_ADJ] are not welcome visitors to our lands, as the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] are greatly troubled by your actions of late. Why do you disturb our peace?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Blackfoot
TEXT.German: Blackfoot:Blackfoot:Blackfoot

TEXT.English: Blackfoot
TEXT.German: Blackfoot

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.
TEXT.French: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Blackfoot Konföderation besteht aus den Nord-Peigan, Süd-Peigan, der Kainai Nation und der Siksika Nation, obwohl eigentlich nur die Siksika als Blackfoot bekannt sind, was sich angeblich von der schwarzen Sohle ihrer Mokasins ableitete. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach der ersten Begegnung mit Pferden in den ersten Dekaden des 18ten Jahrhunderts, übernahmen die Blackfoot schnell ein Leben auf dem Pferderücken und begannen die feindlichen Shoshone und Arapaho von den nordwestlichen Ebenen zu verdrängen um sich eine adequate Versorgung mit Pferden zu sichern. Oft brachen sie zu Angriffen auf um Pferde von den benachbarten Stämmen zu stehlen. Mitte des 18ten Jahrhunderts hatten sie Europäer der Hudson's Bay Company getroffen. 1806 fand das erste aufgezeichnete Treffen mit Amerikanern statt, als sie auf die Expedition von Lewis and Clark trafen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Pcken-Epidemien entvölkerten den Stamm um nach 1800. Alleine die Epidemie 1837 tötete ungefährt 6000 Mitglieder des Stammes. Durch solche Ereignisse geschwächt konnten die Blackfoot gegen die wachsende Zahl der weissen Siedler auf ihrem Land und die Dezimierung der Bison Herden, ihre primäre Nahrungsquelle, kaum noch etwas unternehmen. Im Angesicht der schwindenden Nahrungsversorgung unterzeichneten die Blackfoot den Lame Bull Vertrag von 1855 mit den United States, der den Blackfoot 20.000 Dollar jährlich in Gütern und Dienstleistungen versprach, jedoch unter den Bedingungen, dass ihr Territorium als gemeinsames Jagdgebiet mit den benachbarten Stämmen dienen sollte und dass die Weissen Männer auf Blackfoot Land siedeln durfen. Die letzten Dekaden des 19ten Jahrhunderts bezeugten den fortschreitenden Niedergan der Blackfoot. Um 1880 waren nur noch die Pikuni in Montana geblieben und die Kainai, Siksika, und Piegan nach Kanada geflohen. Dort hofften sie auf bessere Behandlung und eine Möglichkeit ihre Kultur und Lebensart zu erhalten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.

TEXT.English: Blackfoot
TEXT.German: Blackfoot:Blackfoot:Blackfoot:Blackfoot
TEXT.Italian: Blackfoot
TEXT.Spanish: Blackfoot

TEXT.English: Running Eagle

[H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War Chief of the Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1815?-1850?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Running Eagle's life. Even the year of her death is unknown, ranging from 1836-1850. Originally known as Brown Weasel Woman, Running Eagle showed a strong talent for hunting and riding from an early age. When she was 15, she accompanied her father on a hunting party, and rescued him from capture after his horse had been shot by an enemy tribe. Her first war experience was against the Crow, whom had stolen several horses from her village. Running Eagle followed the Crow raiding party back to their camp and attacked two enemy of riders, killing one and reclaiming 11 of the stolen horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Undergoing a vision quest to learn her destiny, Running Eagle received a vision that she was to be a powerful warrior within her tribe. She subsequently took part in and led many war parties, her bravery earning her the name Running Eagle and a place in the warrior society as a war chief. She and five of her warriors were eventually ambushed and clubbed to death by members of the Flathead tribe while trying to steal their horses during a battle.
TEXT.French: [H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War Chief of the Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1815?-1850?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Running Eagle's life. Even the year of her death is unknown, ranging from 1836-1850. Originally known as Brown Weasel Woman, Running Eagle showed a strong talent for hunting and riding from an early age. When she was 15, she accompanied her father on a hunting party, and rescued him from capture after his horse had been shot by an enemy tribe. Her first war experience was against the Crow, whom had stolen several horses from her village. Running Eagle followed the Crow raiding party back to their camp and attacked two enemy of riders, killing one and reclaiming 11 of the stolen horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Undergoing a vision quest to learn her destiny, Running Eagle received a vision that she was to be a powerful warrior within her tribe. She subsequently took part in and led many war parties, her bravery earning her the name Running Eagle and a place in the warrior society as a war chief. She and five of her warriors were eventually ambushed and clubbed to death by members of the Flathead tribe while trying to steal their horses during a battle.
TEXT.German: [H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kriegshäuptling der Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1815-1850[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Wenig ist über das Leben von Running Eagle bekannt. Sogar das Jahr ihres Todes kann lediglich zwischen 1836 und 1850 geschätzt werden. Ursprünglich als Brown Weasel Woman bekannt, zeigte Running Eagle bereits in jungen Jahren ein herausragendes Talent für die Jagd und die Reiterei. Mit 15 begleitete sie ihren Vater bereits auf Jagdausflügen und rettete ihn eines Tages sogar vor der Gefangennahme als sein Pferd von einem feindlichen Stamm erschossen wurde. Ihre ersten Kriegserfahrungen sammelte sie gegen die Crow, als diese mehrere Pferde ihres Stammes gestohlen hatten. Running Eagle verfolgte die Gruppe der Crow bis zu ihrem Lager und griff zweig zwei berittene Feinde gleichzeitig an, von denen sie dann einen tötete. 11 Pferde konnten wiedererlangt werden.[PARAGRAPH:1] Bei einer Visionsprüfung um mehr über ihre Zukunft zu erfahren, erhielt Running Eagle eine Vision, dass sie einst der mächtigste Krieger ihres Stamems werden sollte. Sie beteiligte sich an vielen Kriegsgruppen und erlangte so ihren Namen Running Eagle und eines Platz in der Kriergergesellschaft und letztlich sogar den Titel des Kriegshäuptlings. Sie und 5 weitere ihrer Krieger wurden aber in einen Hinterhalt gelockt und zu Tode geknüppelt, als sie die Pferde eines der Flachlandstämme stehlen wollten.

She subsequently took part in and led many war parties, her bravery earning her the name Running Eagle and a place in the warrior society as a war chief. She and five of her warriors were eventually ambushed and clubbed to death by members of the Flathead tribe while trying to steal their horses during a battle.
