TEXT.English: Welcome, stranger, to the lands of the mighty [OUR_CIV_ADJ] Confederacy. My name is [OUR_NAME], and I hope we can welcome you as a friend, for the legendary warriors of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] are fearsome foes. Let us ask the medicine men to grant our friendship the blessings of the spirits.
TEXT.French: Welcome, stranger, to the lands of the mighty [OUR_CIV_ADJ] Confederacy. My name is [OUR_NAME], and I hope we can welcome you as a friend, for the legendary warriors of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] are fearsome foes. Let us ask the medicine men to grant our friendship the blessings of the spirits.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Blackfoot. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Listening to your words has been my greatest mistake in the past. I never make the same mistake twice.
TEXT.French: Listening to your words has been my greatest mistake in the past. I never make the same mistake twice.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: We will have peace the day I wear your skin as a cloak!
TEXT.French: We will have peace the day I wear your skin as a cloak!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to my teepee, friend. Let us have pow wow and speak of our great feats in battle.
TEXT.French: Welcome to my teepee, friend. Let us have pow wow and speak of our great feats in battle.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Running Eagle aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Oh, it's you again. I was already starting to wonder what made the children cry. What foolishness have you devised this time to annoy the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] with?
TEXT.French: Oh, it's you again. I was already starting to wonder what made the children cry. What foolishness have you devised this time to annoy the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] with?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Volkes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Guaymi
TEXT.German: Guaymi:Guaymi:Guaymi

TEXT.English: Guaymi
TEXT.German: Guaymi

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Guaymi Indians were traditionally located in the remote regions of Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui and Veraguas. Their territory was divided by the Cordillera Central mountain range of modern day Panama and Costa Rico, resulting in the Guaymi being divided between two areas that were climatically and ecologically different. The Guaymi on the Pacific side of the range found themselves scattered throughout small hamlets in remote regions, whereas the Guaymi on the Atlantic side remained in more populated coastal regions. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Spanish first contacted the Guaymi in the early 1500's but attempts to subdue and conquer them largely failed. After a period of armed conflict, Spanish policy resorted to trying to group the Guaymi into settlements controlled by missions. This policy enjoyed only limited success. Some Indians did convert to Christianity and eventually merged with the growing Metiszo community, but most Guaymi retreated further into the remoteness of the mountain rainforests.
TEXT.French: [TAB] The Guaymi Indians were traditionally located in the remote regions of Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui and Veraguas. Their territory was divided by the Cordillera Central mountain range of modern day Panama and Costa Rico, resulting in the Guaymi being divided between two areas that were climatically and ecologically different. The Guaymi on the Pacific side of the range found themselves scattered throughout small hamlets in remote regions, whereas the Guaymi on the Atlantic side remained in more populated coastal regions. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Spanish first contacted the Guaymi in the early 1500's but attempts to subdue and conquer them largely failed. After a period of armed conflict, Spanish policy resorted to trying to group the Guaymi into settlements controlled by missions. This policy enjoyed only limited success. Some Indians did convert to Christianity and eventually merged with the growing Metiszo community, but most Guaymi retreated further into the remoteness of the mountain rainforests.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Guaymi Indianer waren traditionell in den entlegenen Gegenden von Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui und Veraguas beheimatet. Ihr Territorium war unterteilt durch die Cordillera Zentralgebirgskette des heutigen Panama und Costa Rico, was dazu führte, dass die Guaymi auf zwei sehr unterschiedliche klimatischen und ökologische Gebiete verteilt waren. Die Guaymi auf der Pazifikseite der Gebirgskette lebten verteilt und abgeschieden, wohingegen die Guaymi auf der Atlantikseite der Gebirgskette in vergleichsweise bevölkerungsreichen Gebieten lebten.[PARAGRAPH:1] Die Spanier erlangten den ersten Kontakt mit den Guaymi in den frühen 1500ern aber Versuche sie zu unterwerfen oder zu erobern blieben erfolglos. Nach einer Periode des bewaffneten Konflikts versuchten die Spaniern die Guaymi zu bewegen in grösseren Siedlungen zu leben, die durch Missionen kontrolliert wurden. Aber auch diese Vorgehen war nur wenig erfolgreich. Einige Indianer konvertierten zwar zum Christentum und verschmolzen letztlich auch mit den spanischen Kolonisten, die meisten Guaymi zogen sich aber weiter in die Abgeschiedenheit des Regenwaldes zurück.

TEXT.English: Uracca

[H1]Uracca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Guaymi[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Late 1400's -1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Urraca was the most famous of three chieftains, the other two being Nata and Parita, all of whom fought against the Spanish conquistadors. He defeated the Spanish several times and in 1522, he achieved the distinction of being the only Indian leader ever force a captain of the Spanish Empire, Diego de Albitez, to sign a peace treaty. [PARAGRAPH:1] After this stunning success, Urraca was subsequently captured by the conquistadors, but he managed to escape, rejoining his people and continuing the fight against the Spanish until his death in 1531.
TEXT.French: [H1]Uracca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Guaymi[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Late 1400's -1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Urraca was the most famous of three chieftains, the other two being Nata and Parita, all of whom fought against the Spanish conquistadors. Er besiegte die Spanier mehrfach und 1522 schaffte er was noch kein Ureinwohner je zuvor geschafft hatte, er zwang einen Captain des Spanischen Empire, Diego de Albitez, ein Friedensabkommen zu unterzeichnen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach diesem erstaunlichen Erfolg wurde Urraca jedoch von den Conquistadores gefanngen genommen, konnte aber entkommen und nahm mit seinem Volk den Kampf gegen die Spanier wieder auf, den er bis zu seinem Tod 1531 fortführte.

TEXT.English: My name is [OUR_NAME], and I welcome you to the lands of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Join us in our city to watch the stick throwing games, and tell us about your people.
TEXT.French: My name is [OUR_NAME], and I welcome you to the lands of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Join us in our city to watch the stick throwing games, and tell us about your people.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Guaymi. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: The presence of you cockroaches is a pollution of the rainforest. Leave us alone.
TEXT.French: The presence of you cockroaches is a pollution of the rainforest. Leave us alone.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Do you think I'm daft? The only way for the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] to survive is by wiping out every last one of you!
TEXT.French: Do you think I'm daft? The only way for the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] to survive is by wiping out every last one of you!
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the emissaries of the [CT_CIV_ADJ] into their cities. Let us strengthen our friendship and play some games together.
TEXT.French: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the emissaries of the [CT_CIV_ADJ] into their cities. Let us strengthen our friendship and play some games together.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Urraca aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: I will waste no words of welcome on you, as you do not have the ability to appreciate them anyway. Why are you bothering us?
TEXT.French: I will waste no words of welcome on you, as you do not have the ability to appreciate them anyway. Why are you bothering us?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Volkes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.

TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: Tarascans
TEXT.German: Tarascans:Tarascans:Tarascans

TEXT.English: Tarascans
TEXT.German: Tarascans

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Tarascans were a pre-Columbian civilization whose territory at the time of the Spanish conquest was the second largest state in Mesoamerica. According to the Relacion de Michoacan, a 14th century leader of the P'orhepecha people, named Tariacuri forged the tribes around Lake Patzcuaro into the Tarascan state, placing his sons as overlords to newly acquired territory. Tariacuri died in 1350, but his sons continued their father's work, incorporating the Tarascan Sierra and the Balsas River into the Tarascans expanding sphere of influence. [PARAGRAPH:1] From the mid 15th century until the arrival of the Spanish, the Tarascans found themselves competing against the expanding empire of the Aztecs in a series of wars. The Tarascan empire blocked Aztec expansion to the northwest, fortifying and patrolling their frontiers against attacks from ethnic groups allied with or subjugated to the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing of the defeat of the Aztecs, Tangaxuan II, the last Cazonci of the Tarascans, sent emissaries with gifts to the Spanish. Interested by gifts of gold, the Cortes sent a Spanish force under Cristobal de Olid in 1522 to the Tarascan capital of Tzintzuntzan. Tangaxuan submitted to Spanish authority in return for maintaining a large degree of autonomy over his people, and for the next few years both he and the Spanish considered themselves rulers of the empire, with each collecting tribute from the populace. By 1530 the Spanish realized that Tangaxuan was still in effect in control of his empire and dispatched the conquistador Nuno de Guzman to execute him. With the death of Tangaxuan, the Tarascans empire quickly collapsed losing their independence to the Spanish. In 1543 it officially became the governorship of Michoacan.
TEXT.French: [TAB] The Tarascans were a pre-Columbian civilization whose territory at the time of the Spanish conquest was the second largest state in Mesoamerica. According to the Relacion de Michoacan, a 14th century leader of the P'orhepecha people, named Tariacuri forged the tribes around Lake Patzcuaro into the Tarascan state, placing his sons as overlords to newly acquired territory. Tariacuri died in 1350, but his sons continued their father's work, incorporating the Tarascan Sierra and the Balsas River into the Tarascans expanding sphere of influence. [PARAGRAPH:1] From the mid 15th century until the arrival of the Spanish, the Tarascans found themselves competing against the expanding empire of the Aztecs in a series of wars. The Tarascan empire blocked Aztec expansion to the northwest, fortifying and patrolling their frontiers against attacks from ethnic groups allied with or subjugated to the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing of the defeat of the Aztecs, Tangaxuan II, the last Cazonci of the Tarascans, sent emissaries with gifts to the Spanish. Interested by gifts of gold, the Cortes sent a Spanish force under Cristobal de Olid in 1522 to the Tarascan capital of Tzintzuntzan. Tangaxuan submitted to Spanish authority in return for maintaining a large degree of autonomy over his people, and for the next few years both he and the Spanish considered themselves rulers of the empire, with each collecting tribute from the populace. By 1530 the Spanish realized that Tangaxuan was still in effect in control of his empire and dispatched the conquistador Nuno de Guzman to execute him. With the death of Tangaxuan, the Tarascans empire quickly collapsed losing their independence to the Spanish. In 1543 it officially became the governorship of Michoacan.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Tarascans waren eine pre-columbianische Zivilisation deren Territorium zur Zeit der Spanischen Eroberung das zweit grösste in Mittelamerika war. Der 'Relacion de Michoacan' zufolge, vereinte im 14ten Jahrhundert ein Führer der P'orhepecha namens Tariacuri die Stämme um den Lake Patzcuaro zum Staat der Tarascans und setzte seinen Sohn als Oberführer des neu erworbenen Gebietes ein. Tariacuri starb 1350, aber sein Sohn setzte seine Arbeit fort und fügte weitere Gebiete der wachsenden Einflussphere hinzu. [PARAGRAPH:1] Ab Mitte des 15ten Jahrhunderts bis zur Ankunft der Spaniern befanden die Tarascans sich in einem Wettstreit um die Vorherrschaft in diesem Gebiet mit den ebenfalls stark expandierenden Imperium der Azteken, der auch in einer Reihe von Kriegen ausgetragen wurde. Die Tarascans blockierten eine weitere Ausdehnung der Azteken in den Nordwesten und befestigten ihre Grenzen gegen ethnische Gruppen, die mit den Azteken verbündet oder von diesen unterworfen waren. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nachdem Tangaxuan II, der letzte Cazonci der Tarascans, von der Niederlange der Azteken gehört hatte, schickte er Abgesandte mit Geschenken zu den Spaniern. Durch die Geschenke aus Gold angelockt, entsandte Cortes 1522 eine spanische Streitmacht untder dem Kommmando von Cristobal de Olid nach Tzintzuntzan, der Hauptstadt der Tarascans. Tangaxuan unterwarf sich der spanischen Authorität um einen teilweise Autonomie für sein Volk erhalten zu können. 1530 erkannten die Spanier, dass Tangaxuan tatsächlich noch die volle Kontrolle über sein Imperium hielt und entsandten den Conquistador Nuno de Guzman um ihn hinzurichten. Mit dem Tod von Tangaxuan kollabierte das Imperium der Tarascans schnell und verlor jegliche Unabhängigkeit an die Spaniern. 1543 wurde es offiziell zum Gouverneursbezirk Michoacan.

According to the Relacion de Michoacan, a 14th century leader of the P'orhepecha people, named Tariacuri forged the tribes around Lake Patzcuaro into the Tarascan state, placing his sons as overlords to newly acquired territory. Tariacuri died in 1350, but his sons continued their father's work, incorporating the Tarascan Sierra and the Balsas River into the Tarascans expanding sphere of influence. [PARAGRAPH:1] From the mid 15th century until the arrival of the Spanish, the Tarascans found themselves competing against the expanding empire of the Aztecs in a series of wars. The Tarascan empire blocked Aztec expansion to the northwest, fortifying and patrolling their frontiers against attacks from ethnic groups allied with or subjugated to the Aztecs. With the death of Tangaxuan, the Tarascans empire quickly collapsed losing their independence to the Spanish. In 1543 it officially became the governorship of Michoacan.

TEXT.English: Erendira

[H1]Erendira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Princess of the Tarascans[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1503-1530?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Erendira was a princess of the Tarascan people. She was 16 or 17 years old when the Spanish came to Mexico. After the downfall of their enemies the Aztecs, her uncle Tangaxuan II surrendered full autonomy of his kingdom, opting to rule with the Spanish, but was eventually executed by Spanish Conquistadores in 1530.[PARAGRAPH:1] Little is known of Erendira’'s role during this period, some legends and oral traditions claim that she rallied and led a military force that attacked the Spaniards, and that she personally killed a Conquistador and took his horse, later using the animal to teach her people how to ride, though there is no historical evidence to support this. As in life, Erendira’'s fate is also shrouded in mystery. Several stories claimed she committed suicide, others that she retreated to the mountains to train her people to fight, and a further story states that she was kidnapped by her own people and put into a temple so that the Spaniards would never find her. The only certainty historians and scholars have is that soon after the fall of the Tarascan empire, Erendira’s name disappeared from historical records.
TEXT.French: [H1]Erendira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Princess of the Tarascans[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1503-1530?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Erendira was a princess of the Tarascan people. She was 16 or 17 years old when the Spanish came to Mexico. After the downfall of their enemies the Aztecs, her uncle Tangaxuan II surrendered full autonomy of his kingdom, opting to rule with the Spanish, but was eventually executed by Spanish Conquistadores in 1530.[PARAGRAPH:1] Little is known of Erendira’'s role during this period, some legends and oral traditions claim that she rallied and led a military force that attacked the Spaniards, and that she personally killed a Conquistador and took his horse, later using the animal to teach her people how to ride, though there is no historical evidence to support this. As in life, Erendira’'s fate is also shrouded in mystery. Several stories claimed she committed suicide, others that she retreated to the mountains to train her people to fight, and a further story states that she was kidnapped by her own people and put into a temple so that the Spaniards would never find her. The only certainty historians and scholars have is that soon after the fall of the Tarascan empire, Erendira’s name disappeared from historical records.
TEXT.German: [H1]Erendira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prinzessin der Tarascans[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]1503-1530?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Erendira war eine Prinzessin des Tarascan Volkes. Sie war 16 oder 17 als die Spanier nach Mexiko kamen. Nach dem Fall ihrer Feinde der Azteken, unterwarf ihr Onkel Tangaxuan II die volle Autonomie des Königreiches an die Spanier in der Hoffnung noch ein wenig Macht zu erhalten. Letztlich wurde er aber durch spanische Conquistadores 1530 hingerichtet.[PARAGRAPH:1] Wenig ist über Erendiras Rolle während dieser Periode bekannt. Einige Legenden und münldiche überlieferungen behaupten aber, dass sie eine Streitmacht versammelte und gegen die Spanier führte. Es wird sogar erzählt, dass sie persönlich eine Conquistador tötete und sein Pferd nahm, um damit später ihrem Volk das Reiten beizubringen. Es gibt jedoch für diese Geschichten keinerlei historische Beweise. Ihr letztes Schicksal ist ebenfalls von Mythen vernebelt. Einige Geschichten erzählen, dass sie Selbstmord beging, andere dass sie in die Berge floh um dort ihr Volk im Kampft auszubilden und wieder andere, dass sie von ihrem Volk in einem Tempel versteckt wurde, damit die Spanier sie niemals finden sollten. Die einzige Gewissheit die Historiker haben ist die, dass kurz nach dem Fall des Tarascan Imperiums auch der Name Erendira in keiner historischen Aufzeichnung mehr auftauchte.

The only certainty historians and scholars have is that soon after the fall of the Tarascan empire, Erendira’s name disappeared from historical records.

TEXT.English: The people of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] Empire greet the visitors from over the sea. I am [OUR_NAME], leader of our many cities. Be warned that we are a strong and proud nation, and do not tolerate disrespect.
TEXT.French: The people of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] Empire greet the visitors from over the sea. I am [OUR_NAME], leader of our many cities. Be warned that we are a strong and proud nation, and do not tolerate disrespect.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Tarascans. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: I'm not willing to talk with someone so vastly inferior in wisdom, strength and honor. Scurry off to the cesspits you use as your living places.
TEXT.French: I'm not willing to talk with someone so vastly inferior in wisdom, strength and honor. Scurry off to the cesspits you use as your living places.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Does the jaguar ever make peace with the tapir? It is only natural that my warriors continue killing yours.
TEXT.French: Does the jaguar ever make peace with the tapir? It is only natural that my warriors continue killing yours.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the [CT_CIV_ADJ] in their grand cities. I consider you to be a friend of my people. I trust that our conversation will reflect your ecstasy about having this great honor bestowed upon you.
TEXT.French: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the [CT_CIV_ADJ] in their grand cities. I consider you to be a friend of my people. I trust that our conversation will reflect your ecstasy about having this great honor bestowed upon you.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Erendira aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: The beggars of the [CT_EMPIRE] are here again to grovel at my feet. Tell us why you are here, and I may decide to let you leave while still being in possession of the regular number of limbs.
TEXT.French: The beggars of the [CT_EMPIRE] are here again to grovel at my feet. Tell us why you are here, and I may decide to let you leave while still being in possession of the regular number of limbs.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Omagua
TEXT.German: Omagua:Omagua:Omagua

TEXT.English: Omagua
TEXT.German: Omagua

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Omaguas, also known as the Cambeba, were spread in two large groupings within the Amazon Valley. One group occupied the upper Napo and the other the upper Amazon. Until the 17th century the upper Amazon was almost entirely inhabited by the Omagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] The first significant reports of the Omagua, were recorded by Gaspar de Carvajal, a Dominican priest who accompanied Francisco de Orellana's 1542 expedition that traversed the Amazon River. Carvajal reported a populous, organized society whose control extended hundreds of miles along the river, though wrote very little about the people of the Amazon, mostly because they were always trying to kill him. Orellana's party received a cold reception on many parts of the Amazon, particularly from the Machipara and Omagua’s, who attacked the Spanish incessantly, killing and wounding several. In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado. During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Omagua, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.

During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Omagua, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Omagua, auch als Cambeba bekannt, waren auf zwei grosse Gruppierungen innerhalb des Amazonas Gebietes verteilt. Die eine Gruppe siedelte am oberen Napo und die andere am oberen Amazon. Bis zum 17ten Jahrhundert war der obere Amazonas fast vollständig durch die Omagua besiedelt. [PARAGRAPH:1] Die ersten signifikanten Berichte über die Omagua wurden von Gaspar de Carvajal, einem Dominikanischen Priester, aufgezeichnet, der 1542 die Expedition von Francisco de Orellana begleitete, die entlang des Amazonas reiste. Carvajal berichtete von einer bevölkerungsreichen und organisierten Gesellschaft, die hunderte von Meilen entlang des Amazonas kontrollierte, schrieb jedoch sehr wenig über die Menschen des Amazonas selbst, was hauptsächlich daran lag, dass diese versuchten ihn zu töten. Orellanas Gruppe erhielt einen eisigen Empfang durch die Omagua, die unaufhörlich die Spanier angriffenund viele töteten oder verwundeten. Um Vorräte zu erhalten befahl Orellana seinen Männern in seiner Verzweiflung die Dörfer dieser Ureinwohner anzugreifen. Am 21. Mai 1542 passierte Orellana den Mündung des Madeira und lies die Machipara und Omagua Gebiete hinter sich. Orellana starb 1546 bei seiner zweiten Reise in den Amazonas.[PARAGRAPH:1] Pedro de Ursua, der Geschichten über den Reichtum der Omagua gehört hatte, führte 1560 eine weitere Expedition entlang des Amazonas. Ausser Gerüchten über die mystische Stadt El Dorado fand er nichts.[PARAGRAPH:1] Im 16ten und 17ten Jahrhundert führte Krankheiten, die durch die Europäer eingeschleppt worden waren zu einem Bevölkerungskollaps unter den Omagua, worauf diese ihre Städte verliesen, in den Regenwald flohen und einen nomadischen Lebensstil annahmen.

TEXT.English: Aomagua

[H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Omagua[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early to mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of any individual Omagua cacique. The expeditions of Orellana and Ursua, rarely mentioned the names of native individuals, and when they did they often confused the name of the tribe with that of the village and its leader. Thus the leader of the Omagua is often referred to as Aomagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] Aomagua ordered several waves of attacks against the Spanish under Orellana in an attempt to wear the Spanish down and defeat them. His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. It was probably warriors from one of the Omagua tribes who displaying long hair and bone earrings, were likely mistaken as women warriors, fueling the story that would eventually give the region its name, Amazon, after the Greek legend.
TEXT.French: [H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Omagua[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early to mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of any individual Omagua cacique. The expeditions of Orellana and Ursua, rarely mentioned the names of native individuals, and when they did they often confused the name of the tribe with that of the village and its leader. Thus the leader of the Omagua is often referred to as Aomagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] Aomagua ordered several waves of attacks against the Spanish under Orellana in an attempt to wear the Spanish down and defeat them. His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. It was probably warriors from one of the Omagua tribes who displaying long hair and bone earrings, were likely mistaken as women warriors, fueling the story that would eventually give the region its name, Amazon, after the Greek legend.
TEXT.German: [H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique der Omagua[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]Mitte des 16ten Jahrhunderts[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Wenig ist über einzelne Cacique der Omagua bekannt. Die Expeditionen von Orellana und Ursua, nannten kaum Namen einzelner Individuen, und falls doch wurden oft Namen von Stämmen mit Ortschaften oder deren Anführern durcheinander gebracht. Daher wird der Anführer der Omagua oft als Aomagua bezeichnet. [PARAGRAPH:1] Es ist jedoch bekannt, dass der Aomagua mehrere Angriffswellen gegen die Spanier unter Orellana befahl, um die Spanier aufzureiben und letztlich zu besiegen. Seine Anstrengungen waren nicht erfolgreich aber die fortwährende Aggression war genug, um die Orellana zu überzeugen schnellstmöglich das Territorium zu durchqueren. Es waren vermutlich die Omagua, die mit ihrem langen Haar und den Knochenohrringen leicht für Frauenkriegerinnen gehalten werden konnten, die den Amazonas aufgrund der griechischen Legende weiblicher Kriegerinnen den Namen gaben.

TEXT.English: I, [OUR_NAME], represent the prosperous and wealthy nation of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Join me in a banquet together with the nobles of my people, and you will see that peace and cooperation between our nations will benefit us both.
TEXT.French: I, [OUR_NAME], represent the prosperous and wealthy nation of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Join me in a banquet together with the nobles of my people, and you will see that peace and cooperation between our nations will benefit us both.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Omagua. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: We do not speak with traitors. Deadlier than your diseases are your words.
TEXT.French: We do not speak with traitors. Deadlier than your diseases are your words.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Peace is not in the interests of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ensuring that you cannot repeat your past crimes, however, is.
TEXT.French: Peace is not in the interests of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ensuring that you cannot repeat your past crimes, however, is.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the grand jungles of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us speak of the prosperity that has resulted from our friendship. Please enjoy our hospitality during your stay.
TEXT.French: Welcome to the grand jungles of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us speak of the prosperity that has resulted from our friendship. Please enjoy our hospitality during your stay.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Aomagua aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Not you again. If you only had never come to these lands, and left us in peace! What is it this time?
TEXT.French: Not you again. If you only had never come to these lands, and left us in peace! What is it this time?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Mapuche
TEXT.German: Mapuche:Mapuche:Mapuche

TEXT.English: Mapuche
TEXT.German: Mapuche

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Mapuche are a tribe that originally inhabited parts of present day south-central Chile and southwestern Argentina. Despite a lack of centralized organization, the Mapuche were successful in resisting attempts to subjugate them from their much larger neighbor to the north, the Inca. [PARAGRAPH:1] After the conquest of Chile by the Spanish in the late 16thcentury, the Mapuche continued to successfully repel Spanish incursions into their territory, for nearly 300 years using the natural geographical boundary of the Bio-Bio River to assist them. During this period of Mapuche resistance, the Mapuche often fluctuated between periods of fighting and trading with the Spanish and Chileans. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the late 18th century, many Mapuche leaders had finally come to accept the sovereignty of the Spanish king, but with the understanding that they continued to retain de facto control and independence over their own people and territory. During the Chilean War of Independence, 1810-26, Mapuche leaders sided with both the Spanish and the Chileans, playing each side against the other to gain the most favorable advantage for themselves, though most looked on the war with indifference. After the Chileans gained Independence, the Mapuche for the most part in Araucania and Patagonia remained autonomous until the Chilean Occupation of Araucania and the Argentine Conquest of the Desert in late 19th century, when they were removed to reservations.

Despite a lack of centralized organization, the Mapuche were successful in resisting attempts to subjugate them from their much larger neighbor to the north, the Inca. [PARAGRAPH:1] After the conquest of Chile by the Spanish in the late 16thcentury, the Mapuche continued to successfully repel Spanish incursions into their territory, for nearly 300 years using the natural geographical boundary of the Bio-Bio River to assist them. During this period of Mapuche resistance, the Mapuche often fluctuated between periods of fighting and trading with the Spanish and Chileans. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the late 18th century, many Mapuche leaders had finally come to accept the sovereignty of the Spanish king, but with the understanding that they continued to retain de facto control and independence over their own people and territory. During the Chilean War of Independence, 1810-26, Mapuche leaders sided with both the Spanish and the Chileans, playing each side against the other to gain the most favorable advantage for themselves, though most looked on the war with indifference. After the Chileans gained Independence, the Mapuche for the most part in Araucania and Patagonia remained autonomous until the Chilean Occupation of Araucania and the Argentine Conquest of the Desert in late 19th century, when they were removed to reservations.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Mapuche sind ein Stamm, der ursprünglich Teile des heutigen Chile und südwestlichen Argentinien bewohnte. Trotz des Fehlens einer zentralen Organisation waren die Mapuche erfolgreich darin, sich gegen eine Unterwerfung durch ihre viel grösseren Nachbarn die Inka zu wehren. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach der Eroberung Chiles durch die Spanier im späten 16ten Jahrhundert fuhren die Mapuche 300 Jahre erfolgreich damit fort das spanische Eindringen in ihr Territorium abzuwehren. In dieser Periode fluktuierte die Beziehung der Mapuche zu den Spaniern und Chilenen oft zwischen Kampf und Handel. [PARAGRAPH:1] Im späten 18ten Jahrhundert hatte viele Anführer der Mapuche letztlich die Oberherrschaft des spanischen Königs anerkannt, behielten aber das Verständnis bei, dass sie de facto weiterhin die Kontrolle über ihr Volk und ihre Territorien inne hielen. Im Chilenischen Unabhängigkeitskrieg 1810-26 unterstützen Mapuche Anführer beide Seiten, die Spanier, wie auch die Chilenen, spieleten diese gegeneinander aus und suchten ihre eigenen Vorteile. Nach der Unabhängigkeit Chiles, blieben die Mapuche, die hauptsächlich in Araucania und Patagonia lebten, weitgehend autonom. Dies änderte sich erst durch die Chilenische Unterdrückung und die Argentinische Eroberung im späten 19ten Jahrhundert, als sie in Reservate umgesiedelt wurden.

During this period of Mapuche resistance, the Mapuche often fluctuated between periods of fighting and trading with the Spanish and Chileans. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the late 18th century, many Mapuche leaders had finally come to accept the sovereignty of the Spanish king, but with the understanding that they continued to retain de facto control and independence over their own people and territory. During the Chilean War of Independence, 1810-26, Mapuche leaders sided with both the Spanish and the Chileans, playing each side against the other to gain the most favorable advantage for themselves, though most looked on the war with indifference. After the Chileans gained Independence, the Mapuche for the most part in Araucania and Patagonia remained autonomous until the Chilean Occupation of Araucania and the Argentine Conquest of the Desert in late 19th century, when they were removed to reservations.

TEXT.English: Lautaro

[H1]Lautaro[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Toqui of the Mapuche[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1534-1557[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Lautaro was a young military commander of the Mapuche who fought in the Arauco War against the Spanish. Captured as a boy in 1546, Lautaro, became the personal servant of Don Pedro de Valdivia, Spanish conqueror of Chile. While in captivity Lautaro learned the military practice and tactics of the Spanish army. Escaping the Spanish in 1552, Lautaro returned to his people just as they had decided to make war and expel the Spanish invaders from their lands. Leading 6,000 men he attacked the Spanish garrison of Fort Tucapel, forcing the Spanish to retreat and then defeating a smaller Spanish army sent to retake the fort. During this battle his former master Pedro de Valdivia who led the Spanish forces was captured and killed. [PARAGRAPH:1] Given the Mapuche tradition that dictated a lengthy victory celebration, Lautaro was unable to immediately follow up on his success at Tucapel. However, the following year saw further success against the Spanish at the Battle of Marihuenu, and the burning of the city of Concepcion. Despite famine and a smallpox epidemic that reduced his army's size, Lautaro again attacked Concepcion in 1555, and then fought the Spanish at the Battle of Peteroa, although this time he was forced to retreat in order to save his army. In the spring of 1557, Lautaro decided to attack Santiago. Yet his plans were forestalled at the Battle of Mataquito, where a surprise Spanish attack on his encampment saw Lautaro killed and his forces decisively beaten. After the battle, Lautaro's head was cut off displayed in Santiago's plaza.
TEXT.French: [H1]Lautaro[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Toqui of the Mapuche[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1534-1557[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Lautaro was a young military commander of the Mapuche who fought in the Arauco War against the Spanish. Captured as a boy in 1546, Lautaro, became the personal servant of Don Pedro de Valdivia, Spanish conqueror of Chile. While in captivity Lautaro learned the military practice and tactics of the Spanish army. Escaping the Spanish in 1552, Lautaro returned to his people just as they had decided to make war and expel the Spanish invaders from their lands. Leading 6,000 men he attacked the Spanish garrison of Fort Tucapel, forcing the Spanish to retreat and then defeating a smaller Spanish army sent to retake the fort. During this battle his former master Pedro de Valdivia who led the Spanish forces was captured and killed. [PARAGRAPH:1] Given the Mapuche tradition that dictated a lengthy victory celebration, Lautaro was unable to immediately follow up on his success at Tucapel. However, the following year saw further success against the Spanish at the Battle of Marihuenu, and the burning of the city of Concepcion. Despite famine and a smallpox epidemic that reduced his army's size, Lautaro again attacked Concepcion in 1555, and then fought the Spanish at the Battle of Peteroa, although this time he was forced to retreat in order to save his army. In the spring of 1557, Lautaro decided to attack Santiago. Yet his plans were forestalled at the Battle of Mataquito, where a surprise Spanish attack on his encampment saw Lautaro killed and his forces decisively beaten. After the battle, Lautaro's head was cut off displayed in Santiago's plaza.
TEXT.German: [H1]Lautaro[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Toqui der Mapuche[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]1534-1557[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Lautaro war ein junger Militärbefehlshaber der Mapuche, der im Arauco Kriege gegen die Spanier kämpfte. 1546 als Junge gefangen genommen, wurde Lautaro der persönliche Diener von Don Pedro de Valdivia, spanischer Eroberer von Chile. Während seiner Gefangenschaft lernte er die militärischen Praktiken und Taktiken der spanischen Armee. Nach seiner Flucht vor den Spaniern 1552, kehrte Lautaro zu seinem Volk zurück als diese gerade beschlossen hatten gegen die Spanier Krieg zu führen um sie von ihrem Land zu vertreiben. Mit 6000 Mann griff er die Garnison Fort Tucapel an, zwang die Spanier zum Rückzug und besiegte eine kleinere Armee, die das Fort wieder einnehmen sollte. Während dieser Schlacht wurde sein früherer Herr Pedro de Valdivia, der die spanischen Truppen führte, gefangen und später getötet. [PARAGRAPH:1] Aufgrund der Mapuche Tradition, die auf diesen Sieg eine lange Siegesfeier forderte, konnten Lautaro seinen Sieg jedoch nicht gleich weiter ausnutzen. Jedoch erlangte er im folgenden Jahre weitere Erfolge gegen die Spanier bei der Schlacht von Marihuenu und bei der Niederbrennung der Stadt Concepcion. Trotz Hunger und einer Pockenepidemie, die seine Armee stark reduzierten, griff Lautaro 1555 Concepcion erneut an und kämpfte dann gegen die Spanier in der Schlacht von Peteroa, war jedoch dieses Mal gezwungen selbst den Rückzug anzutreten.Im Frühjahr 1557 entschied Lautaro Santiago anzugreifen. Sein Plan wurde jedoch durch die Schlacht von Mataquito verhindert, als ein spanischer überaschungsangriff zu einer entscheidenden Niederlage seiner Truppen und dem Tod von Lautaro selbst führte. Nach der Schlacht wurde der abgetrennte Kopf von Lautaro auf dem Plaza in Santiago aufgestellt.

In the spring of 1557, Lautaro decided to attack Santiago. Yet his plans were forestalled at the Battle of Mataquito, where a surprise Spanish attack on his encampment saw Lautaro killed and his forces decisively beaten. After the battle, Lautaro's head was cut off displayed in Santiago's plaza.

TEXT.English: Chief Joseph

[H1]Chief Joseph[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Nez Perce[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1840 - 1904 AD[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Hin-mah-too-yah-lat-kekt, Hinmatóowyalahtqqit in Americanist orthography, popularly known as Chief Joseph, or Young Joseph (March 3, 1840 - September 21, 1904), succeeded his father Tuekakas (Chief Joseph the Elder) as the leader of the Wal-lam-wat-kain (Wallowa) band of Nez Perce, a Native American tribe indigenous to the Wallowa Valley in northeastern Oregon, in the interior Pacific Northwest region of the United States. He led his band during the most tumultuous period in their contemporary history when they were forcibly removed from their ancestral lands in the Wallowa Valley by the United States federal government and forced to move northeast, onto the significantly reduced reservation in Lapwai, Idaho Territory. A series of events which culminated in episodes of violence led those Nez Perce who resisted removal including Joseph's band and an allied band of the Palouse tribe to take flight to attempt to reach political asylum, ultimately with the Sioux chief Sitting Bull in Canada. They were pursued by the U.S. Army in a campaign led by General Oliver O. Howard. This 1,170-mile (1,900 km) fighting retreat by the Nez Perce in 1877 became known as the Nez Perce War. The skill with which the Nez Perce fought and the manner in which they conducted themselves in the face of incredible adversity led to widespread admiration among their military adversaries and the American public. Coverage of the war in United States newspapers led to widespread recognition of Joseph and the Nez Perce. For his principled resistance to the removal, he became renowned as a humanitarian and peacemaker. However, modern scholars like Robert McCoy and Thomas Guthrie argue that this coverage, as well as Joseph's speeches and writings, distorted the true nature of Joseph's thoughts and gave rise to a "mythical" Chief Joseph as a "red Napoleon" that served the interests of the Anglo-American narrative of manifest destiny. Joseph the Younger succeeded his father as leader of the Wallowa band in 1871. The non-treaty Nez Perce suffered many injustices at the hands of settlers and prospectors, but out of fear of reprisal from the militarily superior Americans, Joseph never allowed any violence against them, instead making many concessions to them in hopes of securing peace. In 1873, Joseph negotiated with the federal government to ensure his people could stay on their land in the Wallowa Valley. But in 1877, the government reversed its policy, and Army General Oliver Howard threatened to attack if the Wallowa band did not relocate to the Idaho Reservation with the other Nez Perce. Joseph reluctantly agreed. Before the outbreak of hostilities, General Howard held a council at Fort Lapwai to try to convince Joseph and his people to relocate. Joseph finished his address to the general, which focused on human equality, by expressing his "[disbelief that] the Great Spirit Chief gave one kind of men the right to tell another kind of men what they must do." Howard reacted angrily, interpreting the statement as a challenge to his authority. When Toohoolhoolzote protested, he was jailed for five days. The day following the council, Joseph, White Bird, and Looking Glass all accompanied Howard to look at different areas. Howard offered them a plot of land that was inhabited by Whites and Native Americans, promising to clear them out. Joseph and his chieftains refused, adhering to their tribal tradition of not taking what did not belong to them. Unable to find any suitable uninhabited land on the reservation, Howard informed Joseph that his people had thirty days to collect their livestock and move to the reservation. Joseph pleaded for more time, but Howard told him that he would consider their presence in the Wallowa Valley beyond the thirty-day mark an act of war. Returning home, Joseph called a council among his people. At the council, he spoke on behalf of peace, preferring to abandon his father's grave over war. Toohoolhoolzote, insulted by his incarceration, advocated war. The Wallowa band began making preparations for the long journey, meeting first with other bands at Rocky Canyon. At this council too, many leaders urged war, while Joseph argued in favor of peace. While the council was underway, a young man whose father had been killed rode up and announced that he and several other young men had already killed four white settlers. Still hoping to avoid further bloodshed, Joseph and other non-treaty Nez Perce leaders began moving people away from Idaho.
TEXT.French: [H1]Chief Joseph[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chief of the Nez Perce[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c. 1840 - 1904 AD[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Hin-mah-too-yah-lat-kekt, Hinmatóowyalahtqqit in Americanist orthography, popularly known as Chief Joseph, or Young Joseph (March 3, 1840 - September 21, 1904), succeeded his father Tuekakas (Chief Joseph the Elder) as the leader of the Wal-lam-wat-kain (Wallowa) band of Nez Perce, a Native American tribe indigenous to the Wallowa Valley in northeastern Oregon, in the interior Pacific Northwest region of the United States. He led his band during the most tumultuous period in their contemporary history when they were forcibly removed from their ancestral lands in the Wallowa Valley by the United States federal government and forced to move northeast, onto the significantly reduced reservation in Lapwai, Idaho Territory. A series of events which culminated in episodes of violence led those Nez Perce who resisted removal including Joseph's band and an allied band of the Palouse tribe to take flight to attempt to reach political asylum, ultimately with the Sioux chief Sitting Bull in Canada. They were pursued by the U.S. Army in a campaign led by General Oliver O. Howard. This 1,170-mile (1,900 km) fighting retreat by the Nez Perce in 1877 became known as the Nez Perce War. The skill with which the Nez Perce fought and the manner in which they conducted themselves in the face of incredible adversity led to widespread admiration among their military adversaries and the American public. Coverage of the war in United States newspapers led to widespread recognition of Joseph and the Nez Perce. For his principled resistance to the removal, he became renowned as a humanitarian and peacemaker. However, modern scholars like Robert McCoy and Thomas Guthrie argue that this coverage, as well as Joseph's speeches and writings, distorted the true nature of Joseph's thoughts and gave rise to a "mythical" Chief Joseph as a "red Napoleon" that served the interests of the Anglo-American narrative of manifest destiny. Joseph the Younger succeeded his father as leader of the Wallowa band in 1871. The non-treaty Nez Perce suffered many injustices at the hands of settlers and prospectors, but out of fear of reprisal from the militarily superior Americans, Joseph never allowed any violence against them, instead making many concessions to them in hopes of securing peace. In 1873, Joseph negotiated with the federal government to ensure his people could stay on their land in the Wallowa Valley. But in 1877, the government reversed its policy, and Army General Oliver Howard threatened to attack if the Wallowa band did not relocate to the Idaho Reservation with the other Nez Perce. Joseph reluctantly agreed. Before the outbreak of hostilities, General Howard held a council at Fort Lapwai to try to convince Joseph and his people to relocate. Joseph finished his address to the general, which focused on human equality, by expressing his "[disbelief that] the Great Spirit Chief gave one kind of men the right to tell another kind of men what they must do." Howard reacted angrily, interpreting the statement as a challenge to his authority. When Toohoolhoolzote protested, he was jailed for five days. The day following the council, Joseph, White Bird, and Looking Glass all accompanied Howard to look at different areas. Howard offered them a plot of land that was inhabited by Whites and Native Americans, promising to clear them out. Joseph and his chieftains refused, adhering to their tribal tradition of not taking what did not belong to them. Unable to find any suitable uninhabited land on the reservation, Howard informed Joseph that his people had thirty days to collect their livestock and move to the reservation. Joseph pleaded for more time, but Howard told him that he would consider their presence in the Wallowa Valley beyond the thirty-day mark an act of war. Returning home, Joseph called a council among his people. At the council, he spoke on behalf of peace, preferring to abandon his father's grave over war. Toohoolhoolzote, insulted by his incarceration, advocated war. The Wallowa band began making preparations for the long journey, meeting first with other bands at Rocky Canyon. At this council too, many leaders urged war, while Joseph argued in favor of peace. While the council was underway, a young man whose father had been killed rode up and announced that he and several other young men had already killed four white settlers. Still hoping to avoid further bloodshed, Joseph and other non-treaty Nez Perce leaders began moving people away from Idaho.
TEXT.German: [H1]Chief Joseph[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Häuptling der Nez Perce[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ca. 1840 - 1904 n. Chr.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Chief Joseph oder Hinmaton-Yalatkit (auch Hinmuuttu-yalatlat - "Donner-der-den-Berg-herunter-rollt" oder Hinmatooyalahtq'it - "Donner-der-zu-höheren-Gebieten-wandert" war der Häuptling der Wal-lam-wat-kain (meist als Wallowa bezeichnet)-Gruppe der Nez Perce-Indianer aus dem Wallowa-Flußtal im nordöstlichen Oregon. Er machte sich gegen Ende der Indianerkriege während des Nez-Perce-Krieges einen Namen als kluger Taktiker. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In der zweiten Hälfte des 19. Jahrhunderts drangen immer mehr weiße Siedler in den Lebensraum der Nez Perce ein. Die US-Regierung ließ die Nez Perce umsiedeln und ihr fruchtbares Gebiet für die Besiedelung durch die Weißen freigeben. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Chief Joseph war weder ein Oberhäuptling, noch hatte er den Rang eines Kriegshäuptlings. Ueber Krieg und Frieden bestimmten die bewährten Krieger. Das Machtgefüge der Indianergruppe war so kompliziert wie die US-amerikanische Bürokratie, die sich seit Ende 1872 mit ihrer Umsiedlungsfrage beschäftigte. Die Nez Perce wehrten sich gegen die geplante Umsiedlung und wollten unter Josephs Leitung nach Kanada fliehen. Am 6. Juni 1877 brachen sie auf. Unterwegs kam es immer wieder zu Kämpfen mit US-Truppen, die der US-Armee mehrere Niederlagen einbrachten. Die Flucht zog sich über vier Monate und 2400 Kilometer quer durch die Bundesstaaten Oregon, Wyoming, Idaho und Montana hin, brachte 123 Soldaten und 55 Zivilisten den Tod und kostete die Armee damals 931.329 Dollar. Zivile Schäden und Verwundete wurden nicht eingerechnet. Die Nez Perce zählten etwa 100-120 Tote, darunter Josephs Bruder Ollokot, Toolhoolhoolzote und Looking Glass;. Erst ein bis zwei Tagesritte (40 Meilen) vor der kanadischen Grenze kapitulierte Chief Joseph am 5. Oktober 1877 in den Bear Paw Mountains vor General Oliver Otis Howard und Oberst Miles, da seine Leute nur unter Zurücklaßung der Verwundeten, alten Frauen und Kinder hätten fliehen können. Etwa 430 Nez Perce gingen in Gefangenschaft. Etwa 50 Leute entkamen in der Nacht vor der Kapitulation nach Kanada, vor allem White Bird, der Chief Josephs Verhalten ablehnte. Insgesamt fanden etwa 200 Nez Perce bei der Lakota-Gruppe von Sitting Bull im kanadischen Exil Zuflucht. Erst 1885 wurde ein Teil der Nez Perce an den Columbia-Fluß in Idaho verlegt, der andere Teil nach Colville in Washington. Dort starb Chief Joseph am 21. September 1904; gemäß seinem Arzt an gebrochenem Herzen. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Der Häuptling wurde übereinstimmend als Mann von gutem Benehmen beschrieben, als aufgeschlossen und intelligent. Für indianische Verhältnisse galt er nicht als überragender Krieger und ließ daher Looking Glass;, Toolhoolhoolzote, Ollokot und anderen den Vortritt. Er taktierte so oft es ging und wird daher als "indianischer Napoleon" charakterisiert.

TEXT.English: I present my friendship to the strangers with the iron skins. I am [OUR_NAME], and I am enjoying the honor to lead the fierce and independent [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Join us when our shamans petition the ancestral spirits for guidance in our future relationship.
TEXT.French: I present my friendship to the strangers with the iron skins. I am [OUR_NAME], and I am enjoying the honor to lead the fierce and independent [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Join us when our shamans petition the ancestral spirits for guidance in our future relationship.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Mapuche. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Go away. I need to go hunting. On your people.
TEXT.French: Go away. I need to go hunting. On your people.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Why should we make peace when we enjoy slaughtering you [CT_CIV_ADJ] cowards so much?
TEXT.French: Why should we make peace when we enjoy slaughtering you [CT_CIV_ADJ] cowards so much?
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome friend. Join me in my tent, and we can discuss the actions of the spirits that guide us.
TEXT.French: Welcome friend. Join me in my tent, and we can discuss the actions of the spirits that guide us.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Lautaro aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Talking to you is like sleeping on an anthill. Do me a favor, and keep it as concise as possible. And then go away. I like the backside of your head much more than your face.
TEXT.French: Talking to you is like sleeping on an anthill. Do me a favor, and keep it as concise as possible. And then go away. I like the backside of your head much more than your face.
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: The Church
Church
TEXT.German: Kirche

TEXT.English: [H1]Church in the New World[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]When Columbus discovered the New World in 1492, the discovery sparked many theological debates in Europe. Especially, the presence of millions of natives, who never heard about Christ or Christianity, interested European theologians. Theologians disagreed with one another about the humanity of natives, the justification of their brutal treatment, the legitimacy of slavery of non-christians, and the best way of converting them to christianity. Pope Alexander VI divided the New World in 1493 between Spain en Portugal, and ordered these nations to bring both continents under christian rule. Sanctioned by the highest ecclesiastical authorities of their time, the Spanish conquistadors embarked on several campaigns of exploration and conquest, often brutally slaughtering the natives they encountered, which was justified by invoking their great mission of spreading Christianity over the world. Priests and missionaries travelled with the conquistadors, some aiding in the forced conversion of subdued natives, while others went into the wilderness to convert indian nations that yet had to be conquered. As a result, Catholic Christianity became the dominant religion in all regions under Spanish or Portuguese administration, a situation that persists until the present day. The missionaries became powerful factors in New World politics. The Jesuits established missions in South America, particularly among the Guarani people of modern-day Paraguay, which protected these indians from slavery and the brutal treatment of Portuguese and Spanish colonists. The Franciscans and Dominicans founded missions in California and New Mexico. These orders had a mighty ally in the Catholic Church, which allowed them a large degree of independence from worldy powers like Spain and Portugal. [PARAGRAPH:1]The protestant religions were introduced later than the catholic religions in the New World. When English, Dutch and Swedish colonization of North America began, the colonists brought their various religions along with them. After the English had gained the upper hand over their competitors in eastern North America, their colonies became a patchwork of small, diverse religious sects, of which many had escaped persecution in the Old World, where their religious ideas were considered radical. While some of these sects persecuted and outlawed one another at various points in the history of New England, no single one of them ever managed to become dominant enough to force the others out. This lack of a dominant religion was one of the main motivations for the Founding Fathers to argue for the Separation of Church and State, to be able to unite the various sects under one flag. [PARAGRAPH:1]A major difference between the English protestants in North America and the catholics in Central-South America, was their idea of the New World and its natives, and their place in the world. While the catholics aimed to convert the native population and assimilate them into new, catholic states, the English had little interest in conversion of natives. They viewed the New World as destined for them by god, and saw the natives as a nuisance that needed to be extinguished. This idea of Manifest Destiny was strengthened by the great mortality of indians to European diseases, which was interpreted as an act of God, to cleanse the land for his chosen people to inhabit. Like the catholics a century earlier, the protestants in North America justified the large-scale slaughter of natives by invoking the divine command to spread Christianity over the entire world. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nowadays, South and Central America are still predominantly catholic, while North America still has no dominant religion. The main christian groups in the United States today are Catholics, Baptists, Methodists, Mormons, Lutherans, Anglicans and Pentacostals.

[PARAGRAPH:1]Nowadays, South and Central America are still predominantly catholic, while North America still has no dominant religion. The main christian groups in the United States today are Catholics, Baptists, Methodists, Mormons, Lutherans, Anglicans and Pentacostals.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kirche in der Neuen Welt[H1][\H1][PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Als Kolumbus 1492 die Neue Welt entdeckte, löste dies viele theologische Debatten in Europa aus. Vorallem die Existenz von Millionen Ureinwohner, die nie von Christus gehört hatten, interessierte die europäischen Theologen sehr. Viel Unstimmigkeit gab es bezüglich der Menschlichkeit der Ureinwohner, der Rechtfertigung der brutalen Behandlung durch die Europäer, der Rechmässigkeit der Versklavung von Nicht-Christen und bezüglich des besten Weges um die Ureinwohner zu christianisieren. Papst Alexander VI teilte die Neue Welt zwischen Spanien und Portugal auf und befahl diesen Nationen die beiden Kontinente Amerikas unter christliche Herrschaft zu bringen. Von den höchsten geistlichen Authoritäten der Zeit sanktioniert, brachen die spanischen Conquistadores zu mehreren Kampagnen zur Erkundung und Eroberung auf. Dabei schlachteten sie oft die Ureinwohner, die sie trafen, brutal ab und rechtfertigten dies mit der Verbreitung des Christentums in der Welt. Priester und Missionare reisten mit den Conquistadores. Einige halfen bei der erzwungenen Konvertierung der unterworfenen Ureinwohner, während andere in die Wildnis zogen um die Ureinwohnerstämme, die noch nicht erobert wurden zu konvertieren. Als Resultat daraus, wurde das katholische Christentum die dominante Religion in allen Gebieten unter spanischer oder portugiesischer Herrschaft, wie es auch bis heute der Fall ist. Die Missionare wurden ein mächtiger Faktor in der Politik der Neuen Welt. Die Jesuiten errichteten Missionen in Südamerika. Vorallem unter den Guarani, ein Volk das im heutigen Paraguay siedelte. Diese Missionen schützten die Ureinwohner vor der Sklavereie und Mishandlung durch spanische und portugiesische Kolonisten. Die Franziskander und Domenikaner errichteten Missionen in Kalifornien und Neu-Mexiko. Durch ihren mächtigen Alliierten, den Papst, gelang es ihnen weitgehen undabhängig von der weltlichen Herrschaft der Spanier und Portugiesen zu bleiben. [PARAGRAPH:1] Die protestantischen Religionen verbreiteten sich erst viel später in der Neuen Welt. Als die Kolonisation durch Engländer, Holländer und Schweden in Nordamerika begann, brachten diese natürlich ihren Glauben mit. Nachdem die Engländer die Oberhand gegen ihre Konkurrenten im östlichen Nordamerika erlangt hatten, entwickelten sich ihre Siedlungen zu einer Art Zusammenschluss verschiedener religiöser Sekten, die der Verfolgung in der Alten Welt entkommen wollten. Obwohl die verschiedenen Sekten sich teilweise gegenseitig bannten und verfolgten, gelang es keiner dieser Sekten, die Dominanz zu erringen. Diese fehlende Dominanz einer einzigen Religion, war die massgebliche Motivation der Gründerväter für eine Teilung von Kirche und Staat zu argumentieren. [PARAGRAPH:1]Einer der grössten Unterschiede zwischen den Protestanten in Nordamerika und den Katholiken in Zentral- und Südamerika, war die Art und Weise, wie sie die Ureinwohner und ihren eigenen Platz in der neuen Welt sahen. Während die Katholiken darauf abzielten, die Ureinwohner zu konvertieren und in die neuen katholischen Staaten zu assimilieren, hatten die Engländer daran wenig Interesse. Sie sahen die Neue Welt als ihr von Gott gegebenes Schicksal und die Ureiwohner als wenig mehr, als eine Störung des göttlichen Plans, die beseitigt werden musste. Selbst die hohen Sterblichkeit der Ureinwohner, durch die von Europäern eingeschleppten Krankheiten, wurde als Werk Gottes interpretiert, um das Land für sein auserwähltes Volk zu säubern. Wie die Katholiken es ein Jahrhundert zuvor getan hatten, rechtfertigten die Protestanten den gross angelegten Völkermord durch den göttlichen Auftrag, das Christentum in der gesamten Welt zu verbreiten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Heutzutage sind Zentral- und Südamerika immer noch weitgehend katholisch, während es in Nordamerika keine dominante Religion gibt. Die grössten christlichen Gruppen in den Vereinigten Staaten sind Katholiken, Baptisten, Methodisten, Mormonen, Lutheraner und Anglikaner.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Church in the New World[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]When Columbus discovered the New World in 1492, the discovery sparked many theological debates in Europe. Especially, the presence of millions of natives, who never heard about Christ or Christianity, interested European theologians. Theologians disagreed with one another about the humanity of natives, the justification of their brutal treatment, the legitimacy of slavery of non-christians, and the best way of converting them to christianity. Pope Alexander VI divided the New World in 1493 between Spain en Portugal, and ordered these nations to bring both continents under christian rule. Sanctioned by the highest ecclesiastical authorities of their time, the Spanish conquistadors embarked on several campaigns of exploration and conquest, often brutally slaughtering the natives they encountered, which was justified by invoking their great mission of spreading Christianity over the world. Priests and missionaries travelled with the conquistadors, some aiding in the forced conversion of subdued natives, while others went into the wilderness to convert indian nations that yet had to be conquered. As a result, Catholic Christianity became the dominant religion in all regions under Spanish or Portuguese administration, a situation that persists until the present day. The missionaries became powerful factors in New World politics. The Jesuits established missions in South America, particularly among the Guarani people of modern-day Paraguay, which protected these indians from slavery and the brutal treatment of Portuguese and Spanish colonists. The Franciscans and Dominicans founded missions in California and New Mexico. These orders had a mighty ally in the Catholic Church, which allowed them a large degree of independence from worldy powers like Spain and Portugal. [PARAGRAPH:1]The protestant religions were introduced later than the catholic religions in the New World. When English, Dutch and Swedish colonization of North America began, the colonists brought their various religions along with them. After the English had gained the upper hand over their competitors in eastern North America, their colonies became a patchwork of small, diverse religious sects, of which many had escaped persecution in the Old World, where their religious ideas were considered radical. While some of these sects persecuted and outlawed one another at various points in the history of New England, no single one of them ever managed to become dominant enough to force the others out. This lack of a dominant religion was one of the main motivations for the Founding Fathers to argue for the Separation of Church and State, to be able to unite the various sects under one flag. [PARAGRAPH:1]A major difference between the English protestants in North America and the catholics in Central-South America, was their idea of the New World and its natives, and their place in the world. While the catholics aimed to convert the native population and assimilate them into new, catholic states, the English had little interest in conversion of natives. They viewed the New World as destined for them by god, and saw the natives as a nuisance that needed to be extinguished. This idea of Manifest Destiny was strengthened by the great mortality of indians to European diseases, which was interpreted as an act of God, to cleanse the land for his chosen people to inhabit. Like the catholics a century earlier, the protestants in North America justified the large-scale slaughter of natives by invoking the divine command to spread Christianity over the entire world. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nowadays, South and Central America are still predominantly catholic, while North America still has no dominant religion. The main christian groups in the United States today are Catholics, Baptists, Methodists, Mormons, Lutherans, Anglicans and Pentacostals.
